With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Desert nomads dashing to the Saudi border with refugees from Kuwait have hundreds of new landmarks to guide them as they evade a gauntlet of Iraqi soldiers. ``Now we are using the abandoned cars as a sign of where to go,'' said Abdullah Al-Ajmi, a Bedouin guide who planned to make his next foray into Kuwait today. Aside from the hundreds of stranded cars left by escapees, the nomads rely on trees, telegraph poles and geography on the dangerous journey. ``I know not to turn, at say the first hill but at the second hill,'' said al-Ajmi, thinking of his routes. ``I know the desert very well from hunting trips before the invasion.'' Tens of thousands of refugees arrived across the desert sands in the first three weeks after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Although refugees still come across the border, this frontier town has largely fallen silent. The only sound at midday is a rope flapping against an aluminum flagpole. With buildups of more than 100,000 troops on both sides of the border, the Saudi government over the weekend declared all but the official border crossing a closed military area. ``This is the new policy,'' Governor Khalid al-Otaishan said before entering a meeting with Saudi and American military officers. There are constant consultations about plans in case of an Iraqi attack. A Saudi official in Dhahran, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Saudi army is fanning out along the front lines _ with the Americans at least 25 miles behind them. ``We would never put Americans up near the border. That could be disastrous politically,'' the official said. ``If there are going to be casualties a Saudi will have to die first.'' Meanwhile, doctors at the Red Crescent tents near the border said there are reports of deaths among those fleeing Kuwait as they run out of water. The Red Crescent is the equivalent of the Red Cross in Moslem countries. People who crossed the border Sunday said the Iraqis are now shooting at anything that moves. One car arrived with its right headlights smashed, a second with its spare tire punctured. About 60 people trickled across Sunday, including a group of 35 Pakistani and Bangladeshi workers in two vehicles. They lost a pickup truck plus all their food, water, cigarettes and video tapes to an Iraqi soldier. ``We were always afraid,'' said Aboul Qassem, a 44-year-old refinery worker from Bangladesh. He said he decided to get out after Iraqi soldiers led away four Westerners working in a hospital near where he works. Iraqi troops have also taken to burning automobile showrooms and Western-style supermarkets, Qassem said. The fear is not deterring some from crossing into Kuwait to try to bring out family members. ``It's very difficult and dangerous,'' said al-Ajma. ``If there are too many Iraqis on the way we have to turn back.'' Mohammed al-Matar, who planned to cross back into Kuwait with al-Ajma, said that on two previous trips they got past Iraqi troops with gifts of bananas, cigarettes and cold water. ``One group told us that for four days they had been drinking the water from the windshield washers of abandoned cars,'' he said. Groups usually travel around 2 p.m., when the temperature climbs above 100 degrees and the soldiers usually seek shelter to rest.

DOC.HEAD: Military Worries About R-and-R for Troops; T-Shirt Sales Boom
With PM_Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military officials say they're just beginning to think about how to provide rest-and-relaxation breaks for thousands of Americans deployed in the Saudi Arabian desert. One possibility is renting a hotel where soldiers can take a break from the searing desert conditions, according to Maj. Gen. Gus Pagonis, who is in charge of logistics for Operation Desert Shield. Soldiers are already grumbling about Saudi Arabia's prohibition on alcohol. But Pagonis isn't worried about that. ``The alcohol has not been a problem whatsoever,'' he said. ``We wouldn't be able to keep the beer cold anyway.''

The State Department recently re-evaluated the pay structure at the American Embassy in Kuwait and concluded employees there were making too much money. As a result, the so-called ``hardship post'' differential was cut from 25 percent to 20 percent. The change was made before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. There's no word on whether officials now plan to up the amount. The 30-odd staffers at the American Consulate in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, also receive a 20 percent differential. The amount of the differential depends on a number of factors, including weather, the quality of health care, danger, availablity of goods and services, and mail service. In Kuwait City, Iraqi soldiers cut off electricity and other utilities to the U.S. Embassy and surrounded the compound, where Ambassador Nathaniel Hawthorne and about 10 staff members remain in defiance of Iraq's order to close foreign embassies.

The T-shirt business is booming in Saudi Arabia with soldiers, reporters and American expatriates the biggest customers. Soldiers with privileges to visit shops near Dhahran buy the shirts in bulk, reselling them to the troops. Among the most popular slogans: _ ``Between Iraq and A Hard Place.'' Underneath is a map of Saudi Arabia, with Dhahran singled out. _ ``Visit Iraq Before Iraq Visits You,'' with a Saudi map on the front. _ ``U.S. Armed Forces: Summer Tour 1990. _ ``Hard Luck Cafe, Kuwait City, Kuwait.''

American women and children aren't the only ones who left Dhahran after Iraq invaded Kuwait three weeks ago. Most pets have been shipped home too. One British Airways flight carried 71 canines in its hold. ``Bandit is in boarding school in Paso Robles, Calif.,'' said Janice Stockwell, who performs ultrasounds at a hospital run by the state-owned Saudi Aramco oil company. She said she spent $900 to ship the border collie back to her parents' house, and added that many of her friends also sent their pets home. ``I know I would get out, but what kind of priority is he'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Battered Ship Heads for Safety Under Own Power
DOC.TEXT: A ship foundering in high seas with a crew of 17 headed for shelter under its own power today in the Western Pacific after a Coast Guard plane dropped replacements for its faulty bilge pumps. The 146-foot Royal Taipan had been reported in danger of sinking after it began taking on water in 25-foot seas churned by 45 mph tropical storm winds. An air-and-sea search was slowed by poor radio communication and an inaccurate position reported by the former Navy minesweeper, which was caught by the storm as it cruised to a shipyard for renovations, the Coast Gurad. The Royal Taipan, whose owners intend to refurbish as a cruise ship, was expected to reach Ulithi Atoll in the Federated States of Micronesia today, Coast Guard spokesman Lt. Kent Youel said. The ship radioed for help Saturday night when it ran into the fringes of Tropical Storm Abe, officials said. Someone on board gave the ship's position as 225 miles south-southwest of Guam, the Coast Guard said. It was located today by a search plane based in Hawaii that homed in on an electronic emergency beacon about 500 miles southwest of Guam. The ship was in 10- to 15-foot seas and 40 mph winds when the pumps were dropped to the crew to replace the vessel's three failed pumps, Youel said. At the atoll, the ship will be met by a patrol boat based nearby so officers can inspect the vessel and determine its seaworthiness, Youel said. The Royal Taipan, owned by Windjammer Cruises of Honolulu, had left the Philippines for Saipan, in the Northern Mariana Islands, said the Coast Guard. The crew reportedly was made up of Filipinos and Americans.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Desert Force Still Missing Spare Parts, Heavy Equipment, Weapons
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To comply with Pentagon ground rules for access to U.S. military installations, the exact locations of those facilities and specifics about security precautions cannot be published.
DOC.TEXT: In the swiftness of the U.S. military deployment, a limited transport capability has left some units still without anti-aircraft weapons and other equipment field commanders consider vital. Yet to arrive are the biggest American tanks, armored vehicles and artillery _ all key cogs in the U.S. strategy for any extended desert ground war against Iraqi troops. Some field commanders report isolated shortages of parts. Others are still waiting for ground-to-air anti-aircraft protection. But the unprecedented deployment of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia so far appears to have proceeded without major problems. ``We've accomplished miracles in a short period of time,'' said Army Maj. Gen. Gus Pagonis, who is in charge of logistics for the U.S. deployment. Pagonis, who met with reporters near a major U.S. staging area in Saudi Arabia, called the effort ``probably the largest exercise ever accomplished in a short period of time since World War II.'' The delays in getting the heavy equipment are blamed not on logistical or command lapses but on the limited capacity of the military's air and sea transport capacity. Officials say many of the concerns should be addressed over the next week to 10 days, as more ships arrive. Pagonis said an average of 50 transport flights arrive in Saudi Arabia daily, carrying troops, equipment and supplies he is hoping to build into at least a 30-day reserve stockpile. Much of the heavy equipment sought by field commanders _ M-1 tanks, armored vehicles, heavy artillery and anti-aircraft batteries _ are on ships headed for the Saudi kingdom. The first such shipment is due to arrive by midweek; the tanks will be deployed into the desert in northeastern Saudi Arabia. The United States has no military stockpiles in the Middle East. With the emphasis in getting troops to Saudi Arabia, Air Force cargo planes had carried only limited equipment until last week, when civilian aircraft were pressed into duty as troop carriers. Also, it takes more than 24 hours to fly from the United States to Saudi Arabia and nearly a month for even the fastest sealift ships to make the trip, and the Navy has just eight of those. Pagonis said he assumed the United States would explore establishing a storage depot somewhere in the region. Among units still waiting for some of its heavy equipment is an Army helicopter unit based in the Saudi desert. The unit would need forward-based refueling and repair facilities in the event of extended fighting, but had just a few mobile fuel tankers as of Saturday _ barely enough to keep choppers at its staging camp refueled. ``If they go to forward positions, I would have nothing back here,' an officer with the unit said. The officer also said stockpiles of certain spare parts were low _ parts that would be needed in any extended combat situation because of the toll of the desert heat and sand on the helicopters and other equipment. ``We're told they'll be here pretty soon,'' the officer said. Another concern voiced by a number of officers was the shortage at some sites of heavy artillery and ground-to-air defense systems. ``We're concerned about it,'' an Air Force officer said during a recent visit to his desert base area when asked about the lack of anti-aircraft protection. ``We're pretty naked out here right now.'' The concern for heavy ground forces, particularly tanks and armored vehicles, stems from Iraq's formidable tank force. Air Force Col. Sandy Sharpe, commander of a wing of A-10 tank-killers stationed in the Saudi desert, said his unit had a few minor problems with spare parts but said, ``they'll roll in.'' Still, Sharpe said the deployment here proved the need for an expanded air-transport capacity to guarantee against any shortages. ``If you don't have it, you can have all the jets in the world and they'll just sit,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average gained 976.00 points on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Monday, up from 24,165.76 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Ambassador: Israel is Lying Low
DOC.TEXT: Israel is lying low during the Persian Gulf crisis to avoid upsetting any joint U.S.-Arab effort to contain Iraq, Israel's ambassador to the United States says. Moshe Arad also said Saddam Hussein's attack on Kuwait supports Israel's long-held belief that the Iraqi president is dangerous. Israel claimed to have thwarted Iraq's efforts to develop nuclear weapons by bombing an Iraqi reactor in 1981. ``Now, we feel vindicated. But that doesn't make us any happier,'' Arad told a gathering of the International B'nai B'rith on Sunday. ``For these recent events bring the danger of another war in the Middle East closer to Israel, and yes, closer to America.'' Arad addressed about 1,000 people from more than 40 countries at the gathering of the world's largest Jewish organization. He said that to prevent upsetting any U.S.-Arab efforts to turn back Saddam, the Jewish state is ``keeping a low profile in the crisis.'' America is widely resented in the Arab world because it is seen as Israel's protector. Arad said Arab-Israeli friction is just part of the formula creating tension in the Middle East. ``The major source of conflict is the intent of Arab dictators to pursue their grand designs to achieve power and influence through military might,'' he said. ``Indeed, the absence of democratic regimes in the Arab world and the wild enthusiasm for violence there will make the resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict even more difficult.'' American support for Arab countries opposing Saddam, including recent approval of sophisticated new fighter planes for Saudi Arabia, might one day hurt Israel, the statesman said. ``When this crisis is over, we must remember that there might be another crisis, with its center an Arab front against Israel,'' Arad said. ``The present conflict and crisis should not be allowed to ... upset the military balance in the region.'' The ambassador took the opportunity to blast longtime enemies for their actions during the crisis. Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat's support of Saddam shows ``the kind of regime he would impose on his own people, and the kind of peace the PLO intends for the region and for Israel,'' he said. Arad criticized _ and warned _ King Hussein of Jordan, who he said ``is trying to please Saddam.'' ``Unless he takes a courageous position against Iraqi aggression, he might find himself pretty soon the next victim on Saddam's list,'' Arad said.

DOC.HEAD: Black, White Leaders Reach Tentative Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Black and white leaders reached a tentative agreement to give blacks equal representation on the Selma school board and end eight months of racial strife, the mayor says. ``We're trying to throw politics out the window and reach some kind of agreement that everybody can live with,'' Mayor Joe Smitherman said. City Council members and Smitherman met with about two dozen black leaders Sunday night to draw up the agreement, he said. Smitherman said ``there are still questions to be answered'' but that he hoped to announce the details today. The proposal would end white dominance of the school board and ultimately establish a plan to alternate control between the two factions, said Smitherman, who is white. The 5,900-student district is about 80 percent black. The 11-member school board's five blacks walked out in December after the six whites on the panel refused to renew the contract of Norward Roussell, the district's first black superintendent. Demonstrations, lawsuits, boycotts and scuffles followed. A black protest leader was arrested twice. The agreement would have five white and five black board members voting on all issues. Board chairman Carl Barker, who is white, would vote only when school litigation matters were involved. Once all the lawsuits are resolved the panel would revert to a plan in which whites and blacks would take turns in control, the mayor said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo On Mideast Optimism, Dollar Drops
DOC.TEXT: Optimism about the Middle East situation prevailed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, lifting share prices sharply. The dollar declined against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 428 points on Friday, rose 976.00 points, or 4.04 percent, to close at 25,141.76. Dealers attributed the Nikkei index's rise to the general sentiment among investors that the unrest in the Middle East will not escalate in the immediate future. ``Investors have been extremely sensitive about the Iraqi situation, and as a result, they have overreacted to the daily development in the Middle East,'' said a dealer with Nomura Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. The Nikkei index shed 2,620.96 last week amid continuing uncertainties over the Persian Gulf crisis. Between Iraqi's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and last Friday the Nikkei plunged 6,668 points, or 21.6 percent. Dealers said they expect the Nikkei index to continue to rise unless ``something drastic happens'' in the Middle East. A dealer with Nikko Securities Co., while warning of future uncertainties, acknowledged that ``investors are finding some of the shares have fallen to bargain levels.'' Volume traded on the first section of the exchange was 330 million shares. On the currency market, the dollar closed at 144.80 yen, down 0.90 yen from Friday's close of 145.70 yen. After opening at 145.20 yen, the currency moved in a range of 144.80-145.55 yen. Currency dealers said trading was mixed throughout today. ``While some investors are trying to sell the dollar because of their pessimistic evaluations of the U.S. economy, other investors are buying it because of the continuing uncertainties over the (Persian) Gulf situation,'' said Akiko Baba, a customer dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Another dealer at Daiichi Kangyo Bank said the currency lost ground toward the end of the day in response to the news report that Javier Perez de Cuellar, secretary-general of the United Nations, would meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz later this week to discuss the crisis. ``When likelihood of a war increases, the dollar is usually bought, and when the opposite occurs, the dollar goes down,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 8.215 percent at 4:00 p.m. from Friday's 8.355-percent close. Their price stood at 82.58 points, up from 81.99.

DOC.HEAD: Stranger Posts Bail for Man Charged in Wife's Suicide
DOC.TEXT: A 72-year-old man charged with helping his wife commit suicide has been bailed out of jail by a bondsman he had never met. ``This man is not a criminal. He was just trying to do the right thing for someone he loved,'' said Carl Wardlaw, who posted the $25,000 that got Bertram Harper out of jail Sunday. Harper, of Loomis, Calif., is charged with murder and conspiracy in the Aug. 19 suicide of his 69-year-old wife, Virginia Lee, in a Romulus hotel room. Mrs. Harper, who was said to have cancer, flew to Michigan on Aug. 18. Police said she killed herself by taking pills and putting a plastic bag over her head while her husband and stepdaughter stood by. Harper said they came to Michigan after learning the state has no specific laws against suicide or assisting in it. He said the death of an Oregon woman who used a doctor's suicide machine brought the state's law to his attention. Wardlaw, a bondsman for 10 years, said it was the first time he had used his own money to bail out someone. ``I bail out so many people who don't deserve it, people who probably belong where they are,'' he said. ``I used to be married and I loved my wife. If she had ever been in that kind of situation I would have wanted to do the same for her.'' Dr. Jack Kevorkian, builder of the suicide machine used June 4 by Alzheimer's victim Janet Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore., has not been charged.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``They have no place to go and are left between the guns of the Americans and Egyptians and the guns of Iraq.'' _ Saeb Erakat, a West Bank professor and activist for the Palestine Liberation Organization, discussing the plight of Palestinians in Kuwait.

``We're not asking for money or anything like that. We're asking only for permission for her family and her to live here with legal permission so she could work.'' _ Colombian Consul Bertha Ospina, seeking support for the defection to the United States of Clara Parra, a judge who received an anonymous death threat believed to be related to Columbia's drug wars.

``In those days, they figured that if you had diabetes, you didn't have a chance. And my parents were highly skeptical of insulin.'' _ Urvan Ubben, 77, who in 1922 became one of the first people to test insulin and is now regarded by experts as possibly the world's oldest surviving diabetic.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Says Soviets Won't Use Force in Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, which over the weekend supported a U.N. resolution sanctioning military action to back an international trade embargo against Iraq, says it will not include itself among the enforcers. But Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Sunday that Moscow would not object if the United States and other nations use force ``within the framework of that resolution.'' In a joint statement, Shevardnadze and visiting French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas urged Iraq to ``show realism and common sense and to heed the will of the international community expressed in the resolutions of the Security Council on the (Persian) Gulf crisis.'' The U.N. Security Council approved the resolution Saturday. It called for ``such measures commensurate with the specific circumstances as may be necessary'' to end trade with Iraq, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and annexed it. The Soviet Union has two warships in the Gulf of Oman, and they are part of a large international naval armada in the Persian Gulf region to pressure Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. But Shevardnadze said Moscow had no plans to send any more vessels to the region, adding: ``We will not take part in the use of any force. ``We voted (for the U.N. resolution) because other nations ... are ready to take part in inspecting the ships, craft, vessels, which are suspected of carrying prohibited products and merchandise,'' he said. ``The United States and other countries which are represented in this area _ I mean which have their own armed forces _ they should act, but within the framework of that resolution,'' he said. The Soviet Union, however, continued diplomatic efforts to resolve the three-week-old Middle East crisis. Egypt's foreign minister, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, met with Shevardnadaze today, Tass said without providing details. At a news conference with Dumas on Sunday, Shevardnadze denied reports that 193 Soviet military advisers still in Iraq are participating ``in preparing details of military operations.'' He said the advisers would be brought home soon after their contracts expire and Soviet women and children have been evacuated. Shevardnadze, however, noted that U.N. resolutions do not prohibit the presence of advisers, but acknowledged ``there is a moral side of the issue and the political aspect, and we understand this.'' ``Certain mass media put forward information that our military advisers take part in preparing details of military operations, etc. That is not true,'' he said. Soviet officials said last week that the military experts continue to repair and maintain Soviet-built weapons and teach Iraqi soldiers how to use them. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov said Friday that about 900 of the 7,791 Soviets still in Iraq are women and children, whom he hoped would be evacuated by Sept. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Among Casualties In Major Cabinet Shakeup
DOC.TEXT: Thailand's foreign minister, architect of its hard-line stance this past decade on Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia, lost his post in a major Cabinet reshuffle today. Five new deputy prime ministers were named and the heads of six of the 13 ministries were replaced in the shakeup, which was engineered by Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan and announced by his office. It was designed to boost the government's image after corruption scandals in which two deputy ministers had been fired. Siddhi Savetsila, foreign minister since 1980, was replaced by Subin Pinkayan, who had been commerce minister. Siddhi's deputy, Prapas Limpabhandu, also was replaced. They both belonged to the scandal-plagued Social Action Party but were not themselves accused of any wrongdoing. ``We have to change to a new team ... but foreign policy will not change,'' Chatichai told reporters today. Siddhi had led efforts to isolate and punish Vietnam after it invaded Cambodia in late 1978, installed a new Communist government and put thousands of hostile troops at Thailand's doorstep. But his influence declined markedly after Chatichai became premier in August 1988 and set out to turn Indochina's ``battlefields into marketplaces.'' Thailand still backs the Cambodian guerrilla forces, but Siddhi's approach gave way to Thai mediation in peace talks involving increased contacts with Vietnam and the Vietnamese-installed government. Also, two well-known technocrats without any party affiliation took over key ministries. Virabongse Ramangura became finance minister and Amaret Sila-on became commerce minister. The reshuffle added a seventh party to the ruling coalition, the Puangchon Chaothai Party of former Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Arthit Kamlang-ek. Arthit became a deputy premier. Arthit went into politics after he was fired as army chief in May 1986 by former Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda for publicly challenging the government. The government was badly shaken by scandals that led to the firing the past two weeks of two deputy ministers belonging to the Social Action Party. Fired Saturday was Deputy Commerce Minister Pinya Chuayplod, who was held responsible for the import of parts for assembling illegal gambling machines. Deputy Interior Minister Santi Chaivirattana was sacked Aug. 15 after accusations that he took bribes to ease safety regulations of gas stations. Due to the scandals, Siddhi last week resigned as leader of the Social Action Party and returned the reins to Kukrit Pramoj, 79, a former prime minister who founded the party and had gone into political retirement. The conservative, pro-West Chatichai administration has been dogged by allegations of corruption since it came to power for a four-year term in the July 1988 parliamentary election.

DOC.HEAD: Keenan Spent Most of Captivity Chained and Blindfolded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with hospital statement. Picks up 5th pvs, `Keenan, a...'
DOC.TEXT: Freed Irish hostage Brian Keenan spent most of his nearly 4{ years in captivity in Lebanon chained and blindfolded with British captive John McCarthy in a tiny basement room, one of Keenan's doctors says. ``For much of the time they weren't allowed to talk above a whisper and the heat and the mosquitoes were terrible,'' Dr. Sean Blake said Sunday, a day after Keenan arrived in Dublin. Keenan also said he had been beaten by his captors but ``he didn't go into any detail and I didn't ask him about it,'' Blake said. Blake, a cardiologist, is one of the doctors tending Keenan at Mater hospital in Dublin, where he was taken for a checkup after his flight home from Syria aboard an Irish government jet. Keenan was freed Friday in Beirut and turned over to Irish officials in Syria a day later. The hospital said this morning that Keenan complained of sore eyes and noise in his ears, and had dental cavities. The hospital statement described the problems as minor and said Keenan would begin physiotherapy today. Keenan, a 39-year-old Belfast teacher, spent his first full day back in Ireland undergoing medical tests and making phone calls to the families of McCarthy and other hostages he left behind in Lebanon, including Americans Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. Keenan said Saturday that he saw Anderson and Sutherland during his captivity, and that they were in good spirits. He was to undergo more tests today, including a psychiatric examination. ``He's very good with the doctors and especially good with the nurses,'' Keenan's sister Brenda Gillham said with a chuckle. She said her brother was tired but ``in very good spirits'' and eating everything in sight. Sister Gemma Byrne, the hospital's chief executive, said Keenan had lost 42 pounds in captivity and ``must have a complete rest.'' Blake said Keenan was somewhat malnourished and unfit from lack of physical activity but otherwise appeared ``very well.'' The fifth Western hostage freed in as many months, Keenan was kidnapped April 11, 1986, in west Beirut while walking to the American University where he taught English. During his first months in captivity, Keenan said he was held in a prison where there were only Arabs and felt very isolated because he didn't speak the language, Blake said. After some months, Keenan said McCarthy joined him and they gave each other ``mutual support,'' Blake said. McCarthy, 33, a reporter for the London-based Worldwide Television News, was captured April 17, 1986. ``Up to six months ago, they were living in this tiny room in a basement, chained and blindfolded for much of the time,'' the doctor said. During that time, Keenan said there was no possibility for any physical activity and the food was meager, Blake said. But six months ago, Keenan said their treatment improved: they were given meat for the first time and were able ``to do some sort of exercise,'' Blake said. He said Keenan told him that his captors came to the room he shared with McCarthy on Thursday and started to take him away without explanation. ``He said `No,' he would not go without John McCarthy,'' Blake said. ``But in the end, he had no option. They just told him, `We want you out.''' Former American hostage Frank Reed, who spent about three years in the same room or house as Keenan and McCarthy, visited Keenan for about 20 minutes on Sunday. Reed was released April 30, eight days after fellow U.S. hostage Robert Polhill was freed. Two Swiss Red Cross workers, Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez, were freed earlier this month. Keenan was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland and was traveling on an Irish passport, but has dual British-Irish citizenship. A little-known group calling itself The Organization of the Islamic Dawn announced his release on Friday. Until the kidnappers' statement, no group had claimed responsibility for Keenan's abduction. Six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian are still believed held by extremist Moslems in Lebanon. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, had been held the longest. He was kidnapped on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: First Western Leader of Buddhist Sect Dead of AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th and 8th grafs to CORRECT spelling of Tendzin, CLARIFY that he was designated successor in 1976.
DOC.TEXT: Vajra Regent Osel Tendzin, who as the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect was stripped of his duties after contracting AIDS, has died of the disease at age 47, church members said. Tendzin, born Thomas Rich, died Saturday at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center, according to church members speaking on condition of anonymity. Hospital spokeswoman Julie Murray could not confirm his death, saying no one was registered under either name. Tendzin in 1976 was designated his spiritual mentor's successor as leader of Vajradhatu, a Dharmadatu Buddhist community based in Boulder, Colo. In 1988, he disclosed he had AIDS. News reports at the time said the charismatic leader also acknowledged putting others at risk through his sexual behavior. The revelation divided the 3,500-member sect. Supporters insisted he remain as leader; critics argued he betrayed followers' trust and must resign. The church's board of directors wrested leadership from Tendzin last year after he refused to step down. He went into more than a year of meditation and seclusion, a traditional Buddhist practice. Tendzin was raised in Passaic, N.J. After dropping out of Fordham University, he met the Venerable Chogyam Trungpa in 1971 and became the Tibetan Buddhist leader's top student. Trungpa gave him the name Osel Tendzin, or ``radiant holder of the teachings.'' Vajradhatu was founded by Trungpa, who had fled the 1950 Chinese invasion of Tibet to settle in Boulder. Trungpa also founded the Naropa Institute, an accredited liberal arts college combining Eastern and Western studies. When Trungpa named Tendzin as his successor, it was the first time a Westerner had achieved such a position in Tibetan Buddhism. Trungpa died in 1987 at the age of 47. Vajradhatu's members include about 800 people in Boulder. It is a diverse group of mostly non-Asians who live ``normal, family lives,'' said Rick Fields, who quit as editor of a Buddhist newspaper after organization leaders refused to let him publish information about Tendzin's illness. Tendzin is survived by his wife, Lila, and their four children, all of Halifax, Nova Scotia. Funeral arrangements not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Regulator Raised Money for Banking Committee Senator
DOC.TEXT: A savings and loan regulator solicited campaign contributions from other thrift watchdogs for a U.S. senator on the Banking Committee. Kermit Mowbray, former president of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Topeka, Kan., raised money for former Sen. David Karnes, R-Neb., the Denver Post reported Sunday. Federal law restricts government employees from raising money for federal campaigns, but Home Loan Bank employees aren't covered by the rule. Mowbray is the target of a Treasury Department investigation into allegations he delayed the seizure of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan to protect then-presidential candidate George Bush from bad publicity. Bush's son, Neil, was a Silverado board member, and loans he approved for a business associate have come under scrutiny by S&L investigators. Mowbray, who was fired without explanation after Silverado failed, defended his fund-raising for Karnes. ``I didn't see anything wrong with that,'' Mowbray said in an interview last week. Karnes ``deserved our support.'' Karnes was chairman of the Topeka branch of the Home Loan Bank before being appointed to the Senate when Democrat Ed Zorinsky died. He ran unsuccessfully for the seat in 1988. Mowbray was in charge of regulating Silverado when he asked colleagues to support Karnes' campaign. He contributed $2,000, and others donated at least $1,000, records show. Edwin Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which governed the Topeka bank, said Mowbray's fund-raising ``shows very poor judgment. It's dead wrong.'' ``If there was any kind of coercion, I would say that it is at the least highly improper and possibly a violation of the law,'' Gray said. Karnes said he spoke with Mowbray by telephone frequently but was unaware of the contributions from thrift regulators. ``Frankly, I was so busy I didn't have time to notice where my campaign funds came from,'' he said. Regarding the alleged delay in closing Silverado, Mowbray testified before the House Banking Committee in June that he received a phone call from Washington directing him to postpone Silverado's closing from October 1988 to December 1988. Bush was elected president in November. He said he didn't remember who called or whether he took the call himself. Mowbray, who earned $190,000 a year as president of the Topeka regulatory bank, gave $2,000 to Karnes' campaign in June 1987. He said he suggested to presidents of the system's 12 regional banks that they also contribute. Federal election records show that in June 1987, Thurman Connell, president of the system's bank in Des Moines, and Brian Dittenhaufer, president of the New York branch, each gave $500 to Karnes' campaign, the newspaper said. Last week, Karnes, whose committee had a role in regulating the industry, denied ever discussing Neil Bush or Silverado with Mowbray. ``I talked to Kermit because he was in Washington about once a month, and he called just to say, `How's it going?''' Karnes said. ``It was against the law (to talk about specific institutions), so even if we wanted to we couldn't discuss it.''

DOC.HEAD: Haze in The South, Fog in The East
DOC.TEXT: The South was under a haze early today and much of the East had fog. Skies were partly cloudy in the rest of the country. High pressure from the southern Rockies to the Appalachians was expected to bring hot, sticky weather to most of the country. Record temperatures were possible in the Plains and Mississippi Valley, with highs in the 100s. Sunny skies and temperatures in the 90s were predicted for most of the East, South and Midwest, but a storm system was forming over Florida. Scattered showers were possible in Louisiana and Texas, and a cold front was expected to bring showers to the Great Lakes region. Rain was expected in Oregon and Northern California, and showers were also possible in Arizona and New Mexico. The coolest weather were expected in the Pacific Northwest, with highs only in the 70s. Elsewhere, temperatures in the 80s were forecast for the Great Lakes and New England, and highs in the 100s were predicted for the Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 106 at Medicine Lodge, Kan., and Salina, Kan. DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Ambassador to Kuwait, Staff Reported Missing
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon said today that its ambassador in Kuwait and his nine-member staff were missing, and it was feared they were taken hostage by Iraq. Salah Staitieh, director general of the Lebanese Foreign Ministry, said Ambassador Adnan Badra closed the embassy in Kuwait City when he was recalled for consultations by the Lebanese government last week. ``He notified us that he was coming with the entire embassy staff via Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Syria. They were due in Beirut two days ago,'' Staitieh told The Associated Press. ``But we have learned through unofficial channels that the ambassador and the embassy personnel are in Baghdad. We do not know why. We have no contact with our embassy in Iraq,'' Staitieh added. Local radio stations said Badra, the head of the embassy's consular section, plus two diplomats and six administrators were seized by Iraqi troops as they set out for the Saudi border on Tuesday. They were taken to Baghdad, where they were being held incommunicado, according to the broadcasts, which cited unnamed Lebanese government sources. The government of President Elias Hrawi is allied with Syria, Iraq's main Arab foe. Both have condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and Baghdad's subsequent order to remove all foreign embassies to Iraq. Iraq last week ordered all embassies in Kuwait to close. About 30 countries have defied the order and remained open with skeleton staff, including the United States and the 12 members of the European Community. On Friday, Iraqi troops began gathering outside some embassies. Water, power and telephones have been periodically cut off, but there have been no reports of diplomats being forcibly removed from their embassies.

DOC.HEAD: Dollars Scrapes New Low; Gold Lower in Zurich
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped to a record low against the West German mark today, and was lower against other key currencies in European trading. Gold was lower in thin trading. The dollar opened at 1.5385 West German marks in Frankfurt this morning, the lowest level since World War II. The previous post-war low was 1.5400 marks on Thursday. At 6 a.m. EDT the dollar was trading at 1.5425 Deutsche Marks, down from 1.5575 marks late Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.80 yen, down 0.90 yen from Friday's close. Later in Europe, it was quoted at 144.70 yen. Traders in Milan, Italy, said market players were liquidating precautionary positions taken in a spurt of dollar buying on Friday. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.2660 Swiss francs, down from 1.2685 _5.1770 French francs, down from 5.2275 _1.7385 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7550 _1,146.00 Italian lire, down from 1,157.50 _1.1330 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1335 The British pound was quoted at $1.9485, compared with $1.9445 late Friday. Currency dealers in Tokyo said trading was mixed today. ``While some investors are trying to sell the dollar because of their pessimistic evaluations of the U.S. economy, other investors are buying it because of the continuing uncertainties over the Gulf situation,'' said Akiko Baba, a customer dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Another dealer at Daiichi Kangyo Bank said the currency lost ground toward the end of the day in response to the news report that Javier Perez de Cuellar, secretary-general of the United Nations, will meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz later this week. The dollar tends to rise when the market is fearful of conflict, and retreat when there is hope for peace. London's gold and silver markets were closed for a bank holiday today. In Zurich, gold was quoted at a bid price of $407.25 per troy ounce, from $410.75 late Friday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of LISBON-dated first item to CORRECT spelling of guerrilla. In Boston-dated last item on Mayes, deletes extraneous word `his' in 3rd graf, CORRECTS in last graf that he did not retire after his years in Philadelphia. A separate on Tendzin moved for PMs as a0448.
DOC.TEXT: Angolan writer and politician Mario Pinto de Andrade, who helped lead a guerrilla war against Portuguese colonial rule, died Sunday in London after a long illness. He was 62. Pinto de Andrade became the first president of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola in 1960, just before the Marxist group launched a 15-year battle. In 1974, he split with the Popular Movement, a year before it came to power with Angola's independence. Recently, he had worked with other veterans of the Popular Movement trying to mediate the long civil war between the Popular Movement government and rebels of the U.S.-backed UNITA, or National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

Vajra Regent Osel Tendzin, the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect, died of AIDS Saturday at age 47. Tendzin, born Thomas Rich, died of respiratory failure at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco, according to members of the Boulder, Colo.-based Dharmadatu Buddhist church called Vajradhatu. Disclosure of his disease, and reports that he had put other members at risk through his sexual practices, divided the 3,500-member sect, and he was stripped of his leadership role last year by the church's board of directors. He met the Venerable Chogyam Trungpa in 1971 and became the Tibetan Buddhist leader's designated successor. Trungpa gave him the name Osel Tendzin, or ``radiant holder of the teachings.'' Trungpa died in 1987.

Stella Mae Roberts, a longtime reporter with The Associated Press and the first woman to be national secretary-treasurer of the Wire Service Guild, died Saturday at age 67 after a long illness. Ms. Roberts joined the news service in Oklahoma City in 1945 and worked there 31 years, much of that time in the Capitol bureau. After retiring in 1976, she became public information director of the Oklahoma Employment Security Commission. Survivors include a niece and two nephews.

Samuel Houston Mayes, a child prodigy who became a principal cellist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, died Friday at his home in Mesa, Ariz., at age 73. He had recently undergone open heart surgery and colon surgery for cancer. Mayes was born in St. Louis. His father was a surgeon, his mother a musician. His first cousin was humorist Will Rogers. Mayes began studying the cello at age 4. When he was 8, he appeared as a soloist with the St. Louis Orchestra. By the time he was 12, Mayes was enrolled in the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia. He played with the Philadelphia Orchestra when he was 17 and performed there for 13 years. Mayes was the principal cellist for the Boston orchestra from 1948 to 1964 and then returned to Philadelphia, playing there until 1973. After a brief stint as principal cellist with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, he became a music professor at the University of Michigan, where he taught from 1975 to 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: National Average Up 5.2 Cents Over Two Weeks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT typo in `according.'
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline rose more than a nickel a gallon at the pump in the past two weeks as motorists continued to feel the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis, according to a national survey. The average price for all grades of gasoline rose 5.2 cents to $1.3316 a gallon, the Lundberg Survey of 13,500 gas stations reported Sunday. The previous survey spanned a three-week period rather than two weeks and found a 10.23-cent increase in the national average. A penny of that increase was due to gasoline tax increases. There were no new taxes in the latest survey, oil analyst Trilby Lundberg said.

DOC.HEAD: US Hopeful Saddam Will Bow to Pressure
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with U.N. Ambassador Pickering describing U.S. policy, Iraqi vulnerability to sanctions; Moynihan saying Saddam could be hanged if hostages harmed; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The administration is expressing hope the Persian Gulf crisis still can be resolved without military conflict, if worldwide economic sanctions force Iraq's Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. ``He's a classic case of someone who is vulnerable to sanctions,'' Thomas Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said of Saddam. ``The strategy is to put maximum pressure on Iraq through the U.N.,'' Pickering said. ``We're watching if the sanctions are going to bite and how rapidly,'' Pickering said on NBC's ``Today'' show. Pickering said Saddam is ``heavily dependent on oil exports,'' and ``it might be a month or two before it begins to bite.'' ``I can see a peaceful way out of it,'' national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said Sunday. ``Saddam Hussein must now see he's facing overwhelming world opinion. ``He is casting about for a way out of the box in which he finds himself,'' Scowcroft said. A final piece of the administration strategy was set in place on Saturday when the United Nations Security Council agreed to authorize the use of military power to enforce the worldwide economic embargo against Iraq. It was the first time in U.N. history that approval had been given for military action to support economic sanctions. The United States had lobbied hard for the U.N. resolution. Pickering said the resolution is ``significant in two ways. First, it gives us the muscle, all of us cooperating to to enforce the U.N. sanctions. Secondly, it is the first time in 45 years, literally, we've gotten this kind of world unity to deal with an agressor.'' In Turkey, 52 Americans connected with the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait were permitted to cross the border from Iraq into Turkey on Sunday, and planned to return to the United States today. Three young males were detained by Iraqi border authorities. An administration official with President Bush in Kennebunkport, Maine, said all three young men were over 18 years old. The official, who declined to be identified by name, said there was no indication that the three were harmed, but that they were sent back to Baghdad with the escort officer. About 2,500 other Americans have been barred from leaving Kuwait and another 500 face a similar fate in Iraq. All told, more than 50 are under arrest in the two countries, according to the State Department. ``If he touches one of those civilians ... if he touches one, he is liable under the Geneva Convention of 1949, which was put into international treaty with Iraq as a party'' Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., said today on ABC's ``Good Morning, America.'' ``That means he hangs, and his commanders hang,'' Moynihan said. The specter of global economic pressure on Iraq, combined with the U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia, prompted several analysts who appeared on network television talk shows Sunday to forecast an eventual reversal by Saddam of his Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait. Former national security advisers Henry Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski indicated there was room for hope that the gulf crisis could be resolved short of military conflict. Kissinger said he believes that ``Saddam Hussein is looking for some way out ... if we stay firm ... we will get it.'' Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan said he was optimistic about Saddam's willingness to negotiate. Both Scowcroft and Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat endorsed the concept of a mediating role by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is seeking urgent talks with Iraqi officials this week. Scowcroft said Saddam has shown himself to be a realist, citing his willingness two weeks ago to bow to Iran's terms for a settlement of their eight-year war. Among other concessions, Saddam agreed to recognize the pre-war boundary of the two countries. Al-Mashat contrasted Iraq's ``desire for peace'' with the American ``design to have war.'' He said the U.S. aggressive intentions were demonstrated by the dispatch of offensive weaponry, including stealth fighter bombers, to Saudi Arabia. He said the U.S. allegation that Iraq posed a threat to Saudi Arabia ``was the biggest deception in history.'' The undersecretary of state for political affairs, Robert Kimmitt, said that sooner or later, Saddam's hand will be forced by the economic sanctions. ``I think they (the sanctions) are becoming increasingly effective. I think the difference between this sanction regime and past sanctions regimes is that it enjoys the virtually unanimous support of the world community and therefore I think the sanctions are beginning to pinch more and more as each day goes by,'' Kimmitt said. ``When he (Saddam) sees that the world community is not breaking rank that it is staying behind the U.N. Security Council-mandated sanctions that he would understand that he has only one way out and that is to withdraw from Kuwait,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 179 Feared Dead in Yugoslav Coal Mine Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 5th pvs, `Bosko Zelic...' to UPDATE number of miners that were trapped. Pick up 6th graf, `If the...'
DOC.TEXT: Rescue crews said today that they had pulled 69 bodies from a coal mine rocked by an explosion that trapped 179 pit workers. Officials said they believed all still below were dead. Rescuers working around the clock since the blast late Sunday reported problems reaching remaining miners. Tons of concrete blocks and other debris blocked the shaft where the explosion occurred. The blast at the Dobrnja-Jug pit of the Kreka mine, 90 miles west of Belgrade, left a crater 45 feet wide and about 15 feet deep. The explosion was thought to have been caused by a buildup of either coal dust or methane gas. Only one man, who was working near the surface, was pulled alive from the mine, said Vidan Krsnanovic, a director of the rescue operation. Bosko Zelic, a member of the mine's managing board, said there were 180 miners in the pit at the time of the explosion, and that no other survivors were likely. Earlier reports indicated 169 were below ground. If the trapped pit workers died, it would be the worst mining disaster in Yugoslav history. There was no immediate indication how far underground the miners were trapped. The blast occurred at a depth of about 1,500 feet. Tangled ruins of the conveyor belt that carried coal from the shaft were scattered around the mine's mouth. Huge pieces of a concrete archway that formed the mine entrance were being pulled away by cranes. The force of the blast ripped out steel supports and ventilation equipment, the Tanjug news agency reported. Kreka mine, one of the oldest in Yugoslavia, was the site of a weeklong strike for higher pay that ended Friday. Mining experts interviewed by Belgrade radio said high concentrations of the highly flammable methane gas might have accumulated in the shafts during the strike. Strikers demonstrated in Sarajevo, capital of Yugoslavia's central region of Bosnia, throughout the past week. They returned to work Saturday after being promised a 100 percent increase in their average $270 monthly salaries. Yugoslavia's worst mining disasters occurred in 1965, when 128 miners died in another colliery in Bosnia. Ninety miners died in a methane gas blast last November at a coal mine about 125 miles south of Belgrade. The explosion was apparently caused by welders working inside one of the shafts. That mine was closed permanently after officials determined it could not be repaired. Officials consider many of Yugoslavia's coal mines unsafe, but only recently have they begun issuing orders to close the most dangerous ones.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers Said Close to Pact on Temporary Production Increase
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers were moving today toward an agreement allowing for a temporary increase in oil production to help fill the gap caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, sources said. Ten of the 11 nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting informally in Vienna have agreed in principle to authorize an increase, said a delegation source, who demanded anonymity. ``They see the need for some kind of OPEC sanction to increase production,'' he said. Only Iran, which contends there is enough excess oil in the industrialized world to meet any shortfall, was opposed, he said. About 4 million barrels of oil a day have been lost to the world market because of the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The sanctions were imposed after Iraq invaded and occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2. Venezuela and Saudi Arabia would like the cartel's backing to boost oil production and help make up part of the loss. Ministers from 11 of the cartel's 13 countries began informal talks on Sunday to decide whether to grant exemptions to their current production agreement. Only Iraq and Libya were not present Sunday for the consultations with OPEC President Sadek Boussena, the Algerian oil minister. Libyan officials were expected to arrive later today, and they might oppose any move to raise production. Under the supply accord worked out last month, the ministers agreed to restrain production at 22.5 million barrels a day in the second half of the year to try to reach a new target price of $21 a barrel. The benchmark was reached almost immediately because of the gulf crisis. Crude oil prices have topped the $30 mark on fears of military escalation and a shortage of supplies in the oil-rich gulf region. The delegation source said any new accord to permit increased crude pumping would likely include promises that production be reduced once the crisis ends. It also would probably call on consuming nations to take steps to use oil in storage to help meet any shortages, he said. He said talks were continuing to work out the details. An accord, he said, could be arranged without holding a formal meeting of the cartel. On Sunday, Venezuelan Oil Minister Celestino Armas appealed to his counterparts to call an emergency meeting to discuss the crisis. The oil market, he said, ``is suffering ... an important disruption, and we have to do something about that.'' Armas said six nations _ one short of the needed majority _ wanted to convene an urgent meeting. They are: Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Ecuador and Kuwait. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela were turned down last week in an attempt to call an emergency meeting. But Armas said the informal talks could result in a formal session this week. ``We do think that these consultations should lead to an extraordinary conference in order to take the decisions and to take the actions that the world is waiting from OPEC at this moment,'' he said. Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, the finance minister of the Kuwaiti government in exile, urged higher output quotas for countries with the capacity to pump more. Sabah was Kuwait's oil minister until July. Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Hisham Nazer, has said the kingdom will raise its output by 2 million barrels a day _ with or without OPEC's blessing. The oil giant has a supply quota of 5.4 million barrels a day. Analysts said the United Arab Emirates, Venezuela, Nigeria and Libya also have the capacity to lift production. Armas said his country will increase pumping to fill its stocks because of the possibility that the oil crunch will continue for some time. Analysts say Venezuela could add as much as 500,000 barrels a day to its OPEC quota of 1.9 million barrels. OPEC nations are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Sinead O'Connor Banned from NJ Venue for Rejecting National Anthem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Outraged officials...', to end with 6 grafs to UPDATE with effort to get comment from spokeswoman; quotes from O'Connor in USA Today. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Irish pop singer Sinead O'Connor threatened to walk out on a concert if ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' was played beforehand. She won the battle but lost the war. The national anthem was not played, but the singer known for her skinhead-style haircut was banned from any future performances at the Garden State Arts Center, officials said. Backstage staff relented following the ultimatum Friday out of fear that a last-minute cancellation would cause a commotion, said Dennis Ingoglia, a spokesman for the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the 9,000-seat venue. O'Connor, whose recordings include ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' and ``Mandinka,'' gave no reason for her demand, Ingoglia said. A telephone message left this morning at the offices of O'Connor's publicist, Elaine Schock, was not immediately returned this morning. But today's editions of USA Today quoted O'Connor as saying: ``I don't see what (anthems) have to do with me or my music or my fans.'' She said she ``didn't mean to be disrespectful'' but wouldn't perform after any national anthem, even Ireland's. She said she had been unaware that the Garden State Arts Center routinely plays the U.S. anthem before shows. She added some criticism of U.S. policy on arts funding: ``I feel very strongly about censorship, and I don't want to go onstage after the anthem of a country that's arresting people and harassing people for expressing themselves onstage.'' George Zilocchi, acting executive director of the highway authority, said in a statement: ``No performer who does not agree to have the national anthem played will be allowed to perform.'' In May, O'Connor refused to perform on ``Saturday Night Live'' because the guest host was controversial comedian Andrew Dice Clay, whose off-color humor, much of it at the expense of women, earlier prompted cast member Nora Dunn to boycott the show.

DOC.HEAD: Five People Killed in Crash of Helicopter At Wisconsin Resort
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter crashed into a hill at a ski resort this morning, killing five people, authorities said. A spokeswoman for the Walworth County Sheriff's Department said the helicopter was reported missing at 5 a.m. and the wreckage was found at about 7 a.m. The crash site was in a ski hill at Alpine Valley, a ski resort and outdoor theater complex about six miles southwest of this southeastern Wisconsin town. Famed guitarists Eric Clapton, Robert Cray and Stevie Ray Vaughn performed Sunday night at the Alpine Valley Music Theatre. A woman answering the telephone at the theater this morning said she has no idea whether any performers could have been on board the helicopter. The Sheriff's Department spokeswoman, who declined to give her name, said the copter was one of four at Alpine Valley that were scheduled to fly during the night to O'Hare International Airport at Chicago. The Sheriff's Department said the identities of the victims were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Study: Teaching is a Revolving Door
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 5, Center director, to describe center.
DOC.TEXT: A predicted teacher shortage probably will not materialize because many veterans who left the profession are returning, a study said today. The National Center for Education Information said more than a third, 38 percent, of current public school teachers have had at least one break from teaching. Nearly half, 46 percent, of new teachers hired since 1985 have had at least one break, and 18 percent of these have had two or more breaks. ``Teaching appears to be a revolving door,'' the study said. ``There is absolutely no question'' that statistics projecting teacher shortages are not accurate, said Emily Feistritzer, director of the center, an independent, non-partisan research group. She said little attention has been paid to the ``returning teacher phenomenon.'' ``All this business of teachers being miserable and leaving is not being borne out in data anywhere,''' she said. The study analyzed the results of a 58-question survey of 3,201 current elementary and secondary school teachers _ 2,380 public school teachers, 469 teachers who had participated in alternative teacher certification programs in Texas and New Jersey and 352 private school teachers. Alternative teacher certification programs are for people who did not earn a college degree in teaching. Twelve percent of those teachers who were hired in the last five years have taught before. The study also showed: _The teaching force in America is getting older, whiter and more female. The average age of all public school teachers is 42 years; of new teachers hired since 1985, the average age is 35 years. Ninety-two percent of all public school teachers are white and 71 percent are women. _To become a teacher, alternative routes attract minorities more than traditional certification routes. Forty-three percent of the teachers from the Texas alternative route and 20 percent from the New Jersey alternate route are minorities. _Alternate route teachers are much more willing to teach in inner cities than those coming through traditional programs. A third, 33 percent, of alternate route teachers say they would be willing to teach in large inner cities, compared with 12 percent of the new hires from traditional programs and 12 percent of all current public school teachers. Since most teachers are women, Feistritzer said childbearing was listed most often as the reason for taking a break from teaching. About three-fourths of all teachers said they chose the profession because of a ``desire to work with young people.'' Ninety-three percent of the private school teachers said they were satisfied with their jobs. That compared with 89 percent of the alternative route teachers in Texas and New Jersey, 87 percent of the returning teachers and 83 percent of all public school teachers. There are 2.3 million public school teachers and another 300,000 private school teachers. Some education-related groups are predicting a shortage, based on teacher attrition, increasing student enrollments and fewer college graduates seeking teaching jobs. Thanks to Teachers, an organization sponsored by the National Education Association and private business groups, reports that many school districts already are reporting shortages. The group says far too few college students are enrolled in teacher training programs to fill the expected 1.3 million teaching job openings expected by 1994. Other studies have estimated that about 200,000 new teachers would be needed a year. However, Feistritzer said about 650,000 teachers have been hired in the last five years, averaging out to 130,000 a year. About 71,000 of those hired each year are new teachers. In the study, 74 percent of all teachers said they expect to be teaching five years from now. Eight percent plan to retire, 7 percent expect to switch to an occupation outside of education, 10 percent expect to be in another occupation in education, 1 percent plan to be homemaking or raising children full time and 1 percent expect to be attending a college or university full time.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes Rose 3.3 Percent in July
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in July, their second straight increase, as mortgage rates dropped into the single digits, a real estate trade group reported today. The National Association of Realtors said house resales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units compared to June's rate of 3.33 million. The 0.9 percent gain in sales in June was the first advance in seven months. Fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages fell from 10.06 percent to 9.8 percent during July, according to surveys conducted by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. However, they turned upward after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and reached 10.29 percent by last Friday. ``Home buyers watched rates keep drifting down and started making their move,'' Realtors' President Norman D. Flynn said. ``The rate drops brought in some borderline buyers who were priced out of the market earlier this year, as well as buyers who could have bought sooner, but chose to wait out the rate increases.'' But Flynn said the recent rate increases probably will push down sales this month. ``Iraq's craziness will be felt in U.S. housing markets,'' he said. The national median existing-home price was $98,400 in July, up 0.9 percent from June. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. Sales increases were posted both in the Northeast and South. In the Northeast, the pace jumped 14.3 percent to 560,000 units, while it gained 6.9 percent in the South to 1.40 million units. ``July's build-up in resales (in the Northeast) was the result of greater activity in the lower price ranges,'' according to John A. Tuccillo, the Realtors' chief economist. ``Sellers have adjusted their prices to fit a buyer's market and buyers have responded.'' The median price in the Northeast was $143,300 in July, 3.4 percent below the June level. The resale increase in the South reflected rising activity in the Southwest, Tuccillo said, where several formerly depressed oil-dominated markets are springing back. The median price in the South was $88,900, up 1.6 percent from June. Sales fell 10.3 percent, to 520,000 units, in the West. The median price there was $141,500, up 2.5 percent from the previous month. Sales fell 3.1 percent in the Midwest, to 930,000 units. The median price there was $76,300, up 0.5 percent from June.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Strike to Protest Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with scene at mass funeral, comments from Desmond Tutu, 10 deaths reported over weekend in Natal province.
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of blacks in the Soweto township stayed away from work today to protest factional fighting that has claimed more than 500 lives over the past two weeks. Buses, taxis and trains in Soweto were carrying roughly a third as many passengers as usual into neighboring Johannesburg. Many schools were closed and the main streets in the township of 2.5 million people were mostly empty. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, addressing a funeral for seven people killed in the violence, told a roaring crowd that police actions, not tribal divisions, were fueling the conflict. ``We have never quarreled because of tribalism,'' Tutu told some 5,000 African National Congress supporters at a Soweto amphitheater. ``The evidence is overwhelming that the police have not been impartial.'' Most of the fighting in Soweto and other townships around Johannesburg has pitted Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks who support the ANC, the country's largest black political organization. ANC leader Nelson Mandela and other anti-apartheid figures have accused police of siding with Inkatha, a charge police deny. The government and many neutral observers portray the conflict as mostly tribal fighting linked to the power struggle between the ANC and Inkatha. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi has blamed the ANC for instigating the fighting, which has resulted in some of the worst violence since nationwide unrest during the mid-1980s. Buthelezi says the ANC wants to crush all opposition. ``Our freedom is at hand,'' Tutu said to tumultuous cheers. ``And there are those (whites) who say they don't want us to have our freedom ... so they have made us fight one another.'' Heavily armed soldiers and police ringed the amphitheater. No arrests or violence were reported. The general strike was called by the anti-apartheid Soweto Civic Association to ``protest the violence, police behavior and to mourn our dead.'' Residents in neighboring townships also took part. A group of Xhosa and Zulu tribal chiefs sympathetic to the ANC toured the townships Sunday and said the violence was ``not a Zulu-Xhosa conflict, but has its roots in the system of apartheid.'' ``The problem is the collaboration between the police and Inkatha,'' said Mwelo Nonkonyana, a Xhosa chief. The delegation, which included seven Xhosa and six Zulu chiefs, said it did not represent any political party. But the chiefs all belong to the Congress of Traditional Leaders of South Africa, a group with close ties to the ANC. The Zulus and the Xhosas are the two largest tribes in South Africa, but townships in the Johannesburg area have blacks from all 10 major tribes in the country. Townships around Johannesburg have been relatively peaceful in recent days for the first time since the violence erupted Aug. 12. A total of 515 blacks have died, including more than 100 in Soweto, police said. Army troops and police continued to patrol the streets and confiscate guns, spears, axes and other weapons. The government has declared townships ringing Johannesburg ``unrest areas,'' giving police wide powers to curb violence. The government lifted a state of emergency in three provinces in June, but retained the measures in the eastern province of Natal, where fighting between Inkatha and ANC forces has claimed about 5,000 lives in the past five years. In Natal, seven blacks were hacked and stabbed to death and three were fatally shot over the weekend in separate attacks, police said. Under South Africa's apartheid system of racial segregation, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy, and the black majority has no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Gustav Growing, Heading Toward Caribbean
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav's winds hit 105 mph early today as the storm headed for the Caribbean, and warnings were posted in the West Indies. At 9 a.m. EDT, Gustav, which reached hurricane strength on Sunday, was about 205 miles east of Guadeloupe. It was moving northwest at nearly 9 mph and was expected to maintain that course and speed for the next 24 hours, foecasters said. Gustav was on a path that would skirt the Leeward Islands, and hurricane forecasters said the island residents were likely to feel its effects. ``It would be close enough that they need to watch it. They would be on the fringes,'' said Mark Zimmer, a specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``Conditions are favorable for further strengthening.'' The islands of Guadeloupe, Antigua, Barbuda, Montserrat, Nevis and St. Kitts issued hurricane warnings late Sunday. A hurricane watch was in effect for St. Martin, Anguilla and surrounding islands but dropped today for Dominica and Martinique. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Hortense trailed Gustav about a thousand miles to the east in the mid-Atlantic, an immediate danger only to shipping. Hortense, the eighth named storm of the Atlantic season, had winds of 45 mph at 6 a.m. today and was not expected to gain strength today. It was moving north at about 5 mph. Gustav and Hortense were born as tropical depressions near the Cape Verde islands off West Africa. Such storms have been among history's worst. Tropical depressions become tropical storms when their sustained winds reach 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes at 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Desecrate Gravestones In Roman Catholic Cemeteries
DOC.TEXT: Vandals desecrated 172 gravestones in separate incidents at two Roman Catholic cemeteries, police said today. No arrests have been made. Youths knocked over and smashed 115 tombstones and ornaments at the Sint Martinus Cemetery in Eindhoven Saturday night, said police spokesman Herman van Zanten. Late Friday night, 57 monuments were damaged at a Roman Catholic graveyard in Oudenbosch, 43 miles from Eindhoven, said Fred Rietveld, another police spokesman. Cemetery vandalism has increased in the south of the Netherlands, which is predominantly Roman Catholic, since the mutilation of corpses at a Jewish cemetery in France and other graveyard attacks in Europe this year, Rietveld said. But he said police do not know the motive. Last week, an art student and a friend were arrested after they dug up a skull at another cemetery in Eindhoven, said Van Zanten. They said they wanted to use it as a drawing model.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Search for Bodies of 35 Missing from Capsized Boat
DOC.TEXT: Divers searched today for the bodies of 35 people presumed drowned when an overcrowded pleasure boat on a moon-gazing cruise capsized, killing 57 people. Most of the 34 people who survived the accident on picturesque Sun Moon Lake in Nantou, about 160 miles southwest of Taipei, were rescued by another boat. One woman swam the 1,650 feet to shore Saturday night, said Jonathan D. Crossman, the British president of Shell Taiwan Ltd., who was on board when the accident occurred. He said earlier police reports that the accident occurred 165 feet from shore were wrong. The pleasure boat was chartered by the Taiwan Shell subsidiary for its employees. The weekend excursion occurred on the eve of the Chinese Valentine Day Festival, during which moon-gazing is traditional. Crossman said 57 people, including 18 children, drowned. Shell officials said all 91 people on board the boat, except for two travel agents and the helmsman, were Shell employees and their families. The company earlier said 88 people were on board. Police arrested helmsman Hsu Ching-hsing for alleged unintentional manslaughter after he was rescued. Hsu, who also owned the boat, attributed the accident to strong winds. But police said the boat carried more than its 60-person capacity. The cruiser was also in breach of a 6 p.m. deadline banning boats from using the lake, officials said. Crossman said from his hotel room in Nantou today that about 20 people drowned after they were crushed under the overturned boat. Others drowned apparently because they could not swim. Crossman, 44, said he was tossed overboard from an upper deck. He grabbed his 7-year-old daughter, Nicola, in his arms and both were rescued. His wife, Julia, 40, and a son, Robert, 6, drowned.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Clapton Entourage Among 5 Killed in Copter Crash; Clapton OK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quote from Clapton manager, move up that status of Cray, Vaughan not yet confirmed, changes `band' to `entourage' in lead to reflect that identities of victims not released; CORRECTS name of early Clapton band to Yardbirds sted Yardbards. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter crashed into a hill near a resort concert hall this morning, killing five people including members of rock star Eric Clapton's entourage, authorities said. Clapton was not aboard the helicopter, said Al Zimmerman, chief dispatcher of the Walworth County Sheriff's Department. But officials could not immediately say whether two other famed guitarists on the bill with Clapton, Stevie Ray Vaughan and Robert Cray, were aboard. Identities of the victims won't be released until relatives are notified, authorities said. The crash site was in a ski hill at Alpine Valley, a ski resort and outdoor theater complex about six miles southwest of this southeastern Wisconsin town. Clapton, along with Cray and Vaughan, had played at the theater Sunday evening. The helicopter, owned by Omni Flight Helicopters Inc., crashed into a field about 12:35 a.m. shortly after leaving the Alpine Valley music theater, said Omni spokesman Phil Huth. ``The helicopter was transporting a pilot and members of Eric Clapton's band,'' Huth said in releasing a prepared statement. Clapton was staying this morning at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago, and was not available for immediate comment, said his tour manager, Peter Jackson. Jackson, who sounded distraught and strained when reached by phone in his room at the hotel, said Clapton learned of the accident when ``one of our planes never arrived at the airport.'' He declined to identify the victims. A spokeswoman for sheriff's department said the helicopter was reported missing at 5 a.m. and the wreckage was found at about 7 a.m. The spokeswoman, Pat Salimas, said the copter was one of four at Alpine Valley that were scheduled to fly during the night to Midway Airport at Chicago. The helicopter crashed into the the back of a ski hill and an electronic signal was activated, notifying the Civil Air Patrol of the crash, she said. Huth confirmed the helicopter was headed to Chicago. Huth said the cause of the crash was not immediately known. Vaughan, with his band Double Trouble, had a platinum album for ``Couldn't Stand the Weather,'' released in 1984. He's known for songs like ``Pride and Joy'' and won a 1984 Grammy Award for best traditional blues recording in 1984. This year, he won a Grammy in the contemporary blues category for ``In Step.'' Cray won a Grammy in 1988 in the contemporary blues category for the hit album ``Strong Persuader.'' The following year, he won in the same category for the single ``Don't Be Afraid of the Dark.'' Clapton, 45, rose to international fame in the '60s for his pounding blues guitar style, first with the British blues groups the Yardbirds and John Mayall's Bluesbreakers. Teaming with Jack Bruce and Ginger Baker, he formed the group Cream in the late 60s, best known for its album ``Wheels of Fire'' and the single ``Sunshine of Your Love.'' Later, he was with the group Blind Faith and Derek and the Dominos before pursuing a solo career. Among his other well-known songs as ``Layla,'' ``Lay Down, Sally,'' ``I Shot the Sheriff'' and ``Tulsa Time.'' He was born in Surrey, England, on March 30, 1945. He was married to Patti Boyd, who previously was married to Beatle George Harrison.

DOC.HEAD: New Study: Alternate Routes Attract Minorities, Inner-City Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Teachers who enter the profession without a college degree in teaching are more likely to be minorities and to want to work in inner-city schools, according to a study released Monday. A third of the teachers who took an alternate route to the classroom say they'd be willing to work in large inner cities, compared to 12 percent of all current public school teachers and 12 percent of new hires from traditional programs, according to the study by the National Center for Education Information. The independent, non-partisan reserach group looked at alternative certification plans in two states as part of a larger teacher study. It found that 43 percent of the non-traditional teachers in Texas and 20 percent of those in New Jersey were minorities. The overall teaching force is becoming older, whiter and more female, the study found. The average age of all public school teachers is 42 years; of new teachers hired since 1985, the average age is 35 years. Ninety-two percent of all public school teachers are white and 71 percent are women.
