The study of 3,201 elementary and secondary school teachers currently on the job also concluded that a predicted teaching shortage probably will not occur because many teachers who leave the profession tend to return. Of the teachers in the study, 38 percent have had at least one break from teaching; 46 percent of those hired since 1985 have had one break and 18 percent of these have had two or more breaks. ``Teaching appears to be a revolving door,'' the study said. Center director Emily Feistritzer said childbearing was listed most often as the reason for taking a break from teaching. She said more attention should be paid to the ``returning teacher phenomenon.'' ``All this business of teachers being miserable and leaving is not being borne out in data anywhere,''' she said. There are 2.3 million public school teachers and another 300,000 private school teachers in the United States. Some education-related groups are predicting a shortage due to teacher attrition, increasing student enrollments and fewer college graduates seeking teaching jobs. Thanks to Teachers, an organization sponsored by the National Education Association and private business groups, reports that many school districts already are reporting shortages. The group says far too few college students are enrolled in teacher-training programs to fill the expected 1.3 million teaching job openings expected by 1994. Other studies have estimated that about 200,000 new teachers would be needed a year. However, Feistritzer said about 650,000 teachers have been hired in the last five years, averaging out to 130,000 a year. About 71,000 of those hired each year are new teachers. Three-quarters of the teachers in her study said they expect to be teaching five years from now. Ten percent predicted they'd be in an education-related occupation, 7 percent plan to switch fields and 8 percent expect to retire. The Feistritzer study is based on the results of a 58-question survey of 2,380 public school teachers, 352 private school teachers and 469 people who had participated in the Texas and New Jersey alternate-route programs.

DOC.HEAD: College Bash Goes Out of Control
DOC.TEXT: Drunken students hurled beer and bottles at police and an ambulance rescuing an injured teen-ager at a fraternity party, authorities said. ``It's superirresponsible on the part of the individuals to do that when they were trying to get to someone who's hurt,'' said police Sgt. Jack Phillips. Police made about five arrests among a crowd estimated at 7,500 attending Saturday night's bash, an annual event in the fraternity and sorority section near the University of Missouri's campus. Mitchell Stegmaier, 17, of Columbia was in serious condition at a Columbia hospital. He took a dare from people who said a $100 bill was on top of the utility pole and was nearly electrocuted when he got tangled in the high-voltage wires, witnesses said. A transformer exploded, jarring Stegmaier from the pole. But he became entangled in a lower set of wires before dropping to the ground, said Phillips. A police patrol car and ambulance tried to get through the crowd, but partygoers started throwing rocks and bottles, Phillips said. The rear window and windshield of the patrol car were smashed, Phillips said. The ambulance windshield also was smashed and a firefighter was hit by a beer can, Phillips said. University Chancellor Haskell Monroe said, ``It is a horrible tragedy. We want to eliminate the likelihood that this will ever happen again.'' Meetings were planned for this week between fraternity leaders and administrators.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Impose Extensive Energy Conservation Program
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Elevators will skip floors and neon signs will be dark under an extensive conservation program being implemented next month as a result of the Persian Gulf situation, officials said Monday. The program seeks to cut South Korea's energy consumption by 10 percent. The country relies on foreign imports for all its oil. Tourist hotels, hospitals, railroad stations and other public facilities will be exempt from the restrictions, according to government officials. Under the program, elevators will stop at every other floor and factories and offices will be banned from using incandescent lamps. The use of neon-lit outdoor signs will be restricted between midnight and sunset the following day, and movie theaters will be barred from operating after midnight.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Meets With Pope
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II discussed Polish politics Monday in a long meeting with Lech Walesa, a leader of the Solidarity labor movement. It was the fifth encounter between the two Poles since John Paul became pope in 1978. Walesa ``presented a panorama of the present situation in Poland, 10 years after the birth of Solidarity,'' said papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro. ``It is a situation of a free and pluralistic society that appears full of hope for the future,'' Navarro said to sum up Walesa's view as expressed to the pope. Walesa attended a Mass celebrated by John Paul in the papal summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, a tpwm outside Rome. The two, along with Tadeusz Goclowski, the bishop of Walesa's hometown of Gdansk, then had breakfast together. Walesa and the pope then talked privately for more than an hour, Navarro said. The Polish labor leader said the men discussed politics in a general discussion ``about the role of Christianity and other themes.'' In a homily Sunday, the pope called on Poles to fight ``moral permissiveness'' and to encourage the teaching of religion in schools. Walesa was in Italy for a convention held by a conservative religious organization.

DOC.HEAD: Former East German Economics Czar Released from Custody
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's former Communist economics czar, who is accused of corruption, has been released from prison because of failing health, officials said Monday. Doctors agreed that Guenter Mittag, 63, was too ill to remain in jail where he was being held in preventive custody, said East German justice officials who asked not to be identified. Mittag was responsible for economic policy in the Communist government that was ousted during last fall's pro-democracy movement. He had been in prison since December and is accused of corruption and sabotaging the country's economy. Other top officials under investigation by the new democratically elected government include former Communist leader Erich Honecker and longtime security chief Erich Mielke. Mittag suffers from acute diabetes, said East German justice officials. He is considered to be the most ill of all the former Communist party leaders under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Critic Rearrested
DOC.TEXT: A well-known critic of the government who was free on bail on a sedition charge was rearrested Monday on another charge for which he already has served a prison sentence. Gitobu Imanyara, a lawyer who edits a monthly magazine, was charged with misappropriating a client's funds, said his attorney, John Khaminwa. Imanyara was convicted of essentially the same charge in 1984 and served two years of a five-year sentence. The case stemmed from a complaint by a client to the Law Society. The Society dismissed the complaint as groundless. The 37-year-old lawyer has angered the government by defending 120 members of the air force who were charged with treason in connection with a failed 1982 coup. More recently, Imanyara has irked officials through his magazine, The Nairobi Law Monthly, which is frequently critical of the government. He was detained in a crackdown in July and held in jail for 20 days without charge. Immediately upon his release, he was arrested and charged with sedition in connection with the July issue of the magazine, which was devoted to multiparty politics, law and democracy. He was freed on bail on that charge on July 31.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis, in Rare Move, Open Doors to Foreign Media
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia, a strictly controlled society, has opened the floodgates to more than 250 reporters, turning coverage of the U.S. troop deployment into what one journalist called Monday ``a media war.'' The decision to let American and foreign journalists roam the oil-rich kingdom is unprecedented. ``It's phenomenal,'' said Ray Wilkinson, Newsweek's Cairo-based correspondent. Wilkinson had a visa request pending for 18 months before he was granted one. ``I never thought I would see the U.S. military in Saudi Arabia, and I never thought I would see us here like this.'' Saudi officials, speaking on condition they not be identified, said the change in government policy came from the highest levels and was partly in reaction to pressure from the United States. ``They know public opinion is important,'' one official said of the Saudi leadership. ``Pressure from the White House'' also played a role, he said. Most reporters have been given monthlong visas. After a month, the situation is fluid, although one Saudi official said it's possible major news organizations will be given a permanent presence in the kingdom. The arrival of hundreds of journalists prompted the U.S. Defense Department to disband its 17-member media pool Sunday, two weeks after the first journalists arrived in the country. Under the pool arrangement, writers, photographers and television journalists made their work available to all news organizations. Some pool reporters complained about restrictions imposed by the Pentagon but praised the access they were given to on-the-ground operations. Most irksome was the Pentagon's initial prohibition on the use of soldiers' names and hometowns. On Saturday, the Pentagon lifted the ban, saying the military situation had relaxed. The Pentagon and the Saudi government still bar reporters from using exact locations when writing about military activities. Navy Lt. Cmdr. Gregg Hartung, the pool coordinator, said he thought the pool worked better than in the past. During the December invasion of Panama, for example, reporters were furious at being penned up away from any action for 24 hours. ``I think we still have room for improvement,'' Hartung said. For instance, he would have liked daily briefings with ``Operation Desert Shield'' commanders to give the pool up-to-date details of the deployment. But that was impossible because the operation was run out of Riyadh, the Saudi capital, while the reporters were based 200 miles away in Dhahran, scene of the major deployment. The invasion of reporters has created a new set of headaches for American and Saudi officials. So many people are vying for limited space on official tours, such as the visit to see three Republican senators, that the Pentagon has given first priority to American reporters. The Saudis have also been besieged by reporters trying to get on sponsored trips. A near riot broke out among reporters pushing to get on buses when the Saudis took a group to the border with Iraq. ``It's a media war. That's the main feature,'' said Alix Van Buren of La Repubblica of Italy. ``Bring in a couple thousand copies of `Scoop,''' said Time Magazine's Jay Peterzell, referring to Evelyn Waugh's satirical novel about covering an African war. ``A lot of people want to reread it.''

DOC.HEAD: Gingrich Breaks With Bush, Returns To Anti-Tax Roots
DOC.TEXT: After flirting with a tax increase and drawing political fire back home in Georgia, House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich is breaking with the Bush administration and returning to his anti-tax political roots. Gingrich, one of the GOP's most fervent anti-tax crusaders during the 1980s, says he will propose billions of dollars in tax cuts when White House and congressional budget negotiations resume next month. ``I think this kind of a tax package represents the best lessons of the 1980s in how to get economic growth and it avoids the greatest dangers of the 1970s, which were to raise taxes going straight into a recession,'' he said last week. Gingrich's announcement comes just a month after he told budget negotiators he would co-sponsor and help line up GOP votes for a $50 billion defiit reduction plan that included up to $25 billion in new taxes. That was the target budget negotiators agreed to shoot for after President Bush in June abandoned his no-tax-increase pledge and announced that new tax revenues were needed to reduce the deficit, which is projected to reach $170 billion in fiscal 1991. Gingrich initially was outraged by Bush's reversal, calling it a mistake that will result in ``a severe blow to the president's credibility and a significant blow to the Republican Party.'' But he later bowed to administration pressure, donned his House leadership hat and agreed to help Bush strike a deficit reduction deal with congressional Democrats. He said at the time he could support a budget agreement with up to $25 billion in new tax revenues if it doesn't raise income tax rates and includes spending cuts, budget reforms, adequate defense spending and a capital gains tax cut. Gingrich's willingness to support new taxes, however, quickly became a major issue in his re-election campaign in Georgia's 6th District. Democrat David Worley, making his second try to unseat Gingrich, has blasted him repeatedly for backing higher taxes in Washington while pledging in fund-raising appeals to fight new taxes. He says Gingrich is proposing tax cuts now ``because he knows he's in trouble at home on the tax issue.'' But Gingrich said his new tax stance is simply a recognition that the ``equation has changed'' in the past month because of the Persian Gulf crisis and increasing evidence that the economy is headed into a recession. ``I'd find it very hard to understand an argument for a tax increase in the face of a weak economy,'' he said. Gingrich concedes that the administration isn't excited about his tax cut proposal. Neither is his fellow GOP budget negotiator, Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the senior Republican on the House Budget Committee. ``I think it is interesting theology and I love tax cuts, but I am not sure tax cuts are indicated at this stage of the game,'' Frenzel said in a telephone interview. Frenzel said a move toward tax cuts now likely would be interpreted by the credit markets here and abroad as an abandonment of efforts to reduce the deficit. And if that happened, he said, interest rates would rise because ``we will be considered an unwise risk for creditors and we will find that we have an interest-rate induced recession.'' Frenzel agreed with Gingrich that worsening economic conditions, coupled with the military crisis precipitated by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, have changed the dynamics of the budget negotiations. ``Almost everybody who did not want a successful budget agreement has a lot better reason to keep us from getting one,'' he said. ``But to me, they're all less significant than the reason that we started with, and that is that we have a fiscal policy that is out of control.''

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Burn Party Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with police instructed to use force, Socialist Party rally, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's police were instructed today to use force if necessary to prevent further violence a day after anti-Communist demonstrators torched and ransacked the governing Socialist Party headquarters. Hundreds of police stood guard around the partially gutted building, blocking off access to the nearby government offices and the presidential palace. The Socialist Party held a rally in downtown Sofia near party headquarters this evening, apparently designed to show its strength despite the attack. Thousands attended, a state radio reporter said. The party headquarters was set ablaze late Sunday by a small group of demonstrators who broke away from a larger anti-Communist protest, throwing torches into its windows. They were incensed by the red star _ the symbol of Communist, one-party rule _ on top of the building. The Socialist Party is the heir to the Communist Party, which changed its name earlier this year in a bid to retain power. Reformers in the party ousted hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov in November, and won a majority in June nationwide elections under the Socialist banner. The main opposition group condemned the assault today and said it could endanger the transition to democracy. ``Do not let yourselves be provoked, keep the public peace, calm down the impatient,'' the Union of Democratic Forces said in a statement carried by the official BTA news agency. ``Let us show in these dramatic hours that we are sensible and civilized people.'' Several firemen and bystanders near the burning building were injured by falling debris, a doctor on the scene reported. One demonstrator said police clubbed protesters inside the building, but there was no word of casualties. The general prosecutor's office said today that more than 50 people had been arrested. The targeted building, dating to the 1950s, is Sofia's largest and had been the Communists' headquarters. In the protest, demonstrators shouted ``Down with the Communists,'' while others threw burning torches through windows of the building, witnesses said. Inside, in areas of the headquarters untouched by flames, protesters destroyed furniture, and hurled papers and other items onto the street. State radio said looters later came to carry off television sets and computers from the building. Firefighters said demonstrators blocked their way and cut most of their hoses. The fire was eventually extinguished early today, more than five hours after it began. President Zhelyu Zhelev cut short a holiday in the Black Sea resort of Varna and went on national radio to appeal for calm. The country is in danger of ``drifting ... into a military dictatorship,'' Zhelev said in an appeal for law and order. As firefighters fought to control the blaze Sunday night, the commander of the national police announced that the main roads into Sofia had been closed to all but those on official business. Today, vehicles were allowed to pass after their occupants produced identification. Bulgarian media carried a statement issued by the unidentified commander announcing that police across the nation had been placed on alert ``so that no similar incidents happen in other regions.'' The crowd outside the building swelled to as many as 10,000 people at one point. About 800 police officers armed with clubs watched but made no move to disperse the crowd. Vice President Atanas Semerdzhiev, a Socialist, ordered police not to use force against the protesters. Before it was brought under control, the fire spread to two neighboring buildings belonging to the Socialist Party. Firemen said several apartments in nearby residential buildings also caught fire. Last week, the Parliament voted to remove red stars and other Communist symbols from buildings after an activist threatened to set himself on fire. The activist, 20-year-old Plamen Stanchev, said he would burn himself by 9 p.m. Sunday unless all Communist symbols had disappeared. When the deadline passed without removal of the red star from the party headquarters, he poured what witnesses said was a flammable liquid over himself but was prevented from striking a match. A small group of demonstrators set fire to the building less than 30 minutes later, the witnesses said. The Socialists were the only former Communist Party in Eastern Europe to win elections after the democratic upheaval that swept the region last year. But the Socialists have seen their popularity steadily erode since the elections as the country's economy deteriorates.

DOC.HEAD: Three Women Found Slain In Two Gainesville, Fla., Apartments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to update with parents calling, one victim 18 and college student, picking up at 6th graf pvs, ``The bodies...'.
DOC.TEXT: A young college student was found slain in her apartment early today, hours after police found two other young women dead in another apartment near the University of Florida, authorities said. Investigators did not immediately link the three slayings. The apartments are less than two miles apart on the south side of Gainesville. ``We're exploring that possibility, but right now we just don't know,'' said police Lt. Sadie Darnell. The three slayings on the eve of the fall term prompted parents to flood the university community with worried calls. ``We're receiving calls from all over, particularly from out-of-state parents,'' said Darnell. UF spokeswoman Linda Gray said the school also was getting many calls. Deputies went to the lone woman's apartment in nearby Alachua County after she failed to report to work at midnight, said sheriff's spokesman Spencer Mann. He said she was 18 and a student at nearby Santa Fe Community College. Mann said there was trauma to the body, but he would not say how she died. University officials did not immediately confirm a published report that the other two victims were incoming UF freshmen. The bodies of the other two women were found Sunday when the parents of one had police and a maintenance man open the apartment door. The parents had been unable to contact their daughter all weekend. The two women were nude and suffered violent deaths sometime during the weekend, according to Ms. Darnell. She said police had no suspects in the case. She said the bodies suffered multiple traumas, but there were no obvious signs of gunshot wounds although police weren't ruling out the possibility. The victims' identities were not released. Both victims found Sunday were incoming University of Florida freshmen, the Gainesville Sun newspaper reported today. Classes began at the university today.

DOC.HEAD: As Refugees Flee, Palestinians Head Back to Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Against a desperate tide of refugees fleeing Kuwait, a widening stream of Jordanian Palestinians are heading the other way, seeking fortunes in what they see as a promising province of Iraq. ``A little more stability comes each day in Kuwait, and Palestinians are taking advantage,'' said Khanchand Ahuja, an electrical engineer who left behind six years of Kuwaiti life to take his family home to India. Heavily laden sedans join the trucks carrying grain and steel through this besieged outpost to Iraq. ``About 2,000 people crossed into Iraq on Sunday,'' reported a senior security official at the border station. ``This is picking up fast.'' Refugees agreed that because of tumultuous conditions, Iraqi-occupied Kuwait is ripe for adventuresome job-seekers, entrepreneurs and criminals. They said hoodlums from among the large Palestinian population joined Iraqi troops in the first wave of looting and are now stealing property at gunpoint, despite Iraqi attempts to restore order. Other Palestinians are buying up refugees' electronic goods, furniture and clothing to resell in Baghdad for big profits. Hatem Elagha, a young Palestinian leaving his native Kuwait to study in Georgia, said many Jordanian Palestinians who were on vacation or who fled after the invasion are returning. ``Things are stabilizing some, and they want to protect their jobs and family holdings,'' he said. ``The politics don't matter to them.'' An estimated 350,000 Jordanians, mostly Palestinians, were settled in Kuwait at the time Iraq invaded and annexed it. Officials said 12,000 of them left, but many are going back. Among many Jordanians, political sympathies clearly lie with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's declared championship of the Arab cause. The 150-mile two-lane blacktop road between the Jordanian capital, Amman, and Ruweishid is not only the escape route from Iraq and Kuwait but also a lifeline that Jordanian road crews are hard at work improving. On a drive to the border, reporters saw a dozen trucks loaded to capacity with heavy steel I-beams and angle iron, useful for building artillery platforms, bunkers and bridges for tanks. There also were open trucks piled high with wheat. At an off-limits section of the border crossing, reporters saw several heavy covered commercial trucks roll into Iraq in the predawn darkness. Officials neither confirm nor deny that goods are crossing into Iraq in spite of U.N. sanctions. On a few buses, the drivers could hardly see around huge portraits of Saddam taped to the windshield. ``This problem came on an American wind, and we are all with Saddam,'' said Dr. Ahmed Dagens, a Jordanian helping treat refugees in a makeshift Red Crescent first aid center. His three colleagues nodded in agreement. Refugees agreed that essential items were rapidly disappearing from the market in Iraq and Kuwait. ``Kuwait is in a terrible state, terrible,'' said an Indian petrochemical engineer who spoke freely when assured he would not be named. ``I don't see how it can hold out.'' He said Kuwait relied on two water treatment plants and two power stations. ``Soon the filters and parts will go, or the water works could be hit by a bomb,'' he said. ``The electrical plants could stop. Without water and refrigeration, a million people could die.'' Ahuja confirmed that Kuwait's essential services were crippled, but he said Iraq was making major efforts to bring stability. Looters were hanged in the market, discouraging further raids, he said. Bread shops and banks were opening one at a time. Iraqi officers took over abandoned police stations. People described mass destruction when Iraqi forces rolled into Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``They smashed everything, and carried away everything they could,'' the Indian engineer said. He said he watched thirsty troops looking for cold drinks break open what they thought was a refrigerator. It was a computer worth a half-million dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Have a Cow, Man. Wear One
DOC.TEXT: Forget leopard. Think Holstein. Finally, there's sportswear for the cow conscious. The Milk Advisory Board is introducing leotards, shorts and other clothing adorned with the likeness of the Holstein milk cow's black-and-white splotches. Holsteins _ and all things cowlike _ are hot, retailers say. ``People love cows,'' said Connie Begg of J.J.'s Mae Inc., the San Francisco manufacturer that's producing the garments. The advisory board based in South San Francisco views the promotion strictly as a way of pushing milk, not clothes. Each item carries a tag telling the bovine buyer: ``This garment is patterned after the unique markings of the Holstein dairy cow _ to remind you that milk does a body good.'' Cow-print leotards and shorts showed up earlier this year on billboards advertising extra light milk. The ads prompted inquiries from people wanting cow-print clothing, said Adri Boudewyn of the Milk Advisory Board. The clothing items include $12.50 T-shirts with the advisory board's logo and $19 black-and-white leotards. ``People can have a cow,'' he said. ``Or they can have the whole herd.''

DOC.HEAD: Eight Senators Pay Visit to U.S. Troops
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eight U.S. senators paid a visit today to American troops in Saudi Arabia and said support for their deployment remains strong back home. ``You're not here alone, this is an international effort,'' Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn told a handful of Marines. ``This is the world against Saddam Hussein.'' Later, Nunn told reporters that a briefing the senators received from American and Saudi military commanders had convinced him a sufficient force was in place to deter an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia. ``An Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia would be national suicide,'' said Nunn, D-Ga. Senate Republican leader Bob Dole, asked if he came away from the briefings convinced a sufficient military force was in place to defeat Iraqi troops to the north, said: ``I think so. If not, it's getting real close.'' From Saudi Arabia, the senators were headed to Alexandria, Egypt, for meetings with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Nunn said the senators would discuss the need for a bigger, multinational force in Saudi Arabia with Arabs on the front lines but did not answer directly when asked whether he thought Egypt should send more troops. Of an bigger Arab role on the front line, Nunn said: ``I think that's important militarily but also, more importantly, politically and psychologically.'' Several of the senators, when asked by reporters, acknowledged that the presence of American hostages in Iraq complicated efforts to resolve the nearly month-old Middle East standoff. But they said the hostage situation alone could not be the force behind U.S. policy. ``You can't run foreign policy on hostages,'' said Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah. ``If you did, no American would be safe anywhere in the world.'' The senators visited troops at an airbase in northeast Saudi Arabia, shaking hands and asking about the desert conditions while being trailed by a horde of U.S. and foreign media. ``What's your biggest problem over here?'' Nunn asked several members of a Marine light helicopter division and the Army's 82nd Airborne Divisions. ``No mail, sir,'' was the most common answer. Others in the group said they were impressed with troop morale in the harsh desert conditions. ``The morale here is just unbelieveable,'' Sen. John Warner, R-Va. and the ranking Republican on Armed Services, said after an paratrooper recounted an exercise in 140-degree heat. ``The people back home are with you,'' Warner said. In a brief tarmac interview, Warner said he was confident the American public could support the deployment even if it dragged on. ``The weak link in this dilemma isn't the people back home,'' Warner said. Asked if by that he expected other nations to eventually loosen their enforcement of sanctions against Iraq, Warner said: ``I don't think so. I certainly hope not.'' Other senators making the trip, all Republicans, were: Don Nickles of Oklahoma, Steve Symms of Idaho, Alfonse D'Amato of New York and Connie Mack of Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Foreign Minister Leads Saddam's Diplomatic Push
LaserPhoto NY21
With AM-Gulf Rpd, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tariq Aziz, Iraq's cigar-chomping foreign minister, arguably has the toughest assignment in world diplomacy _ defending Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait and the holding of thousands of Western men, women and children as hostages. Aziz, the only Christian in Saddam's 25-man Cabinet, heads the Iraqi president's diplomatic offensive in the confrontation with the United States over Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``He's a sly fox and he's utterly in Saddam's pocket,'' said Hans-Heino Kopietz, a London-based Middle East analyst who knows him. The silver-haired Aziz, who speaks English and often appears in public in olive drab military uniform, has shown a flair for survival. But like the rest of Saddam's inner circle, Aziz knows that if Saddam goes down, so does he. The urbane Aziz, 54, has escaped the periodic purges of top political and military officials since Saddam came to power 11 years ago. He survived an assassination attempt in Baghdad on April 1, 1980, when members of the Iranian-backed Ad Dawa Islami, or Islamic Call, detonated a bomb. Several people were killed. The bombing was one of a series of terrorist attacks by pro-Iranian militants in Iraq that was a factor in Saddam's decision to invade Iran in 1980, launching the eight-year gulf war. ``He's one of the brighter people in the regime,'' Kopietz said. ``He's made a lot of friends in the United Nations, which gives him some diplomatic clout. But he serves his master well and does what he's told.'' Aziz has been a close associate of Saddam since the 1950s, when they were in the Baath Arab Socialist Party underground struggling to overthrow the British-imposed monarchy. In those days, Saddam was a street fighter and gunman. Aziz, with a degree in English literature from Baghdad University, worked on party organization and propaganda. The Baath succeeded in seizing power in 1968. Saddam later became vice president and the real power behind the head of state, President Ahmad Hassan al-Bakr. Aziz was one of the party's leading ideologues and editor of its mouthpiece, the Al-Thawra daily newspaper. After Saddam shunted al-Bakr aside in 1979, Aziz was named information minister and became a member of the Baath's national command and the ruling Revolutionary Command Council headed by Saddam. He is considered one of the most eloquent defenders of the Baghdad government, always available to foreign reporters for interviews in his book-lined office. Given the totalitarian and ruthless nature of Saddam's rule, Aziz has no easy task. The invasion and annexation of Kuwait, and Saddam's decision to hold several thousand Americans and Britons hostage in Baghdad to deter Western attack, has made his job even more unenviable. In a government dominated by Sunni Moslems, the Christian Aziz has no independent power base of his own. He was born near the northern city of Mosul into a humble family of Nestorian Christians, an ancient sect that still speaks Aramaic, the language spoken in the time of Jesus Christ. His given name was Mikhail Yuhanna. He changed it to the Moslem-sounding name he now uses. Aziz was named foreign minister and deputy prime minister in 1981. Like other Iraqi leaders, he blamed the United States for the gulf war, claiming Washington had covertly encouraged the revolutionary government in Tehran to provoke Iraq so Washington could regain control of Iran. Aziz argued that Iraq was not the aggressor. Iraq invaded Iran in September 1980 but claimed the war had begun several weeks earlier with border attacks by the Iranians. During the latter stages of the war, when Saddam wanted to internationalize it so that Iran would be weakened and respond to his peace appeals, Aziz and other leaders became less anti-American. In 1986, after the United States restored relations with Baghdad, broken in 1967, the anti-American rhetoric stopped. But it flared again several months ago. Saddam accused the United States and the West of a concerted campaign against Iraq to prevent it from expanding its military power. He claimed that Western opposition was a prelude to an Israeli pre-emptive strike.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Has Working Session with King Hussein
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf to restore dropped words, `embassy in.'
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's King Hussein, touring North African countries as part of efforts to defuse the Persian Gulf crisis, met with Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi, the official Libyan news agency JANA reported today. The JANA dispatch, monitored in Rome, said Gadhafi and the king had a ``working session'' Sunday night in Tripoli, shortly after Hussein's arrival. It did not say what the two men discussed nor did it mention the Persian Gulf crisis, which was touched off when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and then annexed it. A senior Jordanian official said Sunday that King Hussein also will visit Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco and Mauritania. Hussein's visit to Libya is his first since 1984 and comes three months after diplomatic relations were restored. Gadhafi long disdained Jordan's friendly relations with the United States, and relations were cut after Libyan students burned Jordan's embassy in Tripoli to protest King Hussein's moderate policy toward Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes Claim Lives of Famous Musicians
With PM-Copter Crash, AM-Concert Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many prominent musicians have met early deaths in air accidents. Here is a list: Aug. 27, 1990, Grammy-winning blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan, 35, was killed when a helicopter crashed into a hill in East Troy, Wis., after departing from a concert. Vaughan had a platinum album with his band Double Trouble in ``Couldn't Stand the Weather,'' released in 1984. That year, he won a Grammy Award for best traditional blues recording for a song called ``Flood Down in Texas.'' This year, he won a Grammy in the contemporary blues category for ``In Step.'' Dec. 31, 1985, Rick Nelson died in a New Year's Eve plane crash near De Kalb, Texas. Nelson, 45, achieved rock 'n' roll stardom in the late 1950s and early '60s with hits like ``I'm Walkin,''' and ``Travelin' Man.'' He was featured, along with the rest of his family, on the long-running TV series, ``The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet.'' Oct. 21, 1977: Singer Ronnie Van Zant and some members of his Lynyrd Skynyrd band, which carved a niche in the rock world with its image as hard- drinking, hell-raising Southerners, were killed in a plane crash in McComb, Miss. Sept. 20, 1973: Jim Croce died in an air crash near Natchitoches, La., at age 30. He put together a string of rock hits such as ``Time in a Bottle'' in the 1970s. Dec. 10, 1967, rhythm and blues artist Otis Redding died in a plane crash in Wisconsin along with members of his band, the Bar-Kays. He was 26. His greatest hit, ``Sittin' on the Dock of The Bay,'' was released just three days before the crash. July 31, 1964, country music singer Jim Reeves, known for hits like ``Welcome to My World'' and ``He'll Have to Go,'' died at age 39 in a light plane crash near Nashville along with his manager, Dean Manuel, 30. March 5, 1963: Patsy Cline, whose country hits included ``Crazy'' and ``She's Got You,'' died in a plane crash near Camden, Tenn., at age 31. Also killed were Grand Ole Opry stars Cowboy Copas and Hawkshaw Hawkins and pilot Randy Hughes, Miss Cline's manager. Her life was dramatized in the movie, ``Sweet Dreams,'' starring Jessica Lange as Miss Cline. Feb. 3, 1959: A plane carrying singers J.P (The Big Bopper) Richardson, Buddy Holly and Richie Valens crashed near Mason City, Iowa, en route to a show in Fargo, N.D. The Big Bopper, whose big hit was ``Chantilly Lace'' in 1958, was 29. Holly, whose hits included ``Peggy Sue,'' was 22. Valens, famous for songs like ``La Bamba'' and ``Donna,'' was 18. Dec. 15, 1944, big band leader Glenn Miller was in a plane flying over the English Channel en route from Bedford, England, to Paris where he was to give a show. The plane never arrived. Two members of the British Royal Air Force said the musician's plane might have been hit by bombs jettisoned over the English Channel by RAF bombers.

DOC.HEAD: Crash Kills 11; Man Trapped More Than Five Hours in Wreckage
DOC.TEXT: A car stopped suddenly on a highway north of Durban, setting off a chain-reaction crash that killed 11 people and left one man trapped in the wreckage for 5{ hours, authorities said Monday. Rescue workers used torches and the ``jaws of life'' to free Paddy Millerd following the crash Sunday night. ``He's lucky to be alive,'' said Dr. John Keenan of the Natal Emergency Medical Service. Millerd was one of eight people injured in the accident, which involved more than a dozen vehicles. Police said one car came to a sudden stop on a highway and was hit from behind by another. More cars plowed into the growing wreckage. A tanker truck carrying chemicals then smashed into a line of traffic stopped because of the accident, setting off a large fire, police said. The highway was closed more than 12 hours. It was not known why the first car stopped. The independent South African Press Association reported Monday the tanker driver was arrested on suspicion of culpable homicide, drunk driving and reckless driving. His name was not released.

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest Quota System to Give Lower Castes More Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students commandeered buses and blocked streets Monday in the latest of a series of protests against a move to give downtrodden castes a bigger share of government jobs. The unrest began three three weeks ago when Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced a plan to set quotas to guarantee more jobs to lower castes. On Monday, Singh said quotas would also be introduced for lower-income groups, regardless of caste. Hindus, who make up at least 85 percent of India's people, have a complex social system of castes and sub-castes dividing them into a rigid hierarchy. High-caste Hindus hold the majority of government jobs and are usually richer than lower castes. Under the latest quotas, the number of reserved government jobs would rise to nearly 60 percent, with the rest awarded on merit. The government employs about 18 million people in this country of 880 million people. The government says ``socially backward classes'' make up about half of the population and that the quotas would help equitable distribution of income. Opponents say the quota system would lead to the employment and promotion of unqualified people and would heighten caste tensions. Discrimination on the basis of caste is banned by law. But in practice, the caste system still permeates Indian society, especially in rural areas. In New Delhi, students protesting Singh's proposals ordered passengers off city buses, broke the windows, deflated tires and left the buses blocking major intersections. Riot police chased students from one protest site to another. Police said at least 50 youths were arrested. At one point, government employees on their lunch break joined the protesting students. ``What they are doing is right,'' a gray-haired government officer told a policeman trying to disperse the students. ``Your children and mine won't get jobs.'' ``We are not going to take it. We want jobs,'' said Somesh, a teen-age student who was stopping buses in Connaught Place, the city's busiest commercial area. Most of the city's shops and schools were closed. Some closed to support the agitation; others because they feared vandalism. While the protests were under way, Singh was in Parliament proposing more quotas, this time for low-income groups. He said 5 percent to 10 percent of all government jobs would be reserved for low-income groups but the eligibility standards would be decided later.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Beach Braces for Labor Day a Year After Disturbances
DOC.TEXT: This resort city is helping to throw a Labor Day weekend party in hopes that last year's violence will be forgotten and that college students will continue to come to play on the beach and spend money. But some are urging a boycott of Virginia Beach. More than 100,000 young people jammed the city's beachfront strip for the 1989 Labor Day weekend. Many were students from predominantly black colleges and universities along the East Coast who have gathered here for an informal end-of-summer party for nearly 10 years. But violence and looting broke out. City and state police and the National Guard cleared the beachfront thoroughfare. Violent clashes between riot stick-wielding police and young blacks degenerated into a riot. Hundreds of people were arrested or cited, and more than 50 were injured. Most of those arrested were local residents, not college students. Damage was estimated at more than $1.4 million. Both sides blamed the other. The students said city officials and merchants had been hostile and rude, charging high prices and harassing them. City officials said it was simply a problem of too many people in too small an area with too little to do along the 24-block-long strip. Several groups are calling for black students to stay away this year. ``We are doing this to help economically empower black Americans and to protest the injustice done last year,'' said C. David Walker, a student at Norfolk State University and part of group called Concerned Black Awareness Council. He and others are promoting gatherings in Washington, Baltimore, and Atlantic Beach, S.C. The Virginia Beach gathering started nearly a decade ago when a group of black fraternity and sorority members gathered on the beach. From 1985 to 1988, the party had a promoter who called it Greekfest and worked with the city to provide entertainment. Problems in 1988 with scattered vandalism and rowdiness had merchants pressuring the City Council to ``do something about Greekfest.'' The council passed stricter alcohol and beach behavior laws and denied Greekfest organizers the use of city buildings for dances. A civic panel appointed to investigate the 1989 riots for the City Council found that both sides went into the holiday weekend with a defensive attitude. The group said there was enough blame to go around and that both sides needed to work together in planning for 1990. The Council then appointed another citizens group to plan the event with the condition that no tax money be spent to entertain the guests. Part of the festivities will be moved to a park several miles from the beach. With business help, the committee booked two days of musical entertainment at the park. There will be a job fair, a religious-human services conference, parade, football game, and prayer breakfast, plus beach games and swimsuit and dance competitions. Celebrities such as New York Knicks star Patrick Ewing, Christine King Farris, daughter of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., and NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks are expected to attended. There will be planned festivities at the beach, too. But Walker and other students still want to boycott the city. ``All this (the boycott) is, is to say for one four-day weekend, where we would normally spend our money in a predominantly white community, we're going to spend it in a black community,'' said Mark Thompson, a Howard University junior. A boycott would be bad news for Linwood Branch, president of the Virginia Beach Hotel and Motel Association. Branch and others said they don't know what to expect from the weekend, and hotel reservations at the beach are down nearly 70 percent. ``Usually we're about full for the weekend at this point,'' said Branch, owner of a resort and shop on the beach. ``Labor Day is normally the biggest weekend of the season that only lasts 60 to 70 days now.''

DOC.HEAD: 69 Miners Dead, 100 Missing After Explosion
LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers Monday recovered the bodies of 69 coal miners and tunneled toward about 100 others trapped by an explosion, although there was no sign they were alive. Yugoslavia's federal trade union demanded that all those responsible for the accident, from local officials to government ministers, resign. The cause of what would be Yugoslavia's worst mining accident has not been determined, but the investigation is focusing on an accumulation of coal dust or methane gas. One miner who was working near the surface was pulled out of the mine alive shortly after the blast early Sunday. Bosko Zelic, a member of the Kreka mine's managing board, told reporters it was unlikely any more survivors would be found. The mining minister, Radisa Gacic, said in a statement that the tragedy should not be compounded by ``by endangering the lives of any of the rescuers.'' But rescue teams refused to give up hope as they reached a point about 300 yards from an area where the shaft widens. That extra space could have dissipated the force of the blast, said rescue technician Rasim Kekic. ``If anybody happened to be in that spot during the explosion, he may have lived through it,'' he said. Rescuers had been working round the clock since the explosion to clear tons of concrete and other debris that blocked underground shafts. They were concentrating on clearing or building new ventilation shafts in case some of the miners still were alive. The inital blast left a crater 45 feet wide and about 15 feet deep where the entrance to the mine used to be. Huge blocks of concrete that formed the mine mouth lay strewn about the area, and the charred remains of a coal conveyer system were being removed by workers. Mining inspector Mehmed Zulic said that the number of mining helmets and lamps that were issued indicated 170 men were underground at the time of the blast. All but two had been identified. Earlier, Zelic had said the number of those trapped underground was 179. The miners at Kreka, about 90 miles west of Belgrade, returned Saturday from a weeklong strike that ended with a promised 100 percent raise in pay that averaged $270 a month. Speculation about the explosion focused on the possibility that volatile coal dust and methane gas built up in the mine, one of the nation's oldest, during the strike. Yugoslavia's previous worst mining disaster occurred when 128 miners died in 1965. Ninety men were killed in a methane explosion at a coal mine last November.

DOC.HEAD: Troops to Get Playing Cards
DOC.TEXT: Five casinos are planning to airlift 10,000 decks of playing cards to troops in Saudi Arabia by this weekend. Joe Mattes, director of sales and promotions at Laughlin's Colorado Belle, said the cards will be sent to the troops through Norton Air Force Base in San Bernardino, Calif. Along with the Belle, Laughlin's Edgewater Casino will be donating the cards, as well as Circus, Circus, Silver City and Slots a Fun in Las Vegas. ``It's our way of telling the men and women serving over seas how much we appreciate their work in keeping our country safe,'' Mattes said. ``We hope the cards will help them pass the long hours they spend thousands of miles from home.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Frees American Dependents; U.N. Chief and Iraqi to Talk
LaserColor DOD500
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with State Department expelling some Iraqi diplomats. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq allowed 52 American detainees to cross into Turkey today and the U.N. secretary-general announced he would meet a top Iraqi diplomat to seek a peaceful resolution of the Middle East crisis. In Washington, the State Department ordered a two-thirds reduction in the Iraqi Embassy staff in retaliation for Baghdad's crackdown on embassies in Kuwait. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said 36 Iraqi diplomats were being expelled, reducing the embassy's staff from 55 to 19. Those expelled include seven diplomats and 29 members of the non-diplomatic staff. The remaining Iraqi diplomats are being restricted to a 25-mile radius of Washington, she said. The 52 Americans, dependents of diplomats from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait who the Iraqis have refused to release, crossed into Turkey at the Habur border post early today and later flew to a NATO base at Incirlik, 320 miles to the west. Three members of the group, sons of diplomats, were turned back at the border by Iraqi officials, the State Department said in Washington. The three, all over age 18, were sent back to Baghdad under escort. The group's other members were to leave Turkey for the United States on Tuesday, said Sgt. Marty Davis, spokeswoman at Incirlik. In the Persian Gulf, U.S. warships shadowed Iraqi vessels but did not invoke a resolution passed by the U.N. Security Council on Saturday that sanctions the use of military might to enforce a U.N.-ordered trade embargo. CBS News reported that Iraqi captains have received new orders not to defy the embargo but to allow U.S. warships to stop and search their vessels. CBS did not cite a source for the report by its Pentagon correspondent. The multinational force got a boost today when the small gulf state of Qatar agreed to allow use of its military facilities by the forces confronting Iraq. Qatar has traditionally cooperated militarily with Britain and France. In Paris, the military chiefs of nine Western European nations gathered to work out plans to enforce the United Nations embargo. The United Nations said Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will meet Thursday in Jordan with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz ``to engage in a full exchange of views on the crisis.'' It would be the first formal U.N. attempt to mediate the crisis, which Iraqi President Saddam Hussein precipitated by invading Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexing the oil-rich emirate. In Washington, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said Sunday that the Bush administration ``would have no problem'' with a mediation effort by Perez de Cuellar. For a third day, skeleton staffs at embassies in Kuwait City defied an Iraqi order to close their missions. Iraqi troops surrounded the U.S. and other compounds and cut utilities but did not use force against the diplomats. The U.S., British, French, Hungarian and Danish embassies were among those surrounded Sunday. Varying services such as water, power and communications were cut to the U.S., West German, French, Canadian, Japanese, Danish missions. Iraq last week ordered embassies in Kuwait closed, but most nations said they did not recognize Iraq's takeover of its neighbor and refused to heed the order. There have been no reports of Iraqis moving on the embassy holdouts. However, Lebanese officials in Beirut said today that Lebanon's ambassador to Kuwait and his nine-member staff were missing after leaving their mission. Salah Staitieh, director-general of the Lebanese Foreign Ministry, said group was due in Beirut two days ago. Local radio stations in Lebanon said the embassy group was seized by Iraqi troops as it set out for the Saudi border and was taken to Baghdad. The United States sent about 100 diplomats and dependents from Kuwait to Baghdad last week for transit home but the Iraqis reneged on a promise to let them out, saying male embassy workers would be held until the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait was closed. Early today, 52 wives and children of the captive U.S. diplomats were permitted to cross into Turkey. The 429-mile journey from Baghdad to Diyarbakir in southern Turkey took 27 hours, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said condition of anonymity. ``The trip was very tiring, very long and very distressing. Now they are washing up and resting,'' he said before they flew to the Incirlik base. An official at the base, speaking on condition of anonymity, later confirmed the group's arrival and declined to let any of the arrivals talk with an AP reporter by phone. In all, about 21,000 Westerners are stranded in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans. Iraq says some have been distributed among Iraqi strategic sites for use as human shields to deter a U.S. attack. The United States, Britain and France all reported Sunday that more of their citizens in Kuwait had been rounded up. The State Department said in Washington Sunday that Iraqi troops detained two more Americans, who were being held at a Kuwaiti hotel. Dozens have been rounded up in the past weeks. Britain's Foreign Office said today that more British nationals were rounded up Sunday in Kuwait, bringing the total held to 157. In France, the Foreign Ministry said Iraqi troops took eight more French from their homes in Kuwait to a hotel. In all, 60 French nationals are detained. Pope John Paul II, in his first public condemnation of Iraqi actions, criticized human rights violations and prayed for the foreign hostages. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait prompted several nations to send warships to the region, and the United States has moved dozens of warplanes and about 60,000 troops in Saudi Arabia to prevent further Iraqi aggression. It is the biggest American deployment since the Vietnam war. On Sunday, the Army ordered 50 more reserve and National Guard units in 25 states to report for active duty by Aug. 31. Air National Guard Reserve units from six states were called up on Friday. In Paris today, the top military leaders of the nine-member Western European Union opened a one-day meeting behind closed doors. A military source said before the meeting opened that the chief topic would be dividing the tasks of European naval forces and coordinating them with the huge U.S. fleet in the region. But attention also turned to diplomacy. A day after the U.N. Security Council authorized the use of military force to back the trade embargo it ordered against Iraq on Aug. 6, Perez de Cuellar offered to meet with Iraq's top diplomat. In Baghdad, Aziz said he planned to meet with the U.N. chief but declined to say whether Iraq was prepared to compromise on Kuwait's status. He did say, however, that his country would listen to any proposal. Scowcroft said the United States will not back down from its insistence that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, but beyond that ``We're prepared to talk about anything.'' Also in Baghdad, Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat proposed today that an Arab peacekeeping force be deployed in Kuwait for six months to replace Iraqi troops while elections are held. The Bush administration has insisted that the deposed al-Sabah family be restored as Kuwait's rulers.

DOC.HEAD: General Strike Cripples Townships; Tutu Lashes Out at Police
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of blacks went on strike Monday to demand an end to factional fighting that has killed more than 500 people. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu angrily blamed police and pro-apartheid whites for the violence. Tutu called for creation of a new police force acceptable to blacks as he addressed about 6,000 people gathered at a funeral for seven ANC supporters killed in the battles. ``The evidence is overwhelming that the police have not been impartial,'' he told the cheering listeners. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok later rejected charges that police took sides in the conflict. He said in a statement that individual officers may have acted improperly but that the force as a whole tried to maintain order. The strike left the streets of Soweto, a sprawling black township of 2.5 million people, nearly deserted. Many businesses in Soweto and neighboring Johannesburg were forced to close or operate with skeleton staffs. Most trains and buses were almost empty or did not run. The strike was called by the anti-apartheid Soweto Civic Association to ``protest the violence, police behavior and to mourn our dead.'' Residents in several neighboring townships also took part. Heavily armed South African troops and police in armored vehicles patrolled the townships. Police commanders reported no new violence in the Johannesburg area. Savage fighting erupted in the townships around Johannesburg on Aug. 12, pitting Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the African National Congress against Zulus tied to the conservative Inkatha movement. Police said at least 515 people were killed. Police said Monday at least 10 blacks were killed during the weekend in the eastern province of Natal, which has been the scene of factional fighting since 1986. More than 5,000 people have died there. Tutu, a top anti-apartheid leader, passionately denounced the government and police for the violence. He charged the unrest was fomented to frustrate blacks' struggle to be free in South Africa, where the black majority has no voice in national affairs. ``Our freedom is at hand,'' Tutu said to tumultuous cheers. ``And there are those (whites) who say they don't want us to have our freedom ... so they have made us fight one another.'' Zulus and Xhosas are the two largest tribes in South Africa, but Tutu denied the fighting was caused by tribal divisions. ``We have never quarreled because of tribalism. It is a lie! It is a lie!'' he shouted in anger. Other black leaders also attacked the government, charging that apartheid created the ethnic tensions that triggered the fighting. They called for abolition of the hostels where Zulu migrant workers live. Those hostels have often come under attack. ``It is a violence that has been organized by evil forces _ white and black,'' said senior ANC leader Walter Sisulu. At the funeral, ANC honor guards in khaki uniforms stood around the coffins giving clenched fist salutes. The stadium was filled with chanting and singing blacks, many wearing the black, green and gold colors of the ANC. ``I am proud I am black,'' the crowd chanted in unison with Tutu. Government and police leaders deny the charges of bias and insist security forces have been impartial. Elite army battalions were sent into the townships during the weekend to help police. The government and many neutral observers portray the conflict as mostly tribal fighting linked to the power struggle between the ANC and Inkatha. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi has blamed the ANC for instigating the fighting, accusing it of wanting to crush all opposition. President F.W. de Klerk is negotiating with the ANC and other groups to end apartheid and share political power with the black majority. Both Inkatha and the ANC oppose apartheid, South Africa's system of racial segregation, but differ on methods for fighting it.

DOC.HEAD: Jumbo Jet With 342 Aboard Makes Safe Emergency Landing Without Nose Gear
DOC.TEXT: A United Airlines jumbo jet with 342 people aboard skidded to a safe emergency landing today at Los Angeles International Airport after its nose landing gear would not extend, authorities said. The 323 passengers and 19 crew members used emergency chutes to evacuate the Boeing 747, which was coming in from Sydney, Australia, said Tony Molinaro, a spokesman for Chicago-based United Airlines. ``There were no serious injuries reported in the evacuation,'' said Molinaro. He said he was not sure if there were any minor injuries, but he said he knew no one was hospitalized. Fred O'Donnell, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said the aircraft was on approach when the crew notified the tower it was unable to get the front landing gear down. The 10:25 a.m. emergency forced authorities to close down two of the airport's four runways. ``We had to close Runway 25 Left and 25 Right,'' said O'Donnell. ``It can be handled. We just move traffic to the remaining runways. It's not causing a problem.'' It was the second United airliner in a week to land at the airport with a failed landing gear. On Tuesday, a United Boeing 737 jetliner with a retracted right main gear skidded to a safe landing, coming down on the nose gear, the left main gear and the engine under the right wing. It had been diverted to the Los Angeles airport from nearby Burbank Airport. The 107 people aboard the plane slid down emergency chutes. There were no injuries. A flashlight left by a mechanic in the wheel well was responsible for the gear failure, said investigators.

DOC.HEAD: Robbery Suspect Arrested After WLS-TV Studio Evacuated
DOC.TEXT: An armed robbery suspect who forced a television station to interrupt broadcasting by hiding in its building was arrested Monday on the seventh floor. Police found the man in a closet of the building that houses WLS-TV about 29 hours after he entered, said Detective Stephen Stratton. The man had a semiautomatic weapon and about $6,000 in cash believed to have been taken Saturday from a restaurant, Stratton said. WLS went off the air for 25 minutes Saturday night and evacuated about 50 employees after the gunman was seen in a stairwell. Police searched the building but did not find the gunman, who did not harm anyone or attempt to take hostages. Station personnel rigged a studio at their transmitter and broadcast a special report about the gunman. But they had to suspend regular programming. The station resumed regular programming Sunday at 7 a.m. Police surrounded the building again Sunday night after a witness reported hearing glass break and spotting a man in a 10th-floor window. He was arrested early Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Personal Income, Consumer Spending Both Up
DOC.TEXT: Personal incomes grew 0.6 percent in July and consumer spending rose 0.5 percent, the government said Monday in a report that some analysts contend points to a stronger economy than expected. Stephen S. Roach, senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York, said the growth in both areas was important since it could tend to lessen the effect of the Middle East crisis on the economy. ``It holds out the hope that we might be able to scrape by without going into recession,'' he said. In another upbeat report, the National Association of Realtors said existing home sales rose for a second straight month in July. House resales rose 3.3 percent following a 0.9 percent gain in June. The increase reflected decreasing mortgage rates at the end of July, but the trend has reversed since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and analysts predict a slowdown in sales. The Commerce Department said consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, totaled $3.67 trillion. That was up $16.6 billion from the previous month although the pace was slower than June's 1 percent increase. A Commerce spokesman said the slower pace resulted from fewer purchases of automobiles, food and clothing. Nevertheless, William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, called the consumption expenditures for June and July a ``bright spot.'' ``If the July consumption level can be maintained for the next two months, consumption in the third quarter will increase at an annual rate of 2.3 percent over the second quarter,'' he said. ``This would be the highest quarterly increase since the third quarter of 1989.'' But MacReynolds and others said the inflationary effects of rising oil prices likely will reduce spending. So far, however, there have been no ``horror stories,'' according to economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting firm. ``People haven't been canceling auto purchases,'' she said. ``Retailers are complaining about soft business, but there's no sign of further deterioration because of the Middle East crisis.'' The Commerce Department also reported that personal incomes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.67 trillion, a $26.3 billion increase from June. It was the largest increase since a 0.7 percent gain in March. The report said Americans' income after taxes increased 0.5 percent, down slightly from 0.6 percent a month earlier. ``The gains were primarily from wages and salaries, rather than dividends and interest payments and things like that,'' Ms. Shaber said. ``It suggests some strength in the economy, and that's money that people spend.'' Wages and salaries rose $16.2 billion after a $15.9 billion increase in June. Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percent of disposable income _ was unchanged from June's 4.9 percent. A higher savings rate means less dependence on foreign capital since funds thus would be available domestically for business investment. Americans' savings rate for all of 1989 was 4.6 percent. On the spending side, the increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, rose $16.6 billion, down from June's gain of $36.1 billion. Spending on durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ increased $5.3 billion. It was the second consecutive increase after five months of declines. Non-durable spending, however, slipped $1.7 billion following a $13.5 billion gain in June. Spending on services was up $13.0 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Miss America Contestants Arrive in Atlantic City
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: The 50 women competing to be Miss America 1991 arrived Monday, using a train for the first time since 1939. ``Since it was my first train ride, I was quite excited,'' Miss Indiana, Brenda Alyce Bassett, said as the pageant began its two-week 70th anniversary celebration. The contestants' arrival differed from years past when competitors came by plane and car at staggered times. Pageant director Leonard Horn said the pageant returned to train travel to commemorate the anniversary of the program, which began in 1921 as a public relations gimmick by seaside merchants to eke out an added weekend of tourists after Labor Day. In another reference to the past, the contestants spent the weekend making public appearances in Philadelphia. Between 1935 and 1939, the contestants first stopped in Philadelphia before they came to Atlantic City. The pageant has gradually placed greater emphasis on brains over beauty, but Monday's arrival _ like most first days _ shifted the focus to contestants' looks and what they were wearing. This week will be spent rehearsing for next week's show as well as practicing individual talents. The finals will be nationally televised Sept. 8. The winner will succeed Miss America 1990, Debbye Turner, and win a $35,000 scholarship.

DOC.HEAD: Baseball Fans Rampage to Protest Defeat, Nine Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of baseball fans stormed onto a field to protest their team's defeat and hurled broken bottles, trash cans, rocks and burning chairs in a rampage that left nine people hospitalized, police said Monday. President Roh Tae-woo ordered an investigation into the incident, which occurred Sunday night. The prosecutor general's office said six men were being held by police for questioning. One of the injured was hit in the abdomen by shards of glass and was hospitalized in serious condition, police said. Seven other spectators and one riot policeman were also hospitalized. The rampage began three hours into a game between two professional teams, the Haitai Tigers and the Lucky Group Twins. The Twins were ahead 10-0 in the bottom of the seventh when the trouble started. About 400 Tiger fans jumped over barricades surrounding the playing field and stampeded into the pitching area, witnesses said. Another 20,000 spectators shouted and booed from their seats. Protesters hurled hundreds of broken bottles, metal trash cans, rocks and chairs which were set afire, witnesses and police said. The rampage lasted 50 minutes until police intervened. It was not clear what ignited the protest, but witnesses said supporters for the losing team felt they were being cheated. The Twins went on to win the game 13-1. The two teams are placed third and fourth in South Korea's single professional baseball league. Competition between them is intense.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Criticized for Statement about Church, Park
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan's remark that Yellowstone National Park was ``devastated'' by fire two years ago is being criticized as too harsh. Critics also are upset that Lujan said an apocalyptic group that owns land north of the park poses no threat to Yellowstone. Park officials have warned some activities of the Church Universal and Triumphant could harm the park's geothermal resources and its wildlife. During a visit to the park in Wyoming last week, Lujan said it was his impression that the 1988 fires in and near the park ``devastated'' Yellowstone. That was in sharp contrast to efforts by state and federal agencies to play down the extent of the damage. Lujan's comments ``reflect a fundamental misunderstanding of two of the most serious issues facing the land and the people of Park and Gallatin counties,'' Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., said in a letter to Lujan. Baucus said Lujan's statements ``were out of line with public statements and professional judgments of your own Park Service land managers.'' Jeanne Marie Souvigney of the Greater Yellowstone Coalition agreed. ``He must not understand the issues to make statements like that,'' she said. ``There has been a big educational effort that the park was changed by the fires, not devastated.'' Lujan last week met privately with Elizabeth Clare Prophet, the church's spiritual leader, in an effort to hear the church's side of the conflicts with the park and to try to bring the two sides closer to conciliation. He said the conflicts are ``not insurmountable'' and that he believed the park and the church can be good neighbors. The church was criticized last spring when an estimated 31,000 gallons of diesel and gasoline leaked from three tanks at its underground shelter complex. The shelters are intended to protect followers during what Prophet says is a 12-year ``dark cycle'' of global danger and catastrophe. Steve Goldstein, a spokesman for Lujan, said Lujan's intention in meeting with Prophet was to try to bring the park and church closer together. Park officials have testified in public hearings and before Congress that some activities of the church threaten the greater Yellowstone ecosystem. The concerns include development affecting wildlife migration patterns and the church's drilling of a well in a geothermal aquifer. Church officials have said they are considerate of wildlife migration in the fencing of their property. They also have promised not to develop the geothermal well if it would pose any risk to Yellowstone's geysers.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Appeals to Arabs to Increase Pressure on Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday urged Arab countries to unite against Iraqi aggression as he met with the Egyptian foreign minister, the Tass news agency said. Gorbachev emphasized to Esmat Abdel-Meguid ``the necessity of bringing the Arab factor to bear more strongly'' on Iraq, the official news agency said. ``The circumstances are such that Arabs should show their ability to unify quickly and to make joint decisions in their own interests and in the interests of the whole world,'' Tass paraphrased Gorbachev as telling the Egyptian official. ``This would be highly appreciated by the international community,'' he reportedly added. At an Aug. 10 summit in Cairo, 12 of the 21 nations in the Arab League voted to condemn Iraq for seizing Kuwait and agreed to send Arab soldiers to help defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi offensive. Only Egypt, Morocco and Syria have contributed troops. Meanwhile, the evacuation of the families of Soviet oil workers and other technical specialists from Baghdad was being planned. A total of 983 Soviet dependents have been living in Iraq, and all of them are slated to depart on special Aeroflot flights by Sept. 1, Tass said. Gorbachev has called Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait an act of ``treachery'' and a ``blatant violation of international law.'' The Soviet Union voted Saturday for a U.N. Security Council resolution allowing the use of force to impose an international economic embargo on Iraq, a longtime Soviet ally. But Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said Sunday that the Soviet navy, which has two warships in the Persian Gulf region, would not itself use force. Shevardnadze denied that the Soviet Union was restraining itself for the sake of its 7,791 citizens _ including 193 military advisers _ still in Iraq. ``There is no direct connection between the fact that we are not counting on the use of force, and the evacuation of our citizens from Iraq,'' he said. Shevardnadze reiterated the Soviet position that the gulf crisis should be resolved peacefully and politically, rather than militarily. ``Another way (other than a political solution) would mean a catastrophe,'' be told reporters. Despite the unwillingness to use force against its old ally, Soviet officials have maintained that Moscow is in complete solidarity with Western governments against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``The resolutions of the Security Council will be strictly enforced,'' Tass said in summarizing Gorbachev's remarks to Abdel-Meguid. ``And Iraq must draw the correct conclusions from the solidarity shown by the international community in these resolutions, and must not try to aggravate the situation, but rather seek from its side a way out of the impasse.''

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Mixed on Short-Term Treasury Securities
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.49 percent, down from 7.55 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.48 percent, up from 7.45 percent last week. The rates were the lowest for three-month bills since they sold for 7.41 percent on Aug. 13. It was the highest for six-month bills since they averaged 7.52 percent on July 16. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.74 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,810.70 and 7.88 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,621.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.93 percent last week, up from 7.73 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Woman Gets Good News
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arleen Nelson was elated to hear Monday that her daughter and two grandchildren were among 52 Americans safely across the Iraq border. But she's not letting her guard down yet. ``We won't be really at rest until they are back in the United States,'' Mrs. Nelson said. ``It's been a really tense time.'' Rande Vellekoop and her two daughters _ Brigitte, 3, and Joanna, 10 months _ had been trapped in the Persian Gulf region since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``We are waiting to hear from the State Department on where she will be coming in and when,'' Mrs. Nelson said in a telephone interview. Mrs. Nelson said she and her husband, Bud, hadn't spoken with their daughter since her release. Mrs. Vellekoop did, however, manage to reach one of her sisters by telephone. ``I don't know if she'll call anymore,'' she said. In all, about 21,000 Westerners are stranded in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans. Iraq says some hostages have been distributed among Iraqi strategic sites for use as human shields to deter a U.S. attack. The freed Americans, dependents of diplomats from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, crossed into Turkey at the Habur border post early Monday. They later flew to a NATO base at Incirlik, 320 miles to the west. The group was expected to leave Turkey for the United States on Tuesday, said Sgt. Marty Davis, a spokeswoman at Incirlik. Mrs. Vellekoop's husband, Laurens Vellekoop, 33, was among State Department employees, and three young embassy dependents over the age of 18, whom Iraqi authorities refused to release. Mrs. Nelson said she received a call from her son-in-law Sunday. ``Oh my gosh, I was so surprised,'' she said. ``All I could think of was, `Praise the Lord' and how thankful I was to ... hear his voice.''

DOC.HEAD: Brush Fire Destroys 18 Homes; Two Firefighters Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with authorities revise number of homes destroyed to 18 sted 50; picks up 6th graf pvs, `Top priority ...'
DOC.TEXT: A wind-driven brush fire that mushroomed from 120 acres to 2,500 in an afternoon killed two firefighters and destroyed 18 summer homes, authorities said. The firefighters, whose names were not immediately released, were apparently overcome by smoke early today, a spokesman said. ``The wind must have changed and got them disoriented with the smoke and trapped them in there,'' said Bevan Killpack, Uinta National Forest fire information officer. ``That happens if you don't have people watching the behavior of the fire.'' About 200 firefighters battled the blaze overnight, and fire bosses issued a call for 160 more, officials said. Dozens of residents were evacuated from the path of the flames, which were sent racing by canyon wind gusting to 40 mph. Dick Buehler, deputy incident commander, told more than 100 residents at a noon meeting that only 18 homes and cabins in the Swiss Alpine subdivision had been confirmed destroyed, a figure revised sharply downward from the 50 homes fire officials had believed were burned. Top priority was given to saving 300 homes in the Devil's Hole, Lime Canyon and Snake Creek areas. The homes destroyed were in Devil's Hole, said Uinta forest spokeswoman Loyal Clark. The fire was partly in the forest. ``It's a summer-home area where the fire's concentrated, and most of the people in there have left and gone back to their homes. Most of those people had residences in Salt Lake (City) and other areas,'' sheriff's Deputy Jeff Winterton said. The number of those who fled was not immediately known. Smoke from the blaze a half-mile south of Midway drifted over Salt Lake City, about 30 miles to the northeast. Joan Smith, a Salt Lake real estate broker visiting the area, said the smoke in the afternoon was so heavy it looked like dusk. ``The sun was blood red it was so thick,'' she said.
