When word came that flames were fast approaching the Dahl home, family members grabbed photo albums, important documents and their two dogs. ``We just freaked out,'' Millie Dahl said. ``The house is totally gone. We didn't get our clothes, our truck, another car, our snowmobile and the Snowcat out of there in time.'' Mrs. Dahl, 39, her husband, Will, 48, and the couple's three teen-age children spent the night with friends. Their house in the Swiss Alpine neighborhood was one of the few permanently inhabited homes to go, she said. ``I wish we could have had 10 more minutes, but the smoke was billowing,'' she said. ``It was obvious that there was a problem. Fortunately, nobody cried, no one got hysterical and no one fell apart.'' The fire had simmered since Thursday or Friday until the wind Sunday pushed the flames up a mountainside into pine forests and dry oak brush. Gusts carried embers into adjacent canyons, making it difficult for firefighters to predict its spread, Clark said. Fire bosses ordered more crews ``from wherever they can get them,'' said Dave Smith of the Interagency Fire Center in Salt Lake City. A call was also put out for more air tankers and helicopters. Firefighters late Sunday had one of each, officials said. ``We need the air tankers really bad because of the threat to those structures,'' Clark said. ``This looks like our big one of the year.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department: Libya Aided Terrorist Attack on Israel
DOC.TEXT: The Libyan government ``provided direct support in all phases of preparation'' for an unsuccessful May 30 terrorist attack on jammed beach resorts near Tel Aviv, Israel, the State Department said Monday. In a paper it said was based on information from U.S. sources, the department said the six assault boats used in the raid were launched from the merchant ship Tiny Star, known earlier as the Inger M. It said Libya provided personnel who accompanied the ship as it sailed from a Libyan naval base to Ras el-Hilal, on Libya's Mediterranean coast. There it picked up at least 16 terrorists of the Palestine Liberation Front. The department said the Tiny Star then left Libya for the drop-off point west of Israel. ``After launching the assault boats, the Tiny Star probably traveled west-southwest to blend in with the hundreds of merchant ships en route to and from the Suez canal,'' the paper said. The ship was docked at the Libyan port of Tobruk in mid-June and was in the harbor of Tripoli, the Libyan capital, later that month, the paper said. In late July, it said, the ship sailed from Tripoli to Piraeus, Greece. The department said the Tiny Star was purchased in April by Star Navigation Company of Piraeus and sailed from Cyprus for Tripoli on April 10. ``Libya provided direct support in all phases of preparation for the PLF attack against Israel, from assistance in planning the attack to providing personnel who accompanied the ship from which it was launched,'' the department said. It said the PLF began preparing for the seaborne attack at least as early as October 1988. ``From late 1988 until the operation was launched, training and preparations took place in Libya at several locations, including a Libyan naval base,'' the paper said. In a statement accompanying the paper, the department said, ``The U.S. will retain its sanctions against Libya; we expect other governments will continue their sanctions until Libya demonstrates concrete, durable changes in its support for terrorism and cessation of other objectionable behavior.'' Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said ``Libya's involvement in this terrorist operation provides one of the clearest examples ever established of state sponsorship of terrorism, and once again highlights the threat Libya poses to its neighbors and to peace in the region.'' Four Palestinian guerrillas were killed and 12 captured by Israeli forces in the May 30 attack. No Israelis were injured although tens of thousands were at beaches and resort hotels near Tel Aviv to mark Shavuot, the Jewish holiday that honors the giving of the Ten Commandments.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Calls Weapons Charge Against Husband Political Blackmail
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said Monday that charges of illegal weapons possession brought against her husband were politically motivated. ``This is blackmail,'' she said. ``They are just trying to pressure the PPP (Pakistan People's Party) and intimidate me and humiliate him.'' Police filed the charges Sunday night against Asif Ali Zardari but did not arrest the 37-year-old businessman. Ms. Bhutto said the charges were designed to influence elections scheduled for Oct. 24. She already had expressed doubts that the balloting would be free and impartial. Many Pakistanis have questioned whether there even will be elections in October. Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government was dismissed Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, abuse of power and its inability to curb relentless ethnic and political violence. Although she was removed under constitutional provisions, Ms. Bhutto called it a virtual coup. The new military-backed government is setting up tribunals to investigate corruption. Zardari, who critics contend profited while Ms. Bhutto was in power, is expected to be the main target. Qazi Abid, a member of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, also was charged with weapons possession. However, the charges may be dismissed because he is a minister in the new caretaker government. The state-run television on Sunday said all arms licences were being revoked, presumably an attempt to curb repeated shooting sprees in the southern province of Sindh. The broadcast said former and current members of Pakistan's National Assembly and Senate would be allowed to keep their weapons licenses. The charges stem from a raid Saturday of an unregistered jeep that belonged to Abid. Police said a large cache of weapons was seized and Zardari's driver and bodyguard were arrested. Police said some of the weapons were licensed to Abid and some to Zardari. In Islamabad, Abid denied the charges.

DOC.HEAD: First-Rate Roads, Communications Makes U.S. Deployment Easier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs to CLARIFY Sgt. Woods staying in dormlike room. Exact locations of U.S. deployments are withheld to comply with Pentagon ground rules.
DOC.TEXT: When Americans have time to pause in their hurry-up deployment in Saudi Arabia, they find themselves admiring the kingdom's roads and ports, which in some cases surpass those in the United States. Flying over, Sgt. Kenneth Woods of Avon Park, Fla. imagined nights in the pitch black desert eating field rations and trying to cope with the heat. Instead, Woods, a member of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division, is staying in a dormlike room in an air-conditioned trailer that has its own bathroom and shower. Trailer complexes built throughout Saudi Arabia to house construction and oil industry workers are serving as temporary homes to American soldiers. The burgers and fries the Saudis bring for dinner at the camp are sometimes cold by the time they get there, ``but who's in a position to complain,'' said Woods. ``The Saudi government has been remarkably responsive,'' said Army Maj. Gen. Gus Pagonis, who heads the Pentagon's logistics planning in Saudi Arabia. Because of its oil wealth, Saudi Arabia has over the past 20 years pushed an aggressive, multibillion-dollar infrastructure program, often using American companies and consultants. ``We have the money and we want our people to have the best possible conditions,'' a Saudi official said. ``You cannot be a modern society without these things.'' At times, American military commanders stand in awe as they lead reporters through Saudi military installations. ``This is magnificent,'' Air Force Col. John McBroom said during a tour of F-15 hangers at a Saudi air base where his First Tactical Fighter Wing has set up camp. ``These are the best, most modern facilities I've ever seen.'' Navy officials are similarly pleased with Saudi docks. ``We are getting tremendous use of the facilities here,'' Adm. Steve Clarey told reporters last week as Marine tanks, trucks, bulldozers and other equipment were offloaded from U.S. cargo ships. ``This is probably one of the most modern ports in the world.'' So oversized are most Saudi military installations that American forces have been able to move in without dislodging the Saudis from hangers or barracks. The Army's 101st Airborne's air assault brigade is using a Saudi airstrip for its helicopters. ``This saves a lot of wear and tear that would be caused if we had to land over and over again in the sand,'' said Col. Tom Garrett, the brigade's commander. When the huge transport planes carrying American troops and equipment land and unload at Saudi airfields, their cargo is shipped into field positions along a highway system that might make U.S. urban planners jealous. Wide, smooth highways stretch to and from all major cities, and into some desolate desert. It is common to pass construction crews working on new secondary roads around the clock. ``You expect to be getting stuck in the sand all the time, but instead you're worrying about the speed limit,'' an Army truck driver said last week.

Cholera Outbreak Leaves About 30 Dead
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of cholera has killed about 30 people in and around the city of Meknes, the opposition L'Opinion newspaper reported Monday. The epidemic has also spread from Meknes, 90 miles north of Rabat, to the cities of Fez in central Morocco and Taza in the northeast, the newspaper said. L'Opinion estimated more than 200 people in Meknes alone have been treated for cholera. Official Health Ministry figures released Saturday put the figure at 24. The newspaper did not say how the outbreak began, but said the number of cholera cases in Meknes rose in mid-August.

DOC.HEAD: Single Father Prepares for Possible Active Military Duty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT technical to technician
DOC.TEXT: For single parents in the military reserves, the possibility of being called to active duty has an added worry: who will take care of the children? Air Force reservist Phillip Meyer of Savannah is preparing for that contingency now. Meyer, a surgical technician with the 13th Contingent Hospital in Warner Robins, received a call from his unit Friday telling him to prepare to be activated for at least 30 days and asked if he preferred stateside or foreign duty. He prefers to stay in the United States. After the call, Meyer phoned his mother, Edith Meyer, who also lives in Savannah, to ask her to take care of his three children _ 4-year-old Christopher, 3-year-old Christin and 2-year-old Morgan. Then he began wondering what the kids would think if and when he goes. Christopher, the oldest boy, has an idea of what is going on, Meyer said, but the two girls are just too young to comprehend that their father may have to leave them for a long time. ``They know that I'm in the Air Force, pretty much so that every time an airplane flies overhead they say, `there's daddy,''' said Meyer as he rocked Morgan in his living room. ``They're used to me leaving once a month (for drills), but I don't know how they will handle it if I'm activated.'' However, even with three small children, Meyer said he is just like the other reservists trying to get ready, noting that his commanding officer in Warner Robins is in a similar situation _ a single parent with two children. Despite uncertainty about which reserve units ultimately will be activated, Meyer said he wasn't surprised that President Bush agreed with Pentagon advice to call up the reserves. And he said his medical expertise means he may be deployed to Saudi Arabia. ``There's the possibility that I will be over there, because we are a surgical trauma unit. That's what we do.''

DOC.HEAD: KLM Detours Flights To Avoid Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch national airline KLM said Monday it has detoured some of its flights around the Persian Gulf so that crews will no longer stay overnight in the region. KLM flights to the Far East, which previously made stopovers at airports in the gulf, will instead fly via airports in Greece, India, and Thailand, said airline spokesman Peter Wellhuner. The gulf states, including Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Oman, will only be serviced by round-trip flights that do not require new crews to take over in transit. ``We don't want to have our crews positioned overnight in that area'' because of safety concerns, said Wellhuner. The Dutch government has advised businesses to withdraw all non-essential personnel from the gulf and has warned tourists to avoid the region. KLM flies 42 times a week to the Middle East from the Dutch capital. The airline's daily services to Baghdad and Kuwait were discontinued immediately after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists: Politics Is Key To Bush's Owl Plan
DOC.TEXT: Politics is driving a new Bush administration report that will recommend ways to ease the economic toll of protecting the northern spotted owl, environmentalists charged Monday. The government's Interagency Task Force on the Spotted Owl is to recommend by Saturday how the Forest Service should alter its timber harvests to protect the threatened owl across millions of acres in the Pacific Northwest. The panel's goal, as outlined by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, is to keep the species alive by enforcing the Endangered Species Act without devastating the region's timber industry. ``They are trying to find a political solution to a scientific problem,'' said Mike Francis, director of The Wilderness Society's national forest program. ``If they are going to maintain the integrity of the Endangered Species Act, there is very little wiggle room for the administration,'' he said Monday. Frances Hunt of the National Wildlife Federation agreed ``there's very little scientific'' about the task force's mission. ``This is politics and very shortsighted politics. It's ignoring the real issues. It's only going to make a realistic solution harder to find,'' she said. Officials for the Forest Service, Agriculture Department and Interior Department have declined comment on the task force's work over the past week. Agriculture Department spokeswoman Jane Stevens said members of the task force have been directed not to talk to the media. Environmentalists maintain that dramatic reductions in logging of the region's old-growth forests is the only legally and scientifically defensible way to take the rare owl off the road to extinction. The government earlier predicted that one owl protection plan offered by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas and a panel of government scientists would cut regional harvests in half and cost more than 20,000 jobs. But Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said on Sunday that the task force recommendation likely will not impact as much land or as many jobs as has been feared.

DOC.HEAD: 1,400 Sunbeam Mixers Recalled Because of Electric Shock Danger
DOC.TEXT: Sunbeam Appliance Co. of Milwaukee is recalling 1,400 mixers found to have a risk of severe electric shock, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said Monday. The commission said the counter-top mixers can cause severe shock if motors and other electrical components shift through shipping or handling and come in contact with the chrome-plated housing. There have been no reports of consumers being injured, it said. Sunbeam spokesman Wayne Smith said the defect was discovered through rough handling tests at the factory and voluntarily reported to the government. The affected models were distributed from February through April this year and have the model numbers 01930 and 01940. The two models had suggested retail prices of $165 to $185. People with those models were advised to stop using them immediately and contact Sunbeam. Smith said several thousand units had already been recovered from store shelves. The company, a subsidiary of Oster-Sunbeam Appliance, has set up a toll-free telephone number (1-800-441-7068) to help consumers determine if their mixers should be returned. Replacement mixers will be provided free of charge, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Warnings Come Down As Storm Heads Past Islands
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav curved away from outer Caribbean islands Monday and aimed its 105 mph winds toward open ocean. Gustav _ which reached hurricane strength Sunday while heading west toward the Leeward Islands _ turned north onto a path that would skirt the island chain and take it out into the Atlantic. Storm warnings in the islands, which stretch north from the Venezuelan coast, were droppped, but forecasters said rough seas and surf might be experienced. ``They'll probably get a little of the fringe effects,'' said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``But the hurricane itself looks like it's going to pass to the east.'' At 3 p.m. EDT, Gustav was centered near 17.4 degrees north latitude and 58.2 degrees west longitude, or about 240 miles east of Antigua. It was moving north at 10 mph and was expected to hold that course and speed for the next day or two. Gustav had hurricane-force winds extending 35 miles from its center and tropical storm-force winds extending outward 175 miles. Over the weekend, islanders with strong memories of last year's Hurricane Hugo had scrambled to prepare for Gustav's expected onslaught. In Montserrat, a British colony devastated by Hugo, banks, hardware stores, pharmacies and supermarkets opened Sunday. Utilities called workers back from vacation, and the 100-member police and 50-strong volunteer army were fully mobilized. ``The level of preparedness and the level of activity is significantly greater than it was last year'' before Hugo, said Reuben Meade, the government's director of development. ``They are out there in earnest.'' Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Hortense remained about a thousand miles to the east in the mid-Atlantic, a hindrance only to shipping. At noon EDT Monday, Hortense had winds of 45 mph. It was moving north-northwest at about 8 mph. The storm was centered near 19.1 degrees north latitude, 41.8 degrees west longitude, or about 1000 miles west of the Cape Verde Islands of Africa. It wasn't expected to gain strength, but forecasters planned to keep an eye on it. Tropical depressions become tropical storms when their sustained winds reach 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes at 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Little Improvement in Mideast Diplomatic Prospects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines previous and edits throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that he sees little improvement in chances for a diplomatic settlement to the crisis in the Middle East but wished U.N. negotiators well in their effort. ``Saddam Hussein has been so resistant to complying with international law that I don't yet see fruitful negotiations,'' Bush said during a joint news conference with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Bush reiterated U.S. opposition to any agreement that would back away from demands for a complete withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and restoration of the former leadership. Bush said the demand for total Iraqi withdrawal ``is not negotiable.'' ``There is no room for compromise nor negotiation on that point,'' he said. ``There is no flexibility on Iraq getting out of Kuwait and the (former) rulers being permitted to come back,'' Bush declared. ``There's no compromise on the question on getting the legitimate government back and getting the illegitimate invaders out,'' he added. The president also supported his administration's decision to cut by two-thirds the staff of the Iraqi embassy in Washington and to limit the travel of those remaining to no more than 25 miles. He disputed that the action, announced earlier in the day by the State Department, might provoke tensions further. ``Nobody will be held against their will. They're all free to go. We're trying to keep some reasonable parallel in terms of numbers,'' Bush said. Asked if he was more optimistic now than earlier about a diplomatic settlement, Bush said: ``I don't particularly see more hope now... It's so clear that what the world is demanding of Saddam Hussein (is): Get out of Kuwait and restore the rightful leaders to their place.'' The president said he had a call in to UN General Secretary Javier Perez de Cuellar, who will meet with Iraq officials in Jordan on Thursday in a mediation attempt. Bush insisted, however, that the United States would not back down from the UN demand for a full Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. And, he said, ``it's inconceivable that he (Perez de Cuellar) would not have that message'' in his talks. ``It's so clear, it's so obvious.'' He praised Mulroney for its decision to send three ships to the Persian Gulf in support of the trade embargo, despite some earlier Canadian reservations. For his part, Mulroney called Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``a rogue leader ... who sought to annex another nation. And the world turned against him.'' ``We're very pleased with the decision of the United Nations Security Council'' in backing a full naval blockade of Iraq, Mulroney said. Bush and Mulroney spoke to reporters under clear skies outside the president's family vacation complex on the Atlantic Ocean. Mulroney was here for a 24-hour visit. Bush was to return to Washington on Tuesday and will remain in the capital before returning here on Thursday. In other comments, Bush: _ Said he was ``very pleased'' with Soviet support for the UN embargo against Iraq, even though it doesn't include military help. He said he had not yet talked to Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev about recent developments. _ Insisted only a ``tiny minority'' of the Arab world supports ``this outrageous aggression'' by Iraq. ``It's true and everyone knows it's true.'' _ Declared he remains ``on top of the situation'' despite his vacationing. He cited meetings with top aides and his planned return to Washington this week and a previous trip back a week ago. Earlier, the White House said Iraq ``has once again reneged on its pledge'' in refusing to allow a full convoy of dependents of U.S. diplomats to leave the country.

Earlier, the White House said Iraq ``has once again reneged on its pledge'' in refusing to allow a full convoy of dependents of U.S. diplomats to leave the country. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said ``our best estimate'' is that 63 Americans are missing or being held by Iraq, including seven Americans ``known to be picked up over the weekend.'' Fitzwater, speaking in advance of a meeting between Bush and Mulroney, said the president plans to return to Washington on Tuesday and not resume his Maine vacation until Thursday. Mulroney, his wife, Mila, and their three children arrived at Bush's seaside home at noon by helicopter. Fitzwater noted that three members of the convoy of American dependents to reach the Turkish border late Sunday had been detained. Fifty-two others were permitted to leave the country. ``We are disappointed that the Iraqi government has once again reneged on its pledge to allow the entire convoy to depart,'' Fitzwater said. ``We've been in touch with Iraqi officials in Baghdad and Washington and continue to urge the safe release of all Americans and foreign nationals.'' In Washington, U.S. officials said the State Department summoned Iraq's ambassador today and informed him that new restrictions were being imposed on the movement of Iraqi diplomats in the United States. As to what progress this week's talks might produce, Fitzwater said: ``It remains to be seen. We wouldn't want to characterize this effort. ...Certainly we are pleased with the role the U.N. is taking at this point.'' ``We are willing to give it time and continue to pursue the objectives we have in place,'' he added. Fitzwater noted that the United Nations had called for a ``complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Waite Next in Line; Iran Assets Key To Americans
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 8th graf, `Sources close...' to ADD year of Waite's disappearance. Pickup 9th graf, `No group...
DOC.TEXT: A Beirut radio station said Monday that Anglican church envoy Terry Waite would be the next hostage to be freed by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Lebanon. The communist-run Voice of the People also said all six American hostages would be freed once Iran's frozen assets in the United States are released. The station, respected for its balanced reporting and investigative work, said it drew the conclusions from interviews with Iranian and Syrian officials as well as Shiite Moslem leaders after the release of five Western hostages in the past four months. The latest to be freed was Irish teacher Brian Keenan, who was set free Friday and is undergoing medical tests in a Dublin hospital. The first two were Americans Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, freed 10 days apart in April. Swiss orthopedic specialists of the International Committee of the Red Cross, Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez, were released respectively Aug. 8 and 13 after 10 months in captivity. ``Sources familiar with the hostage issue are certain that Terry Waite is the next in line for freedom after Keenan,'' the station said in a 15-minute evaluation of the hostage issue. Waite disappeared after leaving a west Beirut hotel Jan. 20, 1987 for a rendezvous with Islamic Jihad, a group that claims to hold American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. No group has claimed holding the 51-year-old Englishman, from Styal in Cheshire, and none of the freed hostages has mentioned seeing him in captivity. Several Lebanese Shiite leaders lately asserted that Waite was alive and well, which suggests he is being held separately from the 12 other hostages in Lebanon. Keenan said upon his release that he had seen Anderson and British journalist John McCarthy in captivity and that both of them were well. Voice of the People quoted an unnamed source close to the Iranian Embassy in Beirut as saying Waite and other European hostages held in Lebanon would benefit from ``positive stands lately taken by France and Britain toward Iran.'' It did not elaborate. France in July pardoned and freed from prison five members of a pro-Iranian assassination team. The French Foreign Ministry said the release of the Swiss captives may have been a result of that. Britain has recently distanced itself from ``The Satanic Verses,'' a novel by British author Salman Rushdie who is under an Iranian death order for writing the book. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said this monthy his government had no wish to insult Islam and understood that Rushdie's book offended Moslems. Hussein Musavian, director general for West European Affairs at the Iranian Foreign Minstry, said that met conditions set by an Iranian parliamentary ruling last year for resumption of ties with Britain. There are four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian in addition to the six Americans held in Lebanon. The station quoted the unnamed source as saying ``the solution of the question of Iranian frozen assets in the United States will promptly lead to the termination of the plight of the American hostages in Lebanon.'' Mohammad Asfahanian, the Iranian Embassy press officer, denied in the radio program that his government was seeking ``financial or political rewards for its humanitarian efforts'' to gain the release of the hostages. ``We segregate the Iranian efforts to get the frozen assets and our legal rights from the hostages' issue,'' Asfahanian was quoted as saying. The radio station did not attempt to explain the discrepancy between what its anonymous source and the statement by Asfahanian. Iran has an estimated $2 billion of assets frozen in the United States as a result of the 1979 overthrow of the pro-U.S. monarchy in Tehran and the seizure of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Asfahanian said efforts by the West to gain the release of four Iranian diplomats missing in Lebanon since Israel's 1982 invasion would encourage Iran to step up efforts to free the Western hostages. He said Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani's government has lately obtained information that all four missing Iranians are alive, despite assertions by the U.S. government that they were dead. Voice of the People quoted Shiite leader Hussein Musawi, reputed mentor of hostage-holding factions in Lebanon, as saying ``1990 was supposed to be the year of freedom for all Western hostages in Lebanon. ``But the American military intervention in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has lessened the chances of freedom for the American captives in the foreseable future. ``This is the logic of things as they stand now. But if they take an illogical course soon, then it is possible that something contrary to what I am saying could happen,'' Musawi said.

DOC.HEAD: Qatar Joins Other Arab States In Offering Military Facilities
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The state of Qatar on Monday joined other Arab states in the Persian Gulf in making available military facilities to the growing multinational force being deployed to deter any Iraqi attack. The move means that most of the countries in the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council alliance have now agreed to open military facilities to the U.S.-led force. The decision was announced in a statement issued after a meeting of the government and Parliament that was led by the emir. The statement carried by the official Qatar News Agency said only that Qatar ``has agreed to extend military facilities to some friendly countries at their request.'' The emir of Qatar, Sheik Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani, was quoted as citing the ``international unanimity'' represented in today's decision. ``It is Qatar's duty as a GCC state and a member of the Arab League and the joint Arab defense pact, as well as the United Nations, to participate in the Arab and international effort,'' the emir was quoted as saying by the agency. The emir said that the ``consecutive developments in the region required that some sister and friendly states deploy military force in the gulf waters and in the Gulf Cooperation Council member states to help these countries repulse possible aggression.'' Qatar did not specify what military facilities would be made available or which countries would be able to use them. However, the country has traditionally cooperated militarily with Britain and France. Three members of the Gulf Cooperation Council _ Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates _ have already agreed to make military facilities available to the multinational force. Another member, Oman, has a long-standing agreement to make naval facilities available to U.S. and British warships. The remaining member of the gulf alliance is Kuwait, which was invaded and occupied by Iraqi troops Aug. 2. Bahrain agreed to open its air space and air bases to the British Royal Air Force and has extended naval facilities to U.S. and British warships. The United Arab Emirates opened its facilities to ground forces from the United States, Egypt and Pakistan. Saudi Arabia is hosting forces from the United States, Britain, Egypt, Morocco and Syria as well as the gulf alliance as part of the buildup on its soil aimed at detering a possible attack by Iraqi troops massed in Kuwait. The Qatar News Agency said that during Monday's meeting the emir affirmed Qatar's condemnation of the Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait. Qatar has insisted on a full Iraqi withdrawal and the restoration of the Kuwaiti royal family Qatar, with a population of about 250,000, is on a peninsula jutting into the Persian Gulf from the coast of Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Musicians Saddened Over Stevie Ray Vaughan's Death
LaserPhoto NY24; LaserColor NY25
DOC.TEXT: Grammy-winning guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan was remembered upon his death Monday for his rocking Texas roadhouse blues style and his contributions to the music scene here, where he got his musical start. Vaughan, 35, died in a helicopter crash early Monday in Wisconsin after performing with rock star Eric Clapton and guitarist, Robert Cray. ``He was a great musician and a very good friend,'' Cray said. ``I'm shocked at what happened.'' ``He played the blues like he wanted to play to blues, he played and put blues in places that we, even Muddy Waters, didn't do,'' said blues guitarist Buddy Guy, who performed with Vaughn, Cray and Clapton on Sunday. ``We'll miss Stevie and we'll miss his music,'' said Jeff Peterson of the PBS-TV program ``Austin City Limits,'' which has featured Vaughan and his band, Double Trouble. Also killed in the crash near East Troy, Wis., were the pilot and Clapton's agent, a tour manager and a bodyguard. Vaughan, who overcame a drug problem to win two Grammy awards, gained popularity in the middle 1980s with his guitar jamming and blues sound, borrowed from such music legends as B.B. King. ``The loss is a great loss for blues music and all fans of music around the world,'' King said in a statement. ``He was just beginning to be appreciated and develop his potential.'' Vaughan toured this summer with blues singer Joe Cocker and was to release a new record in September with his brother Jimmie, another well-known musician who formed The Fabulous Thunderbirds band. ``This is the worst accident to happen to Texas music since Buddy Holly and the Big Bopper went down in the '50s. It's a void no one can fill,'' said Casey Monahan, director of the Texas Music Office. In 1959, a plane carrying carrying singers J.P. (The Big Bopper) Richardson, Buddy Holly and Richie Valens crashed in Iowa. Holly was from Texas. ``There's not an individual in Austin who's not proud of Stevie and what he's done for us and Austin music. It's tragic for his fans, his family, everybody,'' said Ernie Gammage, head of the Austin Music Industry Council. Vaughan had a platinum album with Double Trouble in ``Couldn't Stand the Weather,'' released in 1984. That same year, he won a Grammy for best traditional blues recording for the song ``Texas Flood.'' It was on a album featuring several blues artists and entitled ``Blues Explosion.'' He won a 1990 Grammy in the contemporary blues category for ``In Step.'' Born Stephen Ray Vaughan on Oct. 3, 1954, in Dallas, he began playing the guitar at age 7, copying his older brother Jimmie. The two had been working on an album for September release called ``Family Style.'' In a recent interview, Jimmie Vaughan recalled Stevie's early interest in music: ``It was my guitar and my records. When I left, I would say, `Don't touch my guitar because I'm going to get you. Leave my guitar alone.' And of course, when I would leave, he would go straight in there and play with my guitar and try to learn what I had been playing.'' At 13, Stevie Ray Vaughan began playing in Dallas clubs before quitting school before his senior year. He moved to Austin in 1972, returning to Dallas in 1986. In addition to his brother, Vaughan is survived by his mother, Martha. A candlelight vigil was planned for Austin's Zilker Park on Monday night. The Hard Rock Cafe in Dallas planned to play his music in tribute all day.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Gather for Citywide Picnic
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: An 84-year-old woman dressed in lavender and lace nibbled pound cake Monday. A tanned, unshaven man wearing a pajama top waited in line for barbecued ribs. It was a picnic for the homeless. There were homemade pies, ribs and potato salad for 1,500 people. Soup kitchens closed their doors and told their regular patrons to head to West Park on the city's North Side for the third annual picnic, sponsored by shelters, hospitals, churches and the Salvation Army. Cecil Johnston, a Salvation Army shelter director, said the picnic offered homeless people a chance ``to experience an event that most of us take for granted.'' The food missions in Pittsburgh usually serve 750 people per day, Johnston said. The elderly woman in a lace blouse and well-combed brown wig, who would identify herself only as Marlene, said she lost her home in April after the friends she lived with died. Since then, she's been living in a shelter, far from her birth place on a Tennessee farm. Because of high blood pressure, her balance is unsteady and she skinned her knees and one hand when she fell on a sidewalk two weeks ago. ``So now I use an umbrella to help me get up,'' Marlene said. ``I'm going to die pretty soon,'' she said without expression. Another woman wanted to make sure she wouldn't be photographed as she waited for the food to arrive. ``I come to the picnic because of a lack of funds and no home. I'm going to try to enjoy myself. It's a good thing for homeless people,'' said the woman, who identified herself as Loloma. ``I don't mind being quoted in the newspaper, but I don't want my picture taken because I'm not on the most-wanted list.'' Smoke rose from two grills where barbecue sauce was basted on ribs, burgers, and hot dogs. Tables of salads and pies were set up under the trees near long tables where neatly dressed men, women and a handful of children sat. Under a tree, a man in a brown shirt and green pants was slumped over, quivering, flailing and foaming at the mouth. Two other homeless men looked on, and a picnicker sitting next to the seizure victim chowed down impassively. Joseph Richards, 24, sought help from police for the man. ``Why don't they build more shelters for people to stay in?'' he asked. He said he considered petty crimes so he could get arrested and get a bed for the night. ``I'd be in jail, but I least I'd be getting three meals a day,'' he said. Light of Life shelter chef Lorenzo Johnson said the city could use 1,000 more beds. Instead, people end up sleeping on grates, in cardboard boxes and sprawled out in the park. Not everyone enjoyed the gathering. ``The Salvation Army just gets money from it,'' said a weathered-looking David Ferneza, who said he had been accused of dealing drugs in Erie. ``It's just a bunch of lies like always.'' But despite the complaints, volunteer Ken Keith, who spooned coleslaw onto plates, said he enjoyed helping out. ``Somebody's got to help feed the homeless.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Retaliates Against Iraq _ Expels Diplomats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs `No deadline ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Iraqis given 72 hours to leave
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Monday ordered the expulsion of 36 members of the Iraqi Embassy staff and imposed strict travel limits on the 19 envoys allowed to remain. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the move came in response to the ``illegal order'' by Iraqi authorities to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. The State Department has refused to comply with that order. The 19 Iraqis permitted to remain in the United States, including Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat, reflects the same number of Americans accredited to the U.S. embassies in Iraq and Kuwait. At a news conference at his Maine vacation home, President Bush said the United States was ``trying to keep a reasonable parallel in terms of numbers.'' He also noted that although many Americans cannot leave Iraq or Kuwait, Iraqis in this country won't be detained. ``Nobody will be held against their will,'' Bush said. ``They're all free to go.'' The expelled Iraqis were given 72 hours to leave the country, a U.S. official said. Among those expelled are seven accredited diplomats, including all those who deal with commercial affairs. Diplomats at Iraq's U.N. mission in New York City are not affected by the order. ``I don't think it was warranted or called for,'' Sami Jabbouri of the Iraqi Embassy press office here said about the explusion order. ``It is just part of the nerve war by the U.S. authorities because they don't want a solution.'' Ms. Tutwiler said the Iraqi diplomats allowed to remain in the United States will be restricted to travel within a 25-mile radius of Washington. In addition, all Iraqi diplomatic visas will be changed from multiple entry to single entry, tighter controls will be imposed on unofficial Iraqis wishing to visit the United States and use of Iraqi Embassy funds for students and other humanitarian needs will be ``closely controlled,'' she said. The move follows by three days the Iraqi deadline for closing the U.S. Embassy and other foreign missions in Kuwait. Ms. Tutwiler said that order was in ``brazen defiance'' of mandatory U.N. Security Council resolutions. Iraqi authorities have cut off water and electricity at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and are restricting all personnel to the embassy grounds. Ms. Tutwiler said the reduced U.S. embassy staff in Kuwait has enough food and water only to last several more days. Power is being supplied by a generator. The United States has refused to close its embassy in Kuwait because it does not want to lend legitimacy to Iraq's conquest and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Seven more Americans were taken by Iraqi authorities into custody over the weekend, bringing the total to 63 _ 42 in Iraq and 21 in Kuwait, Ms. Tutwiler said. She said that Iraq has repeatedly failed to provide U.S. officials with a list of those Americans in their custody and consular access to them, calling that a clear violation of international law. Ms. Tutwiler preceded her announcement of the expulsions with a ringing denunciation of Iraq's recent behavior. ``Since its brutal aggression against Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iraq has demonstrated a blatant disregard for international law and the norms of civilized society through a series of acts,'' she said. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger apprised Al-Mashat of the U.S. actions at a morning meeting at the State Department. Ms. Tutwiler said the United States was urging other governments, particularly those whose embassies have been affected by Iraqi actions in Kuwait, to consider taking similar actions against Iraq's official and non-official presence in their countries. She said representatives 34 other countries that are trying to maintain embassies in Kuwait were invited to a rare State Department meeting late Sunday night for a briefing on the U.S. action against Iraq. In another matter, Ms. Tutwiler said the department was unable to confirm reports that Iraq had decided to allow its ships to be boarded for inspection. ``We certainly hope they are true because that is obviously a very peaceful way to go about enforcing this embargo,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Army Reserve unit of attorneys and paralegals with expertise in international law reported to active duty Monday, a spokesman at Hanscom Air Force Base said. The nine-member unit is the 46th Judge Advocate General Detachment comprising six lawyers and three paralegals, including two women. They were called up Saturday and told to report Monday to their unit's headquarters in Boston, Reserves spokesman John Prowse said. Prowse said he didn't know whether the detachment would remain in Boston or be sent overseas as part of the troop buildup in the Persian Gulf. On Friday, two Army National Guard units in Massachusetts were put on alert status but not given a time or place to report for duty, said 1st Lt. David Guido, spokesman for the Massachusetts National Guard in Reading. Those units are the Hingham-based 1058th Transportation Company, which drives and maintains 5-ton vehicles for moving cargo and troops. The other is the Reading-based 704th Transportation Detachment based at Camp Curtis Guild, a traffic coordination unit.

A Lebanese-American man and his 8-year-old son returned to Massachusetts after dodging automatic gunfire while crossing the desert out of Kuwait. Bassam Mohtady, 34, and his son, Sammer, of Saugus, were among about 3,000 Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait since Saddam Hussein's troops invaded Aug. 2. They ended their journey Sunday at Logan International Airport here. Mohtady, who was in Kuwait to manage an office for his company, World Book Inc., said he and other foreigners met and made plans to leave the country together on Aug. 16. ``We started out with 21 cars and we only made it with six,'' Mohtady told reporters at the airport. ``So you can imagine what happened to the rest of them. We have no idea.'' Mohtady said that his caravan was 12 miles from the Saudi Arabia border when Iraqi troops appeared. ``We had a couple of machine guns that came on us. We did not get a direct hit,'' Mohtady said. ``But we got the return (ricochets) of the shells and it blasted the glass of the jeep. ``And some other people got stuck there. I think they got a direct hit. We don't know what happened to them,'' said Mohtady. ``We ran. We panicked and we ran.'' Sammer went to Kuwait to visit his father in July. The youngster said he understood the danger of their escape, but was not afraid. ``I kind of figured the war out by myself. It was fun,'' said Sammer, a third-grader at Waybright School in Saugus. Mohtady said his son ducked down in the jeep during the shooting and both escaped injury. He said the drive to the border is usually a two-hour trip, but their route through the desert took about 10{ hours because of sand traps. He said being in Kuwait after the invasion was like being a hostage. ``We were hostages, somehow. Our freedom was taken away from us,'' he said. ``We could not move around ... couldn't do anything.'' Mohtady, who is of Lebanese decent but has U.S. citizenship, said he and his son were not harassed by Iraqi troops while they were in Kuwait because he had secured Lebanese passports for both of them. Once in Saudi Arabia, Mohtady said the Kuwaiti Embassy provided him and his son a hotel room. The U.S. Consulate there provided them with airplane tickets back to Massachusetts, he said.

The families of several soldiers dispatched to the Persian Gulf have begun turning to each other for support. ``We need people to talk to. We need to know there are others with children over there,'' said Kathy Collier, whose son Darrin, 24, told her in a telephone call that he was shipping out. Collier organized a meeting last weekend with eight other people who also have family members in the Persian Gulf. They gathered at a home displaying an American flag and huge yellow ribbon on the garage door. ``It's a little different to know that when President Bush said he's drawing a line in the sand in Saudi Arabia, these are the kids he's drawing the line with,'' said Ronnie Muir of Fullerton, whose son Robert, 20, is with the U.S. Army 82nd Airborne Division. At Sunday's meeting, people read letters they had received from overseas and spoke of their last contacts with family members being deployed. ``It's a scary feeling. Let's face it, you can be as macho as you want to be. But these are our kids,'' said Bob Archuletta of Garden Grove. His 27-year-old son, Robert, is among troops dispatched in the standoff that started when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The group is planning a public meeting Sept. 9 at the Crescent Baptist Church in Anaheim. In an effort to stir up support, group members also intend to distribute yellow ribbons with the insignia of military units in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria Cracks Down After Protesters Burn Socialist Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with rally, quotes, attack called planned, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SOF17
DOC.TEXT: About 20,000 supporters of the governing Socialist Party, the former Communist Party, rallied Monday night near their burned party headquarters. Their leader blamed ``hawks'' in the opposition for the arson. About 4,000 opposition supporters standing some distance away from the rally occasionally whistled in derision, but no incidents occurred. Anti-Communist demonstrators ransacked the building in downtown Sofia and set it afire Sunday night, incensed by the red star _ the symbol of Communist, one-party rule _ atop the building. The blaze wrecked left much of the building and damaged adjoining structures. Flames licked at the top story of the sprawling eight-floor granite structure, the largest in Sofia. The fire was put out shortly after 3 a.m. Monday, about five hours after it began. Police on Monday were told to use truncheons and tear gas if necessary to prevent further violence. Hundreds of officers guarded the party headquarters. Maj. Gen. Parvan Rusinov, deputy chief of Sofia's police force, said 39 people were arrested after the attack. He said most had criminal records. He also said 17 people were injured, including two policemen. State radio said vandals attacked the building before the fire, and looters carried off television sets and computers. The Socialist Party is made up of reform Communists who renamed themselves earlier this year. They retained the headquarters and became the only former Communist Party in Eastern Europe to win multiparty elections after the region's democratic upheaval. The party promised last week to remove red stars and other Communist symbols after an anti-Communist activist threatened to set himself on fire in protest. But the symbols remained. Most windows in the badly burned building were shattered. Debris and charred paper and pictures were strewn on the sidwalks outside. Petar Beron, chairman of the 16-party opposition Union of Democratic Forces, condemned the vandalism and blamed ``irresponsible elements.'' Socialist Party leader Alexander Lilov said in a statement to reporters that ``extremely reactionary forces,'' including ``the hawks that are among the opposition,'' masterminded the attack. Lilov later said on TV that the arson was planned well in advance, as shown by the attackers' leaving behind a ground plan of the building, iron bars and other implements. Maj. Gen. Rusinov said the Organization for Civil Disobedience, a group close to the opposition coalition, took the initiative for the arson. The official also quoted Kostantin Trenchev, chief of the opposition Podkrepa trade union, as demanding on Sunday that the red star be removed ``or else the building would be stormed,'' the state BTA news agency reported. Rusinov said the ``storming'' was announced by megaphone at 9:50 p.m., 10 minutes after an ultimatum by Trenchev expired. He did not say who made the announcement. The Podkrepa union is part of the Union of Democratic Forces, the second strongest force in Parliament with 144 of the 400 seats. The Socialists won 211 seats in June elections. Beron called the arson a ``blow against democracy'' and said Trenchev would have to answer both to security organizations and the opposition coalition's leadership. President Zhelyu Zhelev, who led the Union of Democratic Forces in the elections, said over radio and TV that the vandalism ``disgraces the young democracy'' and said thwe arsonists benefited ``those who want the establishment of a new dictatorship.'' The large crowd at Monday's rally indicated the attack may have boosted the flagging image of the Socialist Party, rent by dissension and its popularity eroding as the economy deteriorates. Lilov told the chanting crowd the party's Supreme Council will meet in the damaged premises Tuesday ``because we have no other building.'' He began a fund-raising drive to repair the headquarters. The crowd chanted ``Never, never!'' when speaker after speaker conjured up the specter of an emerging ``neo-fascism'' in Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Little Hope for UN Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with detail. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he sees little hope for ``fruitful negotiations'' in the United Nations-sponsored search for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. He also said it was inconceivable that U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will make concessions to Iraq. Asked if he was more optimistic than he had been about a diplomatic settlement, Bush said: ``I don't particularly see more hope now because it's so clear that what the world is demanding of Saddam Hussein. Clearly, the objective remains the same _ get (Saddam) out of Kuwait and restore the rightful leaders to their place.'' Bush ruled out any settlement that did not fulfill those goals. The president also said he didn't believe his sanctions against Iraq's embassy in Washington would worsen the situation because ``nobody will be held against their will.'' ``They're free to go,'' unlike U.S. diplomats being detained in Baghdad and Kuwait, Bush said. The Iraqi diplomats allowed to stay in the United States will be restricted in their travel to a 25-mile radius of Washington. As to what kind of latitude Perez de Cuellar might exercise in his talks with the Iraqis, which begin Thursday, Bush said: ``There is no flexibility on Iraq getting out of Kuwait and the rulers (of Kuwait) being permitted to come back. ``Saddam Hussein has been so resistant to complying with international law that I don't yet see fruitful negotiations,'' Bush told reporters at a joint news conference with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney at the president's seaside vacation home. However, he said, if Perez de Cuellar could make progress in getting the Iraqis out of Kuwait, ``so much the better,'' ``The United Nations' position is not negotiable,'' Bush said. ``There is no room for compromise on getting the legitimate government back and the illegitimate invaders out.'' The administration has taken a restrained view of Perez de Cuellar's mediation initiative. Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters earlier Monday that ``it remains to be seen'' whether the talks are likely to offer a promising resolution of the crisis. The United Nations condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, called for Iraqi troops to withdraw and endorsed an economic embargo against Iraq to be enforced militarily if needed. Bush praised Mulroney for sending three Navy vessels to support the multinational forces, led by the United States' massive buildup, in the gulf. Bush also pointedly praised the Soviet Union for its compliance with the international sanctions against Iraq. Mulroney, calling Saddam a ``rogue leader,'' said the Canadian government considers its military response acceptable at this point but has not decided whether to beef up the Canadian presence in the gulf. The prime minister, one of Bush's closest international friends, said the president should get credit for ``remarkable political leadership'' that led to the condemnation of Iraq by Arab and Western nations. Bush also said there was no reason to think that because he has remained on vacation he's not at the helm of U.S. policy in the crisis. ``We're on top of the situation,'' he said. ``I think the American people understand that.'' Bush returns to Washington Tuesday to brief members of key congressional committees and the leadership on his Persian Gulf strategy. The White House said Monday that the planned one-day visit would be extended to Thursday afternoon to encompass a range of meetings on budget and other matters. Bush continued his vacation activities Monday, up at dawn to fish in the Kennebunk River as onlookers gathered on the mosquito-infested banks. The president arrived from a boating expedition in his speedboat just moments before Mulroney's helicopter arrived. Mulroney brought his wife, Mila, and three children for a repeat visit of their stay with the Bushes last summer.

DOC.HEAD: Student Don't Like Education, So They Don't Pay $2 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Defaults on student loans will cost taxpayers nearly $2 billion this year, and a major reasons given by people who welsh on debt is that they are out of work, the Education Department said Monday. Many said they simply didn't like the education they got, the department said. ``Unemployed and without income'' was cited more than any other reason, slightly ahead of ``working, but insufficient funds,'' the department said in an 80-page booklet called ``Reducing Student Loan Defaults: A plan for action.'' ``Behind the default statistics are students who are either unable or unwilling to repay their loans,'' says Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos in the introduction. ``Many of the defaults could have been prevented if everyone involved in student loans _ students, post-secondary institutions, lenders, guarantee agencies and the federal and state governments _ had worked together,'' the report says. Many defaulters are confused about the loan process and their repayment responsibilities, the booklet says. Its first recommendation is that colleges and trade schools counsel borrowers on their responsibilities to repay the loans ``even if they do not complete the program or believe they benefited from the program.'' A student leaving school or dropping out, should be contacted immediately and the need for repaying the loan should be emphasized, the department said. The second recommendation is working closely with lenders to reduce defaults, including notifying the lender when a student can't be located to allow banks to begin tracing. One major reason for defaults, the department found, is the student's unhappiness with the education he is offered and reluctance to pay. The percentage is particularly high at proprietary schools _ such as trade schools. Schools should strengthen their curriculum, beef up the quality of their faculties and update facilities and equipment, the department report recommends. It also calls for improved programs to keep students in school because many of the defaulters ``are ill-equipped to find employment later and do not have the means to repay their loans.'' The book is not intended for students. It is being sent to higher education associations, lenders and guarantee agencies and includes examples of the way organizations have used interesting and innovative approaches to reduce defaults. The total of student loan defaults is $7.8 billion, of which $1.9 billion was added last year. In the current fiscal year the program will lend $11 billion to 4.1 million students. ``If defaults were a separate program, it would be the fastest-growing program in the Department of Education today,'' the booklet says. The department has stepped up its efforts, including use of legal actions and private collection agencies, increasing its collections this year to $637 million.

DOC.HEAD: Fidelity Fails Free World Leaders
With AM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House said it was nothing like a rescue at sea and there was no real danger to the leaders of the United States and Canada. But there may have been a bit of chagrin on the part of George Bush when his prized speedboat, Fidelity the Cigarette boat, konked out on the high seas with Brian Mulroney aboard. Bush and his wife Barbara took the visiting Canadian prime minister and his wife Mila for a spin on the ocean following the joint Bush-Mulroney news conference Monday. No sooner had they sped away from the Bush compound on Walker's Point, however, when Fidelity suffered an ``alternator burnout,'' according to a written report from the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. ``Thus the boat was unable to operate,'' the statement said. The boaters were transferred to the Coast Guard boat that trails along when Bush is out on the water. ``There was no need for any special rescue of emergency equipment. ``There was never any danger to the president or the prime minister. ``Fidelity is being towed back to Walker's Point,'' Fitzwater reported. There was no word on future employment for the boat mechanic.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Threats, Employer Relents on Reservist Firing
DOC.TEXT: A suburban apartment manager on Monday reversed his decision to lay off a maintenance man who volunteered for active duty as an Army reservist. While picking up his paycheck last week, Sgt. Charles Mack's sister found a termination slip saying her brother had been ``laid off due to being placed on volunteer active military duty for an indefinite amount of time.'' A member of the 450th Ordnance Company based in Aiken, S.C., Mack responded to a call for active duty volunteers at Fort Bragg, N.C., on Aug. 16. Unless his tour is extended, he is due back in Georgia on Friday. The layoff notice said the Norcross apartment complex would rehire Mack ``if a position was available'' at that time. But federal law guarantees reservists an unpaid leave of absence for military duty and re-employment ``with their seniority, status and pay rate upon return to be as if they were never absent,'' said Maj. Austin Smith of the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve. He said that holds true whether the reservist volunteers or is called up. The apartment complex manager, James Bell, said Monday he didn't know the law when he issued the pink slip. He said the employer support committee had now explained the requirements and he would abide by them. The employer support committee intercedes in reservist-employer conflicts, and the U.S. Department of Labor helps reservists take such cases to court if employers don't relent. Only 3 percent of the cases ever wind up in court, said Jim Bishop, a veterans programs specialist with the Labor Department. Smith said this is the first reservist firing he has heard of since reserve units were placed on alert for the Persian Gulf crisis. Bell initially said he had fired Mack, but later retracted the statement. ``He was temporarily laid off,'' he said. ``I can't just shut my business down. I had to hire people to fill in. It's not like I cast him out in a briar patch with no recourse. He is doing a very honorable service to serve his country.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Jet Fighter Tries to Defect to U.S., But Lands in Russia
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese fighter pilot who was trying to defect to the United States was spotted after he flew into Soviet airspace and was forced to land at a military airfield at Vladivostok, Soviet media reported Monday. No word surfaced on whether the Soviets would return the pilot or the jet to China. Nor was anything said about the pilot's intended destination if he wanted to ask for U.S. political asylum. The Chinese-made MiG-19 fighter was flying at an altitude of only 100 feet on Sunday, but it was detected as soon as it crossed the Soviet border and was intercepted by Soviet air defense forces, Col. Gen. Vladimir Litvinov told the government newspaper Izvestia. Izvestia said the pilot, who was not identified, flew deep into Soviet territory in the Far East. He passed over the landing strip at Vladivostok Airport without responding to calls from an air traffic controller, then changed course and landed at the military field using a braking parachute. Litvinov said the pilot's first request after landing was for food. After he was fed, he was turned over to investigators, the general said. A KGB spokesman told Izvestia the circumstances of the flight were unclear. `It has been established, however, that the Chinese pilot was motivated by political considerations and intended to go to the United States,'' Izvestia said.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Tensions Spark Call To Duty For Some
DOC.TEXT: With the Mideast in turmoil, military recruiters say they're getting lots of calls from patriotic citizens, many of them old soldiers or fresh-faced boys ineligible to wear a uniform and carry a gun. But they call anyway, eager to serve. ``The majority of them aren't eligible, just because of age,'' said Sgt. 1st Class Robert Maydoney, an Army recruiter in Providence. R.I. ``But we get a lot of Vietnam vets, Korean vets, a lot of old-timers who want to help.'' A 54-year-old Korean War veteran called ``asking if he could get back in. He felt it was important, with what was going on,'' Maydoney said. Most of the interest seems directed at the Army, which accepts recruits from age 17 to 35. Air Force, Navy and Marine officials reported little change in the number of would-be recruits since Iraq invaded Kuwait and thousands of U.S. troops were deployed to the Persian Gulf. ``Absolutely we've been getting more calls,'' said Sgt. First Class Rick Henager, an Army recruiter in Hyannis. ``We're talking about an increase of 1,000 percent on some days.'' On his busiest day since the crisis began, Henager said, he got 23 or 24 call, compared to the two or three he gets on a normal day. Henager took a call from a young man who had won a four-year college scholarship but wanted to be a medic in the Middle East if war broke out. ``He said, `Look, I'm all set with my education. But if we do go to war I want to be a part of it.' Another kid said, `I've lived in this country 19 years. It's time I started helping with the rent.' '' First Sgt. Bengt Bernhardsen is in charge of 12 Army recruiting stations in the New York City boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, the largest such Army unit on the East Coast. He said he received 10 to 15 calls a day ``from all walks of life, all age groups, asking about joining the military.'' ``It has really surprised me. It's nice to see patriotism hasn't died. It's alive and living in New York,'' he said. In Louisville, Ky., one of the busiest booths at this year's Kentucky State Fair was the National Guard display. At past fairs, the booth got about 100 inquiries, said Army Sgt. 1st Class Ray Jones, a recruiter for the Army Reserve. ``This year, we've had 250 to 300 leads ... possible recruits,'' he said. The 11-day fair ended Sunday. Americans haven't cornered the market on patriotism. A U.S. Marine recruiting office in Buffalo, N.Y., is getting about five calls a day from Canadians wanting tough Marine training. ``It's kind of sad because we're getting more Canadians calling than we are getting American kids,'' said Sgt. John Taylor. In Pittsburgh, recruiters said nurses' interest in joining the Navy increased after troops went to the Middle East. ``We have seen quite a bit of interest from people who want to serve, particularly nurses,'' said Navy Lt. Cmdr. Shannah Hensler said. ``And just walking down the street, we get a lot of favorable comments from civilians.'' Still, many who feel the call of duty simply can't serve. ``Before this started only about 10 percent of the people who wanted to enlist could enlist,'' Henager said. ``Of the ones calling in now it's probably less than 10 percent who are eligible.'' Maydoney said it wasn't easy telling would-be warriors they couldn't fight. ``A lot of them can't understand it, they feel they can still give something to their country,'' Maydoney said. ``They say, `Well maybe I can't be an infantryman but maybe I can train someone else.'''

DOC.HEAD: Hot Day In Central States, Thunderstorms In Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain extended over the South on Monday and from the northern Plains to New England, and a heat wave hit the central part of the nation. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from eastern North Dakota into northwestern Minnesota, over southeastern Wisconsin, across Pennsylvania, northern New Jersey and New York state into New England. North Dakota had hail as big as golf balls at Akra, Cavalier and near Walhalla. In southeastern New York state, wind gusts during thunderstorms damaged power lines and a tree near Monroe, the National Weather Service reported. Some trees also were downed in the New York City borough of Queens. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, southern Mississippi, and southeastern Louisiana. Elsewhere, rain spread from northwestern California into southwestern Oregon. The weather service reported noon heat indexes _ a combination of temperature and humidity _ of 108 at Kirksville, Mo., and Quincy, Ill.; 106 at Columbia, Mo.; 104 at St. Louis, Mo.; 103 at Cape Girardeau, Mo.; 101 at Springfield, Mo., and Sioux Falls, S.D.; and 100 at Kansas City, Mo. Record high temperatures included 104 at Austin, Texas; 98 at Corpus Christi, Texas; 96 at Galveston, Texas; and 104 at North Platte, Neb. Lake Charles, La., tied its record of 98 and Wichita, Kan., tied its record of 102. The high at Galveston toppled a record that had been on the books since 1884. Some schools in eastern Nebraska closed early or didn't open at all as the state entered the fifth day of a heat wave expected to last through the week. Bakersfield, Calif., cooled to a record-tying low of 56. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 61 at Kalispell, Mont., to 104 at Medicine Lodge, Kan., and Wichita, Kan. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 29 at Jackson, Wyo., and West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: President Answers Critics, Refuses To Resign
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot refused Monday to heed calls for her resignation and said elections set for November would be held as scheduled. Seven of the 12 political groups that in March appointed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot provisional president have called for her resignation and said they would refuse to participate in elections under her administration. Five Cabinet ministers also resigned last week. ``I will not fail to assume all the way to the end the responsibility'' of holding elections, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said at the installation of her newly constituted 13-member Cabinet. ``No one can believe that deviations from the will of the people'' can halt the electoral process, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said in a speech broadcast on state radio. The seven parties have also declared support for the Council of State, which broke off relations with the president Aug. 14, describing her as an obstacle to credible elections. The 19-member Council of State, which is supposed to have veto power over Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, has accused her of abuse of power and of refusing to satisfy popular demands for administrative reform, law and order and economic relief. On Saturday, the Chamber of Commerce and several other business groups asked the president to ``postpone any decision which requires the approval of the Council of State'' so as not to aggravate the crisis. The new Cabinet was appointed without the council's advice and consent. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court judge, was appointed president by a political coalition known as the Unity Assembly, which spearheaded opposition to Haiti's last military ruler, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. He fled into exile in the United States in March after a week of violent protests. Although seven of the 12 groups that comprise the Unity Assembly are now calling for her resignation, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said the five most important groups remained on her side. ``We must note with satisfaction that important political groups, representative of the majority of the electorate,'' are on the election trail. Those who refuse elections are ``on the periphery of reality,'' she said. Haiti, an impoverished Caribbean nation of 6 million inhabitants, has had five different governments since the fall of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier in February 1986. Four of the governments have been led or controlled by the ill-disciplined army, which is widely accused of corruption. The current civilian administration was set up to lead the country to its first democratic elections since independence from France in 1804. Haiti tried to hold free and fair elections on Nov. 29, 1987, but the elections were canceled after assassins supported by the army massacred at least 34 voters at polling stations.

DOC.HEAD: Morley Callaghan, Canadian Author, Dies at 87
DOC.TEXT: Funeral services will be held in Toronto on Wednesday for Canadian novelist and short story writer Morley Callaghan, who died over the weekend after undergoing surgery four weeks earlier. He was 87. His sons Barry, also an author, and Michael were at his side when he died Saturday. The nature of his illness was not disclosed. Callaghan's wife died six years ago. Callaghan's writings spanned more than 60 years. Besides winning acclaim at home, his works were well received in Western Europe, the Soviet Union, Bulgaria and Romania, and wered translated into Chinese. After his graduatuation from law school in 1928, Callaghan got married and headed straight for Paris with his bride. He mixed with Ernest Hemingway, Scott Fitzgerald, James Joyce, Ezra Pound and other literary figures there and in 1928 saw ``Strange Fugitive,'' the first of his more than 20 novels, published. His novel ``The Loved and the Lost'' won Canada's 1952 Governor General's Award. Callaghan was also nominated for a Nobel Prize in literature. His other novels include ``A Native Argosy,'' ``Now that April's Here,'' ``Stories,'' ``They Shall Inherit the Earth,'' ``The Many Colored Coat,'' ``A Passion in Rome,'' ``A Fine and Private Place,'' ``Philo of Crete,'' and ``A Wild Old Man on The Road.'' He also lived in New York and on a Pennsylvania farm, writing for many American magazines, but returned to Toronto as the birthplace and home he never forgot.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says Cuba Has Seized Tons of U.S.-Bound Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Cuban President Fidel Castro said Monday his country has seized 6,000 tons of U.S.-bound cocaine and arrested more than 400 foreign drug traffickers over the past five years, the Mexican news agency Notimex reported. Castro spoke at the opening of a U.N.-sponsored conference on crime prevention held in Havana, the Cuban capital. Notimex said Castro told the conference that Cuba is studying harsher penalties against drug traffic. Cuban Justice Minister Juan Escalona recently said Cuba might impose a death penalty on foreigners convicted of drug crimes on the island. He said most of those arrested have been U.S. citizens of Cuban descent. Castro said that since 1985, Cuba has seized more than 125 tons of marijuana, as well as the 6,000 tons of U.S.-bound cocaine, and arrested more than 400 foreign drug traffickers. The report did not give any further detail about the accused drug traffickers. Castro said the country has confiscated 73 boats and more than 50 airplanes used to transport drugs. Notimex quoted the Cuban leader as saying his country is willing to cooperate with the United Nations to combat drug traffic. But he said it was essential to solve the problem of drug consumption in United States. Cuba is sometimes used as a waystation by drug traffickers shipping products from South America to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gives Green Light To TV Marti
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday the Voice of America television station aimed at Cuban viewers has passed a five-month preliminary test and will become a permanent operation. That means Cubans who get up early enough to watch the pre-dawn programming and whose television reception escapes Cuban jamming efforts will be able to watch the news, movies and shows such as ``Cheers'' and ``Mission Impossible.'' Bush's announcement releases $16 million that had been withheld pending a presidential determination that the operation was both legal and technically feasible. The station, called TV Marti, has been broadcasting news and entertainment shows on a trial basis since March 27. Cuba has jammed the broadcasts since the first day and has said that effort has been virtually 100 per cent successful. The TV Marti signal is sent from a balloon tethered over the Florida keys. TV Marti airs from 3:30 a.m. to 6 a.m. each day. The broadcasts are timed so that they do not interfere with local programming. U.S. officials said that to do otherwise would violate international regulations. In the announcement, made public at Bush's vacation retreat in Kennebunkport, Maine, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the testing period demonstrated that TV Marti did not interfere with Florida television broadcasting and did not violate international telecommunications agreements. Cuban President Fidel Castro has denounced TV Marti as illegal and a ``gross interference'' in Cuba's internal affairs. A survey commissioned by the U.S. Information Agency, which oversees TV Marti, said polls of Cuban emigres indicated there were about 273,000 households in the station's target area which ``should be able'' to receive broadcasts at least occasionally. But an unpublished report by the General Accounting Office, a congressional watchdog agency, said the administration ``vastly overestimated'' TV Marti viewership. A copy of the report was obtained last week by the Miami Herald, which said classified State Department estimates indicate the viewership is only about 50,000 to 70,000. According to the Herald, the GAO faulted the administration for its methodology in obtaining the viewership estimates. Most of those polled were Cubans who have emigrated since TV Marti went on the air five months ago. Fitzwater said in his announcement that the rationale for TV Marti is that it provides free access to information for people who are denied that right. The statement regretted the Cuban jamming effort but said the experience of U.S. government sponsored broadcasts to Eastern Europe during the Cold War era was that attempts at jamming often were ineffectual. The Voice of America has been beaming radio broadcasts tailored for Cuban audiences since 1985. Cuba began jamming the operation, known as Radio Marti, in the Havana area shortly after the TV Marti tests began.

DOC.HEAD: SATs Sink for Third Straight Year; Verbal Scores Lowest in a Decade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CLARIFY that tests were administered in the 1989-90 school year.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Warning that reading could become a ``lost art'' among high school students, the College Board reported Monday that SAT scores sank for the third consecutive year. Verbal averages dropped to their lowest levels in a decade. Scores on the verbal section of the Scholastic Aptitude Test in the 1989-90 school year fell 3 points to 424 _ the lowest since 1980 and equal to the lowest levels since annual averages were first compiled in 1971. Scores on the math section averaged 476, unchanged for the fourth straight year. The steady, four-year slide in verbal scores from a recent peak of 431 in 1986 is ``disturbing but not particularly surprising,'' said College Board president Donald M. Stewart. ``Students must pay less attention to videogames and music videos and begin to read more.'' Blame for the poor verbal scores rests with parents and schools, Stewart said in an interview. ``The requirement to read through homework has been reduced. Students don't read as much because they don't have to read as much,'' he said. ``Reading is in danger of becoming a lost art among too many American students _ and that would be a national tragedy.'' Among the few bright spots in the gloomy report: Women's math scores reached their best levels in 16 years, scores of American Indians rose a combined 13 points, and black test-takers continued a 15-year trend as the most improved ethnic group. The SAT, taken by 1.03 million college-bound high school students, is a two-part multiple-choice exam, each scored on a scale of 200-800. It is sponsored by the College Board, and administered by the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J. It is the predominant college entrance exam in 22 states. Scores on the ACT, the college entrance test that predominates in 28 states mainly in the Midwest and West, will be released Sept. 11. The SAT has become the single most often-cited barometer of the nation's educational progress, or lack of it. This year's scores and the stagnation in student achievement that they suggest will almost certainly fuel public doubts about the success of the decade-old school reform movement. But the College Board and others caution that no single number can reasonably summarize the performance of 40 million students attending 83,000 public schools across the country. Critics also have repeatedly accused the SAT and ACT of bias against women and minorities. The tests' makers deny those charges.
