But the SAT is undergoing a massive revision that ETS says should produce a fairer, more accurate gauge of college aptitude by 1993. Among the report's other findings: _ The higher a student's family income, the higher the average score. Test-takers from 151,485 families earning $70,000 or more averaged 468 on the verbal, 527 on math. The 41,845 test-takers from families earning less than $10,000 averaged 357 in verbal, 419 math. _ Women's math scores rose a point to their highest average in 16 years: 455. _ American Indians scored the best year-to-year gains of any ethnic group: a 4-point gain in verbal averages to 388, and a 9-point rise in math to 437. _ Verbal scores among black students rose by 1 point to 352 and now stand 20 points higher than 1976 levels. Math averages were down a point to 385, but are still 31 points better than 1976 scores. _ Averages among white students dropped 4 points on verbal scores to 442, and were unchanged at 491 in math. _ Non-white students now constitute 27 percent of all SAT test-takers, up from 25 percent in 1989 and 17 percent in 1980. _ Iowa posted the highest state average, a combined 1088 on the verbal and math. But only 5 percent of high school graduates took it. _ South Carolina, where 54 percent took the test, had the lowest average _ 834. The College Board is a private, nonprofit membership organization based in New York representing over 2,700 colleges, universities, secondary schools and other educational associations.

DOC.HEAD: Five Permanent Security Council Members Begin Talks on Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the Security Council opened private talks Monday aimed at breaking an impasse in efforts to end Cambodia's 11-year-old civil war. The permanent council members _ the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France _ are discussing a formula for establishing a multiparty transitional Cambodian administration that would organize free elections after a cease-fire, said a U.S. official, speaking privately. The transitional administration, or Supreme National Council, would work with U.N. agencies and officials in organizing the elections, the official said. Diplomats from the five nations were expected to brief U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Tuesday on the outcome of their discussions. They were also expected to consult with representatives of Vietnam and the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, as well as with officials from other countries in the region. Richard Solomon, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs, was leading the U.S. delegation in the private talks. In Bangkok, Thailand, a U.S. official said he expected that the five permanent council members would propose a new formula for the composition of the Supreme National Council in an effort to break the latest impasse in peace talks. Alexander Watson, U.S. permanent representative to the United Nations, said he expected that the permanent council members would propose that the Supreme National Council be comprised of people chosen in their individual capacities rather than as representatives of specific Cambodian factions. ``That's an effort obviously to avoid endless squabbles over which factions are represented by how many people (and) in which way,'' Watson said after talks with Thai officials. He was in Thailand on a six-nation Asian trip. ``This is a historic moment,'' Watson said. ``Never have all the pieces been in place like they are now for a real shot at getting a solution to the problem.'' The Vietnamese-backed Cambodian government and the three guerrilla groups opposing it have argued over how many seats each of the factions should have on the Supreme National Council. The guerrilla coalition comprises the Khmer Rouge, which has the strongest guerrilla army, the forces of former Cambodian leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Vietnam installed the current government after invading Cambodia in late 1978 and ousting the Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of people during its 3{-year reign. Watson said he expected the Security Council to agree that the Supreme National Council would function as an advisory body for a U.N. interim government. In June, Secretary of State James A. Baker III altered the diplomatic balance on Cambodia when he announced that the United States was withdrawing its recognition of the guerrilla coalition and opening talks with Vietnam. U.S. officials held their first round of talks with Vietnamese diplomats last month at Vietnam's U.N. Mission. The United States has been assisting the two non-Communist factions in the guerrilla coalition, led by Prince Sihanouk and former Premier Son Sann. China is the main backer of the Khmer Rouge; while the Soviet Union has supported Vietnam and the Phnom Penh government.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Calls Missile Defense Test `Partial Success'
DOC.TEXT: The first of a series of tests of sensors designed to support the Pentagon's ``Brilliant Pebbles'' space-based missile defense system achieved only partial success, the Defense Department reported Monday. The department said that electronic data being sent back to earth on the functioning of the experiment was cut off in mid flight. But the Pentagon said the 13-minute experiment, launched on Saturday from the Wallops Island, Va. Flight Facility was a beneficial first step in the scheduled series of 12 experimental flights. The Brilliant Pebbles component of the Strategic Defense Initiative or Star Wars would place a cluster of small interceptor rockets into earth orbit, each capable of detecting the launch of hostile strategic missiles. The interceptor rockets could be ordered to speed toward the incoming missiles over thousands of miles and destroy them by high velocity impact. The Brilliant Pebbles experimental package was launched aboard a Black Brant X rocket at 3:04 a.m. Saturday. The Pentagon said the expendable rocket and its payload landed as planned in the Atlantic. The payload was to have been deployed at an altitude of 124 miles but Pentagon officials said they do not yet know if that goal was achieved. ``Only a partial set of objectives was achieved due to a premature termination of telemetry,'' the Pentagon statement said, referring to the interrupted flow of electronic data. A Pentagon official, who commented on condition he not be identified by name, said program managers will now try to learn how much of the experiment was completed, using backup sources from an aircraft, a satellite and from radars at Wallops Island. ``A number of the parts of the launch were very successful and validated other parts of the experiment,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Side With Plaintiffs, But Award No Damages
DOC.TEXT: Former Contra supply courier Eugene Hasenfus, who was shot down in Nicaragua, won a partial victory Monday in his lawsuit against an air carrier and former Air Force Gen. Richard Secord, but jurors gave him no money. Hasenfus had filed a federal civil lawsuit against Secord, a figure in the Iran-Contra scandal, and Miami-based Southern Air Transport, contending they controlled the illegal network supplying the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. He maintained they were responsible for damages suffered as a result of Nicaraguan soldiers shooting down a cargo plane Hasenfus was on in October 1986. Hasenfus, the sole survivor, was joined in the suit by the family of co-pilot Wallace Sawyer Jr., who was killed in the crash. ``I've had so much taken from me already,'' Hasenfus said. ``This is a disappointment.'' Jurors found that there was a special relationship or joint venture among the plantiffs and defendants, but that Hasenfus had been paid all he was due and that there was no written contract to cover his legal expenses in Nicaragua. Before jurors began deliberations on Aug. 21, U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins ruled in favor of Secord and Southern Air that the jury should only consider claims for back salary for Hasenfus and death benefits for Sawyer's wife of Magnolia, Ark. The plaintiffs had sought payment for legal bills, lost income, mental stress and other items. Attorneys for the defendants argued that Hasenfus and Sawyer were independent contractors who knew the risks of the operation and to whom the defendants had no special responsibility. The jurors disagreed with that but said they could find no evidence of an written contract or other justification to award any damages. Jurors deliberated for nearly 32 hours over five days. They apparently were deadlocked for several days last week on the question of damages and seemed frustrated by the decision they felt compelled to reach. ``We did feel there was a secret operation. We tried very hard to live by the evidence that they gave us but there wasn't any proof of any oral agreement,'' juror Wade Harris said. Hasenfus, of Marinette, Wis., sought $57,000 in lost and back pay. His wife, Sally, wanted $66,000 reimbursement for the legal expense involved in extricating her husband from the Nicaraguan jail where he spent three months. ``They removed their fingerprints quite well from everything,'' Hasenfus said afterward. Mrs. Hasenfus said State Department officials had assured her they would help pay for her husband's legal expenses while he was held in Nicaragua. But Hasenfus' attorneys were unable to link Secord and Southern Air to those State Department officials, explained one juror. ``If we could have proved the State Department (employees) were agents of Secord and Southern Air, we would have given them money,'' juror Ivis Charbonier said. Secord's attorney, Thomas Spencer, was pleased that no money damages were awarded. ``These fellows were independent contractors. They took those risks,'' Spencer said. Spencer said Secord was overseas and unavailable for comment. Secord is on probation after a guilty plea to lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0665 to CORRECT cycle designator
Britons Detained by Iraq Appear on TV With Messages to Families
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britons detained by Iraq appeared on Iraqi television Monday, addressing the camera with assurances to their families. ``It is just as obvious that these people are under constraint as it was with the last pictures,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Iraqi authorities have detained about 200 Britons in Iraq and 157 in Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2, the Foreign Office said. In all, about 21,000 Westerners are standed in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans. An Iraqi broadcast Thursday of President Saddam Hussein visiting with British hostages was denounced as a manipulative and callous attempt at propaganda. Monday's interviews were featured in a program on Iraqi television called ``Guest's News'' and in each one the hostage reassured relatives at home. An unidentified woman from Leeds was interviewed lying in a hospital bed where the television report said she had given birth to a baby son, Omar. Wearing a traditional Arabic head veil, and pictured with another son, identified as Adnam, she was asked if she had a message for her family back home and told her family, ``I'm safe, and not to worry too much.'' Tony, Pauline and Julian Barlow, who were taken from the Cedar Beach Hotel in Kuwait by the Iraqis, said nervously, ``We're being well treated. Everything is safe and we'll see you soon.'' Chris Myers, sitting with his girlfriend Caroline Hughes, spoke to his parents, but Miss Hughes said nothing and appeared to be less relaxed. The couple, stopped at a checkpoint, were among the first to be detained by the Iraqis. The television report showed the detainees in what appeared to be an apartment. Some were pictured playing pool. It also featured other foreign detainees, including a man who said he was from Hamburg, West Germany, and an Australian named as Edith Puckeridge. Englishwoman Christine Smythe said she was fine and wished her father a happy birthday. Margaret Hare sent her ``Love to everybody'' and Maggie Ross, shown with what appeared to be her family, told relatives and friends they were all right. ``We want to say that we're together, that we are well and that the children are being amazingly strong and brave in a very difficult situation. We hope we will be free to see you soon.''

DOC.HEAD: West African Task Force Seizes Liberian Rebel Gunboat, Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Two Nigerian warships captured a gunboat carrying weapons for forces loyal to Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor, a spokesman for West African forces trying to end Liberia's civil war said Monday. Lt. Col. John Dungs of the multinational force said the two Nigerian warships seized the gunboat Sunday. A Ghana news agency correspondent traveling with the multinational force reported 27 rebels were captured when the gunboat, a converted trawler, was seized as it was approaching two Nigerian frigates. The report did not say whether any shots were fired. One of the frigates was carrying Taylor's rival rebel leader, Prince Johnson, to Freetown to make flight connections for a meeting in Banjul, Gambia, of parties involved in the Liberian conflict. The two Nigerian frigates and a Ghanaian frigrate were expected to pick up more men, supplies and armaments in Freetown before returning to Monrovia, where the multinational force landed Friday night. It already has advanced out of the port area and secured some of the city. Nigeria, Gambia, Sierra Leone, Ghana and Guinea have provided 3,000 troops to end the 8-month-old tribal war in Liberia. Taylor, whose forces control most of Liberia, opposes the intervention and accuses Nigeria and Guinea of supporting embattled President Samuel Doe. Both Doe and Johnson have welcomed what they call a peacekeeping force. They have negotiated a truce between their fighters, who together control most of Monrovia. The Ghana news agency correspondent reported the streets of the Liberian capital of Monrovia were quiet Sunday night, and the only people in view were residents searching for food. The city has been without electricity and water for two months, and most food stocks were looted by government troops or rebels. But a spokesman for Taylor's National Patriotic Front accused the West African force of shelling civilian areas. ``They didn't come in with white flag waving, they came in blasting,'' Taylor's spokesman Tom Woewiyu said in Ouagadougu, Burkina Faso. Taylor has sent Woewiyu on a tour of West African capitals to try to persuade their heads of state to oppose the presence of troops from other countries in the region in Liberia. Reporters who recently returned from Taylor's headquarters in Liberia said they had seen some soldiers from Burkina Faso there. Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore has criticized the decision to send in the West African force. Woewiyu said the West African force was ``a surrogate group put together by the United States since they couldn't use Prince Johnson to defeat us.'' ``They went out and bought themselves some stool pigeons to carry the job for them.'' The West African leaders who have sent troops to Liberia say the war is affecting the entire region, which must cope with an influx of 400,000 refugees from the nation of 2.3 million people. Nine members of the multinational force who were injured in clashes with Taylor's rebels over the weekend in Monrovia were airlifted to U.S. Navy vessels for medical treatment, said Abass Bundu, executive secretary of the Economic Community of West African states, which ordered the foreign intervention. None of the multinational troops had been killed, Bundu said. The U.S. ships are providing support for several squads of Marines guarding the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia. Journalists who had been covering territory controlled by Taylor left during the weekend after the rebel leader accused an American journalist, Stephen Smith of Liberation of Paris, of being a spy. Taylor's men conducted a mock execution of Smith, firing just over his shoulders. Taylor's 10,000 fighters represent the largest army in the country, but many of his troops are teen-agers and inexperienced. The civil war has left 5,000 people dead, mainly civilians slaughtered for their tribal affiliations. The war began in December when Taylor's forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast, accusing Doe of corruption and mismanagement. Johnson later split with Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: Sexually Graphic Pictures Important to Exhibition, Curator Testifies
DOC.TEXT: Sexually graphic photographs included in a traveling exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe's work were necessary to understand the life of the late artist, a museum curator testified Monday. ``To have left them out would have been to leave out a chapter of a novel or a segment of history,'' said Janet Kardon, the director of the American Craft Museum in New York City, who assembled the exhibit. Mrs. Kardon testified for two hours at a hearing for the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie. They are charged with a misdemeanor count of pandering obscenity for displaying the homoerotic pictures. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David J. Albanese summoned Mrs. Kardon to help resolve a dispute over whether a jury could consider the pictures individually or whether it must treat the whole exhibit as a single work of art. Prosecutors contend the pictures are separate works. Defense lawyers disagree and asked Albanese to dismiss the case on the grounds that the exhibit as a whole isn't obscene. Albanese said he would rule Sept. 6 on the request for dismissal. The photographs were included in a six-week show that ended May 26. Mrs. Kardon said she assembled the 175-photograph exhibit with Mapplethorpe's help as an overview of his life. Mapplethorpe died last year at age 42 of AIDS. Outrage over the photos contributed to restrictions on federal funding for the arts. Most of the works in the exhibit are portraits or pictures of flowers, although some show homosexual acts. ``You really have to reflect everything an artist felt was important in their work,'' Mrs. Kardon said. ``For the most part, this is the only place those (sexually graphic) images appear, and they were an important part of his work.'' The judge earlier ordered Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on a misdemeanor count involving Mapplethorpe pictures of naked children. That charge and the other of pandering to obscenity each carry a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine for Barrie. The gallery could be fined $5,000 on each charge. The exhibition has appeared in several U.S. cities, but drew charges only in Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: Jumbo Jet With 343 Aboard Makes Safe Emergency Landing Without Nose Gear
DOC.TEXT: A United Airlines jumbo jet carrying 343 people landed safely Monday despite a retracted front landing gear, authorities said. Ten passengers suffered minor injuries sliding down the plane's emergency chutes. ``It was pretty scary,'' said Joy Wahab, 20, of San Diego. ``We circled and the pilot tried to put the landing gear down. It didn't work. He said, `Well, we're going to come down one way or the other.' '' The Boeing 747 skidded to a stop at Los Angeles International Airport with its nose landing gear stuck in a retracted position. The 323 passengers and 20 crew members left the plane via emergency chutes, said Tony Molinaro, a spokesman for Chicago-based United Airlines. Flight 816 originated in Sydney, Australia. Ten passengers were treated for minor injuries, said Fire Department spokesman Greg Acevedo. Most complained of chute burns and back pain, he said. ``It was frightening not knowing what they were going to do,'' said Cassandra Edwards of Berkeley, who sat in the first-class section above the nose gear. ``There was a point when I heard the nose scrape on the bottom. That sound is very unnerving, knowing that the nose is sliding, knowing that at any moment it could explode.'' Damage to the aircraft was slight and there were no sparks or flames upon landing, said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Fred O'Donnell. Several passengers said the landing was smooth.

DOC.HEAD: Reactor Shut Down At Chernobyl Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, site of a disastrous 1986 explosion, was shut down Monday because of a malfunction, Izvestia reported. The government newspaper, in a report attributed to Nikolai Shteinberg, deputy chairman of the State Committee for Nuclear Power Station Safety, said the staff of Reactor No. 3 shut down the unit ``in keeping with operational rules.'' ``Established safety standards were not violated,'' the newspaper said. It gave no further details on the malfunction. It was Chernobyl's Reactor No. 4 that caught fire and exploded on April 26, 1986, spewing radioactive cesium, strontium and plutonium over a wide area of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia. Official reports say 31 people were killed in the partial meltdown, but unofficial reports say 250 died. Four years after the accident, more than 2 million people are still living on contaminated lands in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Grammy Winner Stevie Ray Vaughan Killed in Helicopter Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf pvs, `Among the...' to UPDATE with names of others killed.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY24, LaserColor NY25; others upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Grammy-winning blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan was among five people killed early Monday when their helicopter slammed into a hill in dense fog after leaving a concert, authorities said. The other victims were three members of rock star Eric Clapton's entourage and a pilot. Clapton, who played with Vaughan at the concert Sunday night, landed safely in Chicago on another helicopter. His publicist, Ronnie Lippin, announced Vaughan's death. Lippin said there was no truth to a report that Vaughan had begged to get on the helicopter that crashed because it would arrive at its destination earlier. Clapton said the victims, who included his agent, bodyguard, and tour manager, ``were my companions, my associates, and my friends. This is a tragic loss of some very special people.'' The helicopter, owned by Omni Flight Helicopters Inc., crashed into a field shortly after leaving the Alpine Valley Music Theater, an open-air stage and ski resort near East Troy, 30 miles southwest of Milwaukee, said Omni spokesman Phil Huth. Wreckage and bodies were scattered over 200 feet, authorities said. Clapton's manager, Roger Forrester, told Britain's Sky News: ``We had four helicopters and Eric and I were in one directly behind it when it suddenly disappeared from vision.'' ``Obviously we were not aware of the tragic circumstances until the early hours when daybreak broke and they discovered it on a ski slope directly behind the building in which we had just performed.'' Among the victims was Bobby Brooks, 34, Clapton's agent at Creative Artists Agency, whose clients also included Crosby, Stills & Nash; Whoopi Goldberg; Pat Benatar; Jackson Browne and Dolly Parton. Walworth County Coroner John Griebel identified the other victims as Nigel Browne of London, a Clapton bodyguard; Colin Smythe of London, one of Clapton's tour managers, and pilot Jeff Brown of East Chicago, Ind. Vaughan, 35, who overcame a 1986 drug problem to win two Grammy awards and the musician of the decade honors in his home state of Texas, gained popularity in the middle 1980s with his guitar jamming and blues sound, borrowed much from music legends B.B. King, Muddy Waters and Albert King. B.B. King said he was ``saddened beyond words'' after learning of Vaughan's death. ``Stevie Ray Vaughan was like one of my children, and I felt a great loss when I heard the news,'' B.B. King said in a statement. ``The loss is a great loss for blues music and all fans of music around the world. He was just beginning to be appreciated and develop his potential.'' Chicago blues guitarist Buddy Guy, a longtime friend of Vaughan who had participated in Sunday night's concert, choked back tears after learning about the crash. ``He was one of the greatest I ever met,'' Guy said. ``My head ain't right yet.'' ``This is the worst accident to happen to Texas music since Buddy Holly and the Big Bopper went down in the '50s,'' said Casey Monahan, director of the Texas Music Office in Austin, where Vaughan got his musical start. ``It's a hole no one can fill.'' Andy Schwartz, a spokesman for Epic Records in New York, which owns Vaughan's label, said Vaughan had toured this summer with blues singer Joe Cocker and was to release a new record in September with his brother, Jimmie. Jimmie Vaughan had been at the weekend concert, Schwartz said. ``They were really looking forward to the release of the record, had completed some video and were having some discussion about touring as the Vaughan brothers,'' Schwartz said. Vaughan had a platinum album with his band Double Trouble in ``Couldn't Stand the Weather,'' released in 1984. That same year, he won a Grammy Award for best traditional blues recording for a song called ``Texas Flood.'' This year, he won a Grammy in the contemporary blues category for ``In Step.'' Guitar Player Magazine cited Vaughan as the best electric blues player in 1983, 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1988, finally naming him to its ``Gallery of the Greats'' in 1989. He also was named this spring as musician of the decade by the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference in Austin, Texas. Bill Bruce, a National Transportation Safety Board investigator, said the Bell Jet Ranger helicopter slammed into the hill in dense fog, but it was not certain if weather contributed to the accident. ``It was a high energy impact at a shallow angle,'' Bruce said. The victims apparently died upon impact, authorities said. Dominic Scaffidi, a National Weather Service forecaster at Sullivan, said fog had reduced visibility overnight to below two miles in parts of southern Wisconsin, a condition requiring pilots to fly by instruments rather than sight. Deputies found the wreckage about 7 a.m. The other victims included Nigel Browne, a Clapton bodyguard; and Colin Smythe, one of Clapton's tour managers, Clapton's statement said. The pilot was identified as Jeff Brown by Walworth County Coroner John Griebel.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Premier Ends Talks With Mohawks, Orders Army To Remove Barricades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with military comment. Pickup 5th pvs, `Mohawk negotiators...'
DOC.TEXT: Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa broke off talks Monday with Indians involved in a seven-week armed standoff with authorities and ordered the army to tear down Mohawk barricades in two Quebec communities. The premier said the Mohawks had not been negotiating in good faith, and he was therefore obliged to assume his responsibility for public order. ``I have asked the Canadian army to continue its mission, to take down the barricades,'' Bourassa told a news conference in Montreal, broadcast live on Canadian television. ``And I hope in the coming days we will have a resolution to this crisis.'' At Bourassa's request, troops a week ago replaced Quebec provincial police at the barricades in the communities of Oka and Chateauguay. Gen. John de Chastelain, chief of staff of the Canadian Forces, did not say how or when the army would move, but indicated it would be soon. ``We have been told to take down the barricades, we're going to take down the barricades,'' the general told reporters later Monday. ``We hope somebody will take them down for us.'' He said the best way would be if the Mohawks simply abandoned their positions and allowed the army to move in and simply cart away the pieces. Mohawk negotiators could not be reached immediately for comment on Bourassa's decision. But Georges Erasmus, national chief of the Assembly of First Nations, a nationwide grouping of Indian bands, said: ``He's declared war on the Mohawks.'' Erasmus insisted that the Mohawks wanted a negotiated settlement. ``That's the only thing that's going to avoid bloodshed.'' A reporter for Canadian television reported from the scene at Oka, where the Indian troubles began, that armed Mohawk men appeared to have withdrawn from the barricades, leaving only women and children. Part of the problem with the negotiations has to do with the confused nature of Mohawk politics. Various groups vie for leadership on the numerous reserves. Some claim the militant Warrior society has usurped authority from elected native officials. ``We Quebeckers and Canadians cannot tolerate groups of citizens living in Quebec choosing which laws they want to respect and which they want to ignore,'' Bourassa told the news conference. Mohawks from the Kahnesatake reserve at Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, set up a barricade across the main road into the reserve to protest the town's plan to expand a golf course onto territory claimed by the Indians. On July 11, provincial police attempted to storm the barricade, but were repulsed. A policeman was shot dead in the attempt, although it was not clear who killed him. After the police action, Mohawks from the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal set up a sympathy blockade at Chateauguay, cutting off the Mercier Bridge across the St. Lawrence River linking Montreal's southern suburbs with the city. That blockade caused a major disruption of traffic, forcing many people to make long detours. It also led to rising tempers among local residents, against both the police and the Indians. The issue of the golf course was resolved early on when the federal government agreed to buy the land and turn it over to the natives. But since then, the Mohawks have used the situation to air a much wider series of demands, including sovereignty. Bernard Roy, the federal government's negotiator, spoke to reporters two hours before Bourassa, saying the Mohawks must moderate their demands. He said the Mohawk demand for immunity from prosecution for those involved in the July 11 shootout was unacceptable. The Mohawks had agreed, in what they called a gesture of good faith, to open one lane of the Mercier bridge to traffic. That was rejected by Bourassa, who termed the offer not serious.

DOC.HEAD: Two Bombs Explode in Latest Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A blast on Monday damaged a factory owned by the family of the trade secretary, whose commercial holdings have been a target of suspected renegades, police said. Another bomb exploded before dawn Tuesday outside a car dealer in the financial district of Makati, police said. Windows of the building were shattered, but there were no injuries, police said. The incident Tuesday, the 17th explosion in two weeks, occurred on the third year anniversary of the Aug. 28, 1987 failed coup against President Corazon Aquino. The blasts, blamed on rebel soldiers, have gone off despite military and police checkpoints in the capital. Military leaders have warned that the spate of explosions may precede a coup attempt. Mrs. Aquino meanwhile urged village leaders to fight the ``psychological terror'' spread by the rebels. ``At this point their main strategy is to sow psychological terror in the minds of our people through constant lies, misinformation and destructive rumor-mongering,'' Mrs. Aquino said in an address to village leaders Monday. She asked them to ``fight these lies and rumors.'' At the armed forces headquarters in suburban Quezon city, statements purportedly coming from dissidents were circulated Monday on the eve of the August coup, which almost toppled Mrs. Aquino and left at least 50 people dead. It called Mrs. Aquino to resign or ``face the wrath of the nation.'' Monday's bombing at the Republic Flour Mills was the fourth blast at firms owned by the family of Trade Secretary Jose Concepcion. The most serious bombing occurred Friday at Concepcion's soft drink company on the outskirts of Manila. Three workers were wounded. There have been six coup attempts against Mrs. Aquino since she was swept to power in a 1985 civilian-military coup that toppled President Ferdinand Marcos.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Says He Will Insist That Iraq Respect U.N. Resolutions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Monday he will insist that Iraq respect Security Council resolutions demanding the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and the release of all foreigners. Perez de Cuellar is scheduled to meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on Thursday in Amman, Jordan, in an effort to negotiate an end to the Persian Gulf crisis. Since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered his troops into Kuwait on Aug. 2, the U.N. Security Council has passed five resolutions condemning Iraq. The resolutions have demanded the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, imposed a trade embargo, declared the annexation of Kuwait null and void, insisted that Iraq allow all foreigners to leave, and authorized military action to enforce the economic sanctions against Baghdad. ``Now is the time for diplomacy in order to obtain full implementation of the Security Council resolutions,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters. ``The Security Council is not a negotiator, it is a body that adopts resolutions which are laws for the international community. The secretary-general has to be a negotiator. That is why I am now going to the area to see the ways and means of having the resolutions implemented,'' he said. The U.N. chief said it ``is my hope'' that Iraq is seeking a negotiated end to the crisis. Perez de Cuellar held a series of private meetings Monday with senior diplomats regarding his mission, including the U.S., Soviet, French, British and Chinese ambassadors; the Kuwaiti ambassador; and the whole Security Council, after which he met reporters. Perez de Cuellar said he was open to discussion on the blockade of food and medicine shipments to Iraq under the U.N. trade embargo. The Security Council resolution allows shipments of such goods in certain humanitarian cases. Asked whether he was bothered that the embargo is preventing food and medicine from reaching the Iraqi public, Perez de Cuellar replied: ``That is a question which is, as well, one of the subjects I am going to discuss with the Iraqis.'' But Perez de Cuellar insisted that he would always bear in mind the five resolutions passed by the Security Council in his talks with Iraqi officials. In Kennebunkport, Maine, President Bush told a news conference that if Perez de Cuellar could make progress in getting the Iraqis out of Kuwait, ``so much the better.'' But he said Saddam's resistance to comply with international law leaves little hope for ``fruitful negotiation'' in the U.N.-sponsored search for a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. The president said it was inconceivable that Perez de Cuellar will make concessions to Iraq. ``The United Nations' position is not negotiable,'' Bush said. ``There is no room for compromise on getting the legitimate government (of Kuwait) back and the illegitimate invaders out.'' Perez de Cuellar said he had not yet heard from Bush on his mission, but added: ``I am persuaded personally that President Bush will not undermine my efforts.'' Saddam has invited Perez de Cuellar to come to Baghdad, but the U.N. chief said he has no plans for now to visit Iraq. He did not explicitly explain why, saying only that he thought it was important for him to meet Aziz in Jordan. Asked to assess the prospects for the talks, Perez de Cuellar later told NBC News: ``I am hopeful, and I think that widsom will prevail.''

DOC.HEAD: Statue of Lenin in Downtown Tbilisi Finally Felled by Activists
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people watched as a giant statue of Vladimir Lenin was toppled with official approval early Tuesday in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi, a local editor reported. The statue of the founder of the Soviet state had become a target of anti-Communist activists in the Caucasian republic months ago, and police had guarded it against threats to destroy it. During a meeting of the Georgia Supreme Soviet on March 18, demonstrators hurled cans of red-brown paint at Lenin, marring the statue and its pedestal. Zurab Kodalashvili, editor of the independent Georgian agency Novosti Iberia, said authorities gave in to public demands and agreed to permit dismantling of the monument. The huge stone monument that dominated the downtown square in front of City Hall was toppled shortly after midnight with about 350 people standing by, Kodalashvili said. The editor told The Associated Press by telephone from Tbilisi that the square filled with people during the night as unidentified workers labored for more than five hours to bring down the statue. Similar statues, ubiquitous throughout the Soviet Union, have been destroyed in more than two dozen Georgian towns in recent months, and another was toppled recently in a Lithuanian town. Criticism of the Communist revolutionary has surfaced in recent months, but for most of the past seven decades, Lenin's name and memory have been sacrosanct. One official exception took place at the the Moscow City Council, where radical reformers who won election earlier this year voted to remove Lenin's bust from their chambers.

DOC.HEAD: PUSH Delays Picketing, Plans Strategy
DOC.TEXT: Operation PUSH on Monday postponed a nationwide picketing campaign, scheduled as part of its boycott of Nike products. ``We plan to begin that tomorrow or Wednesday,'' said Victoria Hollins, a spokeswoman for the civil-rights organization. She said the delay was intended to allow PUSH to plan strategy. Ms. Hollins said representatives of the organization plan to stand outside stores selling products of the athletic shoe company to hand out leaflets urging customers not to buy the products. PUSH stands for People United to Serve Humanity. The Chicago-based organization, which called for the boycott Aug. 11, was founded in 1971 by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a former contender for the Democratic presidential nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Maker Tells Frustrated Consumers to Keep Calling Recall Number
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer's announcement last week that it was recalling one of its coffee makers has led to a flood of calls that have tied up a toll-free number and brought some consumers to a fast boil. ``We know there is a large volume of calls we're missing,'' said Jerry Ray, spokesman for Proctor-Silex Co. of Richmond, Va. Ray said the company processed 75,000 calls in the first four days after it pledged to provide free coffee makers to an estimated 800,000 consumers who purchased a model now declared a fire hazard. Proctor-Silex said the coffee makers are subject to potentially dangerous overheating because their thermostats and thermal fuses may malfunction. Consumers have complained to news organizations that they spent hours unsuccessfully trying to get through to the toll free number, or that they were connected to the wrong number. Amy Paulman, public affairs officer for the Consumer Product Safety Commission, said it was not unusual for telephone lines to be jammed the first few days after a recall is announced. Ray said the company has 200 trained phone operators answering queries 24 hours a day. He urged people to call at night when the line is not so busy, and to keep trying. Ray, however, said telephone company officials have assured Proctor-Silex that there is no problem with phone connections. He said some radio stations broadcast the wrong number and many consumers were simply misdialing. The correct number is 1-800-341-3333. Ray said about 80 percent of the people calling have A6 models that are not subject to the recall. The recalled models were made in 1985 and 1986, begin with A4 or A5 and have series number that end with the numbers 58 or 68. Calls are even received from people who own rival brand coffee makers, Ray said. ``We get calls from people who own everything.'' The phone service will be open several months, he said, and ``We're glad people are trying to call. We're trying to get the coffee makers out of the kitchen.''

DOC.HEAD: 10 of 11 OPEC Members Agree To Allow Temporary Increase in Production
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with tentative agreement on production increase. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhotos VIE1, VIE2; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Ten of 11 OPEC ministers tentatively agreed early Tuesday to permit increased oil production immediately by some countries in response to the Persian Gulf crisis, sources said. Iran was lone holdout at an informal meeting of 11 of the 13 Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraq and Libya did not attend. OPEC officials planned to try to persuade Iran to join the arrangement, which would lift the cartel's quotas temporarily to permit increased production by countries with additional production capability. The ministers were expected to meet Tuesday to endorse the plan. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have said they intend to pump more oil to help make up for the shortfall of 4 million barrels a day caused by the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. U.N. sanctions were imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The officials were trying to come up with an ``understanding'' that would sanction output increases by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and others to help offset losses to the world market caused by the crisis, said senior delegate sources. ``Most countries have already agreed to sanction production increases for the simple reason that . . . (the countries) are going to do it anyway,'' said one source. ``If they do it outside OPEC, it may be difficult to have them back in the mold again.'' A source close to OPEC said it appeared Saudi Arabia, the world's largest crude exporter, has already increased oil production to meet the extra demand. But he refused to give details. Figures obtained Monday from the U.S. Energy Information Administration estimate Saudi Arabia's production at 6 million barrels of oil per day, 600,000 more than its OPEC quota of 5.4 million barrels. In Venezuela, the government said a 90-hour shutdown of one of its oil installations began Monday as that country prepared to increase production. A subsidiary of the state oil monopoly Petroleos de Venezuela shut down a site to increase production capacity there from 180,000 barrels per day to 220,000 barrels per day, the government news agency Venpres said. Venezuela's OPEC quota is 1.95 million barrels a day. Quotas were set last month under a production accord worked out by the 13 producer nations. That agreement sets an overall output ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day in the last half of the year. Iran has fought lifting the quotas. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh, taking a break from closed-door discussions, said Monday ``it is not necessary'' now to boost output, ``but maybe in the future.'' Iran says enough excess oil is stored in the industrialized world to make up for any shortages. Libyan officials were also expected to argue against any move to raise production. A Libyan delegation may arrive Tuesday for the consultations with OPEC President Sadek Boussena, the Algerian oil minister, sources said. Resentment has surfaced at what some nations view as political pressure on the group from the United States, the world's largest oil importer, to lift production. Delegate sources said some countries received calls from American officials before the meeting asking questions about their positions. ``We cannot be pressured,'' said one source, demanding anonymity. Any arrangement to permit higher pumping would likely include promises that production be reduced once the crisis ends, according to the sources. It also would probably call on consuming nations to take steps to use oil in storage to help meet any shortages, they said. Another source suggested the talks might end with those nations wanting to boost output issuing a statement on their own, without the cartel's backing. There also seemed to be some support for a solution that would not require a formal statement _ or even a formal meeting. Crude prices surged last week above $30 a barrel on fears of military escalation and a shortage of crude supplies in the oil-rich gulf region. But they plummeted Monday, with a barrel of light sweet crude for October delivery dropped $4 to close at $26.91 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The OPEC nations are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Drops Sharply in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped $17.58 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Tuesday, opening at $392.82. It closed at $410.40 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Gives Blacks, Whites Equal Power on School Board
DOC.TEXT: Black and white leaders trying to end eight months of racial protests over the public schools agreed Monday on a plan to share power on the school board. The agreement worked out over the weekend was approved by the City Council and school board members of both races, said Mayor Joe Smitherman. The plan would give each race an equal vote, and the chairmanship would alternate between black and white. Smitherman and council members reached the agreement in meetings Sunday with two dozen black leaders. ``I think we've got something good worked out,'' said Smitherman, who is white. Black protesters weren't directly involved in the talks, Sanders said. The trouble began in December, when the five blacks on the 11-member school board walked out over a decision against rehiring Norward Roussell, the public school system's first black superintendent. Daily protests, lawsuits, school boycotts, sit-ins and several altercations with police followed. Roussell resigned in May, about two months before his contract expired, and settled a $10 million lawsuit against the school board for $150,000. State Sen. Hank Sanders, a Selma attorney and leader of the protests, said Monday that protesters and City Attorney Henry Pitts were working toward an end to pending litigation. He refused to release details. The city filed misdemeanor charges against several protesters, including Sanders' wife, Rose, and the protesters in turn filed a $10 billion lawsuit challenging the City Council's appointment of school board members. Sanders has said the suit would be dropped and the protests would stop if the charges were dismissed. Selma schools reopened Aug. 20, with blacks making up 80 percent of the student body of about 5,800. The agreement worked out over the weekend was approved by the City Council and black and white members of the school board, Smitherman said. Under the plan, five white and five black board members vote on all issues and chairman Carl Barker would vote only on litigation matters. The City Council promised to keep a racial balance on future boards and to appoint a black as board chairman when Barker eventually steps down. The chairmanship would alternate between blacks and whites. ``People have asked me how the board can operate with a five-and-five split,'' Smitherman said Monday. ``Well, you're going to operate with the art of compromise.'' The full board is to meet Sept. 13. The white members of the board have continued to meet throughout the walkout. Sanders said the agreement doesn't give blacks equal power because Barker would control committee appointments and could vote on legal matters. The rotation would be fair, ``but that may not come about under this present agreement for several years,'' he said. ``The long and short of it is that at this point the protests would continue and the litigation would continue,'' Sanders said. ``The black (school) board members would be back but that would be all.''

DOC.HEAD: Gambling Emerges as Major Issue in Tuesday's Alaska Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to ADD how gambling initiative relates to governor's race. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Jim Campell...
DOC.TEXT: Differences over a gambling initiative were at the center of a close race for governor between Lt. Gov. Stephen McAlpine and former Anchorage Mayor Tony Knowles going into Tuesday's Democratic primary. In the Republican race, state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski was heavily favored to win her second consecutive nomination. In Oklahoma, Gov. Henry Bellmon, a Republican, opened the door for a wide-open race when he announced he would not seek re-election, and five candidates in each party sought the nomination for his job in Tuesday's primaries. Alaskans were expected to reject an initiative that would allow local-option casino gambling. There was virtually no campaign for the measure, and a poll last week found voters opposing it by 2-to-1. Gov. Steve Cowper, a Democrat, helped lead the campaign against the gambling measure. Knowles, who opposes the measure, seized on the issue in the campaign's final weeks after McAlpine said he would vote for the initiative. McAlpine said he opposes casino gambling but supports letting local voters decide. McAlpine tried to paint Knowles as soft on drugs because of the former mayor's opposition to a measure on the November general election ballot that would restore criminal penalties for possessing small amounts of marijuana. Alaska is the only state that has no criminal penalties for possessing less than 4 ounces of marijuana at home. Knowles said he opposes the measure because it would allow jail terms for first-time offenders. In the Republican race Sturgulewski maintained a healthy lead in the polls in her second bid to become Alaska's first woman governor. She lost the 1986 race to Cowper, who is not seeking a second term. Jim Campbell, a former chairman of the Alaska Railroad Corp., advanced in the polls in recent weeks but still remained well behind Sturgulewski. In third place was state Sen. Rick Halford, who appealed to conservative, anti-government voters. In congressional races, Rep. Don Young and Sen. Ted Stevens were expected to win the GOP nominations easily. Young had token opposition from Gary Sinkola, of Fairbanks, and Stevens faced Bob Bird, a teacher from Kenai and anti-abortion activist. On the Democratic, former Valdez mayor John Devens was the only candidate to oppose Young. Seeking the nomination for Stevens' seat were Tom Taggart of Hyder and Michael Beasley of Eagle River. Alaska is one of three states with an open primary in which all candidates appear on one ballot regardless of party. Voters are free to vote in one party in one race and another party in another race. In Oklahoma's Republican gubernatorial primary, four candidates said they had a real shot at the anticipated Sept. 18 runoff. They were Oklahoma City attorney Burns Hargis, former U.S. Attorney Bill Price, restaurateur and former television newsman Vince Orza and truck stop operator Jerry Brown. The other candidate was Caddo rancher and political newcomer Jerry Hoyt. In the Democratic primary, U.S. Rep. Wes Watkins battled with Oklahoma City businessman David Walters, who ran unsuccessfully against Bellmon in 1986, and House Speaker Steve Lewis. The other candidates were John Shorty Barnett and Anne Hartin Langston. Even a pillow came into dispute in the heated campaign. Walters chaged that Watkins set on a pillow during a televised debate among all the Democratic nominees in an effort to make himself look taller. ``Now that's the vintage Wes Watkins. Even while he's supposed to be debating the issues in front of the people, he uses a prop to make himself appear to be something he's not,'' Walters said. Watkins replied he was ``shocked that Mr. Walters is so sensitive about his height'' and said the pillow was to ease his back. ``I offered to help him (Walters) raise his chair, but he declined,'' Watkins said. U.S. Sen. David Boren faced two candidates in the Democratic primary _ newcomer Manuel Ybarra and perennial candidate Virginia Jenner. The winner will face the sole GOP candidate, lawyer Stephen Jones.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Stations Divided Over Sinead O'Connor's Anti-Anthem Stand
DOC.TEXT: At least four radio stations took Sinead O'Connor off the air after the Irish singer offended patriotic listeners by banning ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' from her concert. Anti-O'Connor backlash tied up radio switchboards in New York and New Jersey, but apparently didn't ripple beyond the region. O'Connor's hits include ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' and ``Mandinka.'' During the peak morning drive time Monday, radio show hosts smashed O'Connor's records on the air. Listeners were incensed that the singer-songwriter, known for her confessional lyrics and shaved head, threatened to walk out of the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel Friday night if the national anthem was played, as it routinely is at the amphitheater. Mike Opelka, producer of the morning show at WHTZ in Newark, said the station got about 1,200 unsolicited calls between 7 a.m. and 10 a.m. By a margin of 30-1, callers wanted O'Connor off the air. The ban will likely be short-lived, said program director Steve Kingston. ``It's a statement based on the feelings of our audience,'' Kingston said. ``Tomorrow, when people forget about it, we'll probably go back to playing her record.'' WPLJ in New York, WHTG in Eatontown, and WDHA in Dover, N.J., also stopped playing O'Connor songs, including singles from her hit album ``I Do Not Want What I Haven't Got.'' In a news release Monday, O'Connor said she hadn't meant to insult anyone, but objects to any national anthem being played at her concerts, ``even my own.'' The New Jersey center gave in to the singer's demand, fearing that a last-minute cancellation would enrage the audience of 9,000, but prohibited any future appearances. Directors of rock stations in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Diego said they hadn't heard of the controversy. Meanwhile, Armed Forces Radio said soldiers and their families overseas would continue to hear O'Connor. ``Our position for music is, if it's a song that is popular and goes up the charts with various audiences in the U.S., that's where we play our music from,'' said spokesman Jim Kout. ``We don't ban artists. The only time we wouldn't carry a song would be when a judge declared it obscene.'' A New York state senator was less forgiving. Nicholas Spano, a Westchester County Republican, urged fans to boycott O'Connor's performance Wednesday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. ``He's pathetic,'' responded O'Connor's publicist, Elaine Schock. ``Politicians will jump on anything, won't they?'' Schock said. ``I'm surprised he believes in censorship because Americans believe so strongly in freedom of speech. He should be ashamed.''

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson To Interview Iraqi President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped words, `leave' and `interview.'
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is headed to Baghdad to interview Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein for the syndicated television show ``Inside Edition,'' a spokeswoman for the show said Monday. Jackson, whose own ``The Jesse Jackson Show'' is to premiere next month, was scheduled to leave Monday night for Jordan with a 15-member group. From there, they planned to travel to Iraq and interview Saddam on Wednesday or Thursday, said the spokeswoman, Allyson Kossow. Iraq has issued visas, she said. She said no date had been set yet for the broadcast of Jackson's interview with Saddam, whose Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait touched off the Persian Gulf crisis, which has brought thousands of U.S. soldiers to Saudi Arabia. Kossow said Jackson isn't being paid for the interview, nor will the interview appear on Jackson's own show, which is syndicated by Warner Bros. in Los Angeles. ``Inside Edition,'' which is syndicated by competing King World Productions, will pay for the travel and production expenses of Jackson's group, and ``we retain complete editorial control'' of interviews, Kossow said. No spokesperson for Jackson's talk show was immediately available for comment. Jackson, who in 1984 played a role as an unofficial diplomat in seeking the release of a U.S. Navy pilot shot down and held in Syria, told a news conference last week he was trying to arrange a trip to Iraq. He said his goal was to interview Iraqi officials and American hostages in Baghdad for his new series, but not to go there as anything other than a journalist. ``It would not be appropriate to go there as a diplomat,'' he said then. Jackson's party includes former ABC correspondent Ken Walker, Kossow said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Young Women Found Slain Near Florida University
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `One of ...,' to CLARIFY police statements.
DOC.TEXT: The killings of three women students on the eve of fall classes in this college town left other students fearful, parents worried and police trying to match clues at two off-campus apartments. The body of an 18-year-old Santa Fe Community College student was found in her apartment early Monday, about eight hours after police found two University of Florida freshman slain in their southwest Gainesville apartment less than two miles away. Investigators believed the killings were linked, said Gainesville Police Chief Wayland Clifton. One of the victims was found nude and one was partly nude, police said. They refused to give details on the third victim or say how the three were killed. ``We're looking at a number of leads, a lot of evidence but we can't say we have a definite suspect in mind,'' Clifton said. He didn't explain how the two attacks were linked. The first two bodies were discovered Sunday afternoon after the parents of a Jacksonville student, unable to reach their daughter, had police and a maintenance man open the door, police said. The slayings prompted a flood of telephone calls to police and the university, where classes began Monday. ``We're receiving calls from all over, particularly from out-of-state parents,'' said Lt. Sadie Darnell, spokeswoman for the Gainesville Police Department. ``We don't want to create panic, but people need to be cautious about who they let into their apartments and who they let into their cars,'' she said. University of Florida spokeswoman Linda Gray said the university also was besieged by frantic calls. President John Lombardi and other officials spent Monday morning trying to ease the fears of anxious parents. The university, which advised students to make reassuring calls home, has established a free phone bank. ``My parents were calling all weekend and they couldn't get me because I was out. My father was a basket case,'' said Lainie Gold, 20, a University of Florida junior from North Miami. ``Everyone I've talked to is very nervous.'' ``I made sure all my doors and windows were locked,'' said Christie Torchia, 21, a junior from Coral Springs. The killings revived memories of Tiffany Sessions, a 20-year-old UF student who vanished Feb. 9, 1989, after leaving her Gainesville apartment to go jogging. Despite a massive search, no trace of her has been found. The students killed in the same apartment were identified by Gainesville police as Christina P. Powell, 17, of Jacksonville, and Sonya Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach. Both were second-semester freshmen who had gone to summer school at the University of Florida. The third victim was Christa L. Hoyt, 18, a student at nearby Santa Fe Community College and a full-time records clerk at the Alachua County Sheriff's Office, the college's president, Lawrence Tyree said Monday. University spokeswoman Linda Gray said that more than 75 percent of the university's 34,000 students live off campus, many in apartments. ``This is such a tragic way for this school year to begin,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Police Headquarters Destroyed by Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire on Monday destroyed the headquarters of the military police. It came during a 3-week-old strike by state police over the killing of an officer allegedly by military police. No injuries were reported in the fire. Military Police Commander Ivan Granoogst said there was no immediate indication that the fire was linked to the police strike. He said investigators have not excluded arson. The two-story 18th-century brick building is inside the Fort Zeelandia military compound in Paramaribo and normally heavily guarded. Military police said the fire broke out at 2 a.m. in a food storage room and burned for two hours, destroying the building. Only the walls remained standing. The building was constructed in 1890 and was considered an important historical landmark in the capital of this nation on the northern coast of South America. The state police allege that the military police killed police officer Herman Gooding on Aug. 4. They claim the killing was in retaliation for the arrest in a nightclub the previous day of a military policeman who was shot in the leg while resisting arrest. The state police went on strike after Gooding's slaying. Two weeks ago, the government named a special committee to oversee an investigation into the police killing. However, the state police continued their strike and no policemen can be seen patrolling the streets. They have, however, returned to administrative duties and are investigating crimes such as murder, manslaughter and larceny.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Legislature to Investigate Mass Grave
DOC.TEXT: A parliamentary committee that intends to investigate a grave containing 10 bodies _ including two men who reportedly had been arrested by the army _ has summoned army chief Gen. Humberto Ortega to testify. Parliamentarian Frank Duarte, chairman of the Human Rights Commission, told the pro-government newspaper La Prensa that he issued the summons Monday after a human rights activist claimed the army had ignored her demands for an investigation. Peasants found the grave, which included the body of a child, in mid-June near a former military base, near the town of Wiwili, 175 miles from Managua. That area had been in the heart of the war zone during the war in the 1980s between U.S.-backed Contra rebels and troops of the Sandinista government, which was voted out of power this year. Two women who viewed the bodies said they recognized clothing and other personal articles belonging to their sons, both draft-dodgers who disappeared in October 1983 after being arrested by the Sandinista army. The civil war ended after Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took office April 25. La Prensa belongs to Mrs. Chamorro's family. Ortega led the army during the rule of his brother _ former President Daniel Ortega _ and was retained as army chief by Mrs. Chamorro. The newspaper did not give details of the pending investigation by the National Assembly committee. The date for the start of hearings has not been made public. Lt. Col. Rosa Pasos, the army spokeswoman, was out of her office and was not immediately available for comment, an aide said. Duarte said he was acting on a complaint by Marta Patricia Baltodano of the Nicaraguan Association for Human Rights.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Again On Central Square
DOC.TEXT: About 100 anti-government demonstrators gathered in a central square in Bucharest for the sixth straight day Monday, demanding the resignation of President Ion Iliescu. Police stationed in the area of University Square prevented the protesters from disrupting traffic at the main intersection on the capital's fashionable Balcescu Boulevard. Bucharest residents opposed to the protesters' actions also intervened. There were several skirmishes between protesters and bystanders, and one man appeared to be badly beaten. The rallies _ motivated by the deteriorating state of the economy _ began Wednesday evening and escalated to violent confrontations with police at the weekend in which 80 people were detained. On Saturday night, a clash erupted after police moved in, armed with clubs and shields. At least two people were reported hospitalized. About 300 protesters occupied the square Sunday. Monday's protesters, numbering about 100, again chanted slogans demanding Iliescu's resignation. Critics accuse Iliescu and his associates, who won free elections earlier this year, of keeping many of the policies of ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausecu. The University Square was the site of a 53-day anti-government demonstration and traffic blockade earlier this year that sparked several days of violence in the capital. In a separate development Monday, labor leaders at the important Tractorul factory in the central city of Brasov declared a general strike, media reported. The union there has demanded higher pay and improved work conditions. They said they would not return to work until Prime Minister Petre Roman came to negotiate. The government issued a statement rejecting the demands and charging the action was costing the economy $1 million daily.

DOC.HEAD: Killer Fire Rages Out of Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE acreage and number of homes destroyed, names of firefighters killed, details. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Gov. Norm...' Edd is cq in 10th graf.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphotos SK1,3
DOC.TEXT: More crews were mobilized Monday as the wind picked up again, whipping a 3,000-acre fire that killed two firefighters and destroyed 19 homes outside this northern Utah mountain community. The fire, of unknown origin, exploded across 2,500 acres and through several canyons with the help of 40 mph wind Sunday, burning to within a half-mile of Midway, a community of 1,200. About 200 firefighters worked Monday to build containment lines around the stubborn blaze 30 miles east of Salt Lake City. At dusk, the crew was cut in half to give exhausted firefighters a chance to rest. The remaining crew should be able to handle the fire overnight as temperatures cooled and winds died down, said Dick Buehler, deputy incident commander. Uinta National Forest spokeswoman Vicki May said a fire line had been partially completed along the fire's northeastern perimeter, and air tankers made passes over the northwestern corner to aid ground crews in snuffing stubborn hot spots. But while crews made against the blaze during the morning, wind out of the south picked up early in the afternoon, pushing flames northward through oak brush and pine trees left tinder-dry by drought. About 300 homes were evacuated in the fire's path. Uinta spokesman Bevan Killpack said the two dead firefighters were working on a ridge late Sunday, trying to build a fire line with a bulldozer, when flames ``blew up (and) confused them.'' The pair apparently were overcome by smoke, although their bodies were severely burned when they were found. ``The wind must have changed and got them disoriented with the smoke and trapped them in there,'' Killpack said. The victims were identified as Wasatch County Sheriff's Deputy Blake Wright, 39, of Heber City, and Ralph Broadhead, 65, a county public works employee. Sheriff Edd Thacker said the two were trapped between the fire and a cliff and cleared wood and brush away with a bulldozer in a vain attempt to avoid the flames. ``They did what they were supposed to do. They tried what they knew how, but it was a firestorm,'' he said. ``Investigators estimate that 1,100-degree temperatures went through there. That's like a blowtorch.'' Gov. Norm Bangerter, who flew over the fire area late Monday morning, offered his sympathy to the victims' families. Atop Faucett Canyon, Dale Jablonski, area forester for State Lands and Forestry, supervised firefighters cutting a line between the blaze and a nearby cabin Monday. ``What we're trying to do now is get a safety zone where we can make a stand, and if the fire makes a run at us, we can get out,'' he said, watching his crew and a bulldozer clear away trees and brush. In Midway, about 100 people gathered outside the town hall to watch the fire and look over a map of the area. Most were cabin owners trying to figure out if their summer homes lay in the fire's path. ``I'm a homeowner, well, I guess lot owner now,'' lamented Louis Cardon, whose $150,000 cabin in the Devil's Hole area was one of the first to be gutted by flames. Norval Lambert was waiting to hear whether his cabin in Lime Canyon was safe. The fire was just one ridge away from his home, he said. Lambert said his cabin, which he began building in 1971, was filled with antiques. ``There's some stuff there I just can't replace. You can't put a value on it.'' The firefighting force included crews from the U.S. Forest Service, the state, the National Park Service, Wasatch County, Utah State Prison and the cities of Provo, Orem, Lehi, Pleasant Grove and American Fork.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Aug. 20-27:
DOC.HEAD: `Open' Saudi Coverage Leads to Disbanded Press Pool
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon disbanded its Persian Gulf news media pool Aug. 26, saying it is not needed because open coverage is now being permitted. ``The decision by the government of Saudi Arabia to allow reporters from the U.S. and other countries to cover the military operation in the Gulf region makes it unnecessary to continue the National Media Pool,'' the Defense Department said. The 17-member pool had been filing press and broadcast reports and transmitting still photographs daily since its arrival in Saudi Arabia Aug. 13. The decision came four days after President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said they would welcome freer media access to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. At that time they said it would be up to the Saudis to allow it. Bush and Cheney were questioned after reports that the Saudis were beginning to restrict media coverage and considering whether to order most foreign journalists out of the country. Eleven major news organizations expressed concern about reporting restrictions in Saudi Arabia in a letter Aug. 22 to Bush. The media said ``minimum access'' had been available through the Defense Department pool and extremely limited unilateral representation, with more severe limitations in the offing. ``We respectfully request that the administration do everything in its power to gain full media access to Saudi Arabia and to the American presence there,'' the groups said. ``Perhaps accreditation through the American military would be the correct solution.'' The letter was signed by officials in the Washington bureaus of ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN; The Associated Press; Time and Newsweek magazines; and The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times.
DOC.HEAD: American Troops Hungry for News of Home
DOC.TEXT: An American Marine from New York had one question when he arrived in this desert kingdom: ``Are the Mets in first?'' Most of the thousands of U.S. service men and women here have no access to American publications or any television, so they incessantly ask visiting reporters about the situation back home. ``Do the American people want us here?'' an Army private on a desert exercise last week wanted to know. ``Is President Bush saying we'll go to war?'' asked an Air Force supply officer. A mimeographed newsletter attempts to fill the void with a story headlined: ``Secretary of Defense Explains Why We Are Here.'' But it does little to satisfy the appetite of the news-hungry Americans. ``The situation is very uncertain,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says in the newsletter. ``We don't know how long it will last.'' However, there were signs the troops will be getting more access to the news. A daily shipment of newspapers was sent to some camps last week. ``They get passed around and read again and again and again,'' said a spokesman for the 82nd Airborne Division. ``The guys are hungry for news.'' A few issues of the military newspaper Stars & Stripes have turned up, and the small newsletter that carried Cheney's remarks is being published at one Saudi airbase where U.S. forces are positioned. Iraq is trying to fill the news void with radio broadcasts suggesting that while Americans are protecting Saudi oil fields the ``petrol emirs'' are in the United States and have ``enjoyed'' the company of American women. ``I thought it was pretty funny, actually,'' said a member of the 82nd Airborne who listened to the broadcast. ``If that's their idea of psychological warfare I don't think we have much to worry about.'' The Saudi media also has had its fair share of recent propaganda. Local television, which can be seen by some U.S. forces staying in hotels or Saudi barracks, frequently includes lengthy segments showing the arrival and exercises of troops in the kingdom. There is no narration, but patriotic music booms. Saudi papers carry daily dispatches from a state press agency designed to assure the public that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will not affect Saudi Arabia's food supplies, economy or security. In the United States, a Chicago cable television company is producing free 30-second video greetings from family and friends of soldiers sent to the Mideast. Edward K. Conklin, spokesman for Jones' Intercable Inc., said the military has agreed to broadcast the ``Cable Grams From Home'' to U.S. ships in the Persian Gulf. He said arrangements were being made to broadcast the greetings to troops on land, too. The company will produce the videos this week at its 10 studios in suburban Chicago, Conklin said. ``We know people who have not had the chance to say goodbye to family and friends,'' Conklin said. ``We had one lady who was contacted and all she got was a call from a computer that private so-and-so had been shipped to the Persian Gulf and no other information was available.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Says Rape Victims' Names Not Confidential
DOC.TEXT: Iowa police must release the names of most rape victims to the news media, the state attorney general's office said Aug. 24. Newspaper editors and broadcasters said they would continue to protect the names. In response to a request by Gov. Terry Branstad, assistant attorney general Gordon Allen said state law does not permit police to keep the names of rape victims confidential. The only exception is when release of the name would jeopardize the investigation or put the victim in danger, he said. A spokesman for Branstad said the governor would seek to change the law to assure confidentiality. Allen's opinion was criticized by a victim services counselor, who said it would make sexual assault victims reluctant to report crimes. The issue came up earlier this year when The Des Moines Register challenged the practice by Des Moines police of routinely suppressing names and other information about rape victims. The department has since released the names, but none has been used in news stories.
DOC.HEAD: Author Sues New York Times Over Book Review
DOC.TEXT: An investigative reporter angered by The New York Times' review of his book on the alleged links between organized crime and the National Football League filed a $10 million libel lawsuit against the paper Aug. 23. Dan E. Moldea filed suit in U.S. District Court in Washington over the newspaper's Sept. 3, 1989, review of his book, ``Interference: How Organized Crime Influences Professional Football.'' The newspaper's top attorney expressed confidence the suit would be thrown out of court and said the review was based ``on accurate facts.'' The review by Times sportswriter Gerald Eskenazi said, in part, that Moldea's book contains ``sloppy journalism'' as well as ``errors and unfounded insinuations.'' The lawsuit alleges the review ``was intended to protect the NFL by personally attacking Moldea, discrediting his reputation and smearing his good name as a careful investigative reporter.'' ``The review gave false impressions through use of false and misleading examples intended to injure Moldea's reputation, impeach Moldea's honesty and integrity and destroyed the likelihood that `Interference' would become a widely read book by the public,'' the suit says. Moldea said in an interview that his publisher, William Morrow and Co. Inc., had printed 33,000 copies of the book because initial sales had been strong. But after the Times' review came out, sales dropped off precipitously, and only about 21,000 were sold, he said. ``This thing could have been stopped so long ago had they just published a correction or my letter'' that countered, point by point, statements in the review, Moldea said. Eskenazi declined comment on the matter, referring questions to Times executives ``even though this is something I'm appalled at when people do it to me.'' The Times' senior attorney, George Freeman, said he had not seen the lawsuit, but he was familiar with the case. ``We're totally convinced that the suit will be dismissed,'' Freeman said. A book review is ``protected opinion, particularly where a review is based on accurate facts, as this one is.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Editor Files Countersuit Against Town
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper editor sued the town of West Hartford on Aug. 22, claiming the Hartford suburb violated his rights when it sued him for writing an editorial critical of the way an anti-abortion protest was handled. John Spear, editor of the Orange County Post, a Washingtonville, N.Y., weekly, claimed in the federal suit that the town tried to ``intimidate, harass, censor and silence a free press'' when it sued him for alleged racketeering and extortion. Spear did not take part in either of two large anti-abortion protests in West Hartford in 1989. But the town named him in its June 1989 racketeering lawsuit against anti-abortion activists, claiming his April 4 editorial, ``Northern Red Necks,'' expressed support for illegal anti-abortion activities. He was dropped from the suit in December 1989. ``If the freedom of the press means anything, it means that we can criticize the government harshly. That's what Mr. Spear did,'' Joseph Secola, Spear's attorney, said at a news conference. ``They had absolutely no legal basis for suing him,'' Secola said. ``They viciously abused the legal process.'' Spears' suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Hartford, seeks unspecified punitive and compensatory damages. Patrick G. Alair, the assistant corporation counsel for West Hartford, said Spear's involvement in the protest went beyond writing the editorial. He noted that one of Spear's employees was arrested in the protest. Still, he said, the town dropped Spears from the suit because of concerns over Spear's First Amendment rights. ``We did not want the real issues in the case to be clouded up with a First Amendment issue,'' Alair said. ``As a legal issue, (Spear) is a newspaper person. There is an issue of freedom of the press there.'' Spear's editorial said anti-abortion protesters at an April 1 demonstration in West Hartford suffered police brutality and were denied their civil rights. The town claimed Spear ``deliberately and maliciously published an incorrect, defamatory account'' of the protest. The town did not allege libel, however. Instead, the town relied on the racketeering law and claimed Spear's editorial was an attempt to ``extort a less diligent or softened response from the West Hartford Police Department to future protest activities.'' It also said Spear, as editor of the Orange County Post, ``has actively supported the illegal activities of Operation Rescue through that medium.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Reporter Doesn't Have To Turn Over Notes
DOC.TEXT: A municipal judge ruled Aug. 20 that a newspaper reporter does not have to turn over to defense attorneys a set of confidential notes on a murder case. ``We have to weigh the tremendous interests of the defendants against the profound interest of society'' in a free press, Municipal Court Judge Carol A. Corrigan said. Attorneys for three men accused in a 2-year-old murder had demanded to see the notes of Harry Harris, a crime reporter for The Tribune.
