In 1988, Harris interviewed a key police informant and wrote a story based on that discussion; defense attorneys said the notes contain evidence that could clear their clients. But Corrigan ruled that turning over the notes _ which she viewed after being ordered to do so by a higher court _ would have ``a chilling effect'' on the ability of reporters to interview confidential sources. ``Reporters should take heart from this decision,'' said Tribune attorney Judith Epstein. ``It is an extraordinarily important case.'' The case was the first major test of reporters' rights in California since earlier this year when the state Supreme Court, in a case called Delaney vs. Superior Court, weakened protection afforded reporters by California's Shield Law, Epstein said. The Delaney ruling makes it easier for lawyers to demonstrate that previously protected reporters' notes and other confidential information may be seized and used in court.
DOC.HEAD: Cincinnati Post Sues Sheriff Over Personnel Records
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Post has asked the Ohio Supreme Court to order Hamilton County Sheriff Simon Leis to make public the personnel records of 20 of his deputies. The Post claimed in its suit that Leis violated Ohio's public records law by denying reporter Molly Kavanaugh access to the records. The suit, filed Aug. 23, also asks the court to hold an expedited hearing on its request for the records. Ms. Kavanaugh, as part of an investigative story about hiring and employment practices in the sheriff's department, made a written request to Leis for the records on June 26, according to the Post's complaint. Ms. Kavanaugh had requested personnel records of people promoted from the department's corrections division to its patrol division since Jan. 1, 1989, and 10 other department employees. Leis on July 2 provided the newspaper with a list of people appointed to the patrol division, but he refused access to any personnel files, citing confidentiality provisions in two union contracts. The newspaper then sent Leis a letter noting an Ohio Supreme Court ruling that union contracts do not permit local governments to deny access to police personnel files that are public record. Leis responded with a letter saying he was seeking a lawyer's advice on the issue. Frank Weikel, a spokesman for Leis, said the department had no comment on the suit.
DOC.HEAD: Actress Demands Enquirer Give Up Negative
DOC.TEXT: Actress Lisa Bonet wants a federal judge to order the National Enquirer to hand over a negative of her baby daughter. Attorneys for ``The Cosby Show'' actress filed a motion in U.S. District Court on Aug. 20 asking a federal judge to make ``the seedier elements of the paparazzi'' produce a stolen negative of the actress' baby girl, Zoe. Zoe Kravitz was only a month old when Bonet's mother, Arlene Boney, left a roll of film to be developed at a Reseda, Calif., store owned by American Drug Stores Inc., attorneys say. When a missing photo from the roll appeared in the National Enquirer's Jan. 10, 1989, issue, Bonet and her mother sued the store chain. Bonet's attorneys say the Enquirer's original negative will prove that a drugstore clerk stole it. Claiming they are protected by the First Amendment from revealing sources, Enquirer employees refuse to say how much they paid for the film and who sold it to them.
DOC.HEAD: Thomson Buys Controlling Interest in Pasadena Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Thomson Newspaper Group has purchased a majority interest in the Pasadena Star-News, giving a subsidiary control of three Southern California newspapers with combined circulation of 124,000. The San Gabriel Valley Tribune Inc., which is owned by Toronto-based Thomson, said it had acquired controlling interest in the Star-News by purchasing common stock from Texas media magnate William Dean Singleton. Officials declined to release terms of the deal Aug. 22. Singleton is not a publicly traded company and is not compelled to divulge such information. Singleton bought the 103-year-old Star-News for $55 million in June 1989 from the Knight-Ridder newspaper group. The Thomson group now controls three Los Angeles County newspapers: the 43,000-circulation Star-News, the 63,000-circulation San Gabriel Valley Daily Tribune in West Covina and the 18,000-circulation Whittier Daily News. Singleton, whose MediaNews Group owns such papers as the Houston Post and the Denver Post, retains a minority stake in the Star-News, said F. Al Totter, president of San Gabriel Valley Newspaper Management Co.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Left to Charitable Trust
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Stuart James Grant, owner of The Register & Bee, left the newspaper to a charitable trust when she died Aug. 7. Her son, W. Lawson Grant Jr., publisher of the paper, said Aug. 22 he believes there will be few changes and the newspaper will remain under local control. ``Mother's estate was set up so that it will continue that way.'' Mrs. Grant inherited the paper from her father when she was 17 and retained sole ownership. Her grandfather acquired the Register in 1897 and founded the afternoon paper, the Bee, two years later. Her will was probated in Danville Circuit Court. It named a local bank as executor and trustee and called for income from her multimillion-dollar trust to be given to four schools and five charities. The will leaves no money to Mrs. Grant's four children or any other descendants.
DOC.HEAD: Two Texas Newspapers for Sale
DOC.TEXT: Worrell Enterprises said it is offering the Greenville Herald Banner and the Bryan-College Station Eagle for sale. Eagle Publisher Dennis E. Thomas said the move is designed to diversify the Charlottesville, Va.-based company's holdings. Worrell said in a news release that ``the core of the company will remain in the newspaper business.'' Worrell bought the Eagle from Harte-Hanks Newspapers Inc. in January 1988.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: U.S. Information Agency Overrated Viewership
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has vastly overestimated the viewership of TV Marti, whose broadcasts since March have been marked by Cuban government jamming, according to a congressional report Aug. 25. The U.S. Information Agency had estimated 1 million to 7 million Cubans watched the new station, which broadcasts American entertainment and news shows to the communist-ruled island from Florida. But the General Accounting Office, in an unpublished report obtained by The Miami Herald, cited notes by U.S. diplomats who estimated an audience of only 50,000 to 70,000. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, faulted the USIA's methods in two viewership surveys, which polled Cuban refugees and emigres arriving at Miami International Airport between March 28 and May 12. The survey subjects ``would be more interested in and aware of TV Marti than the general population'' because they were leaving Cuba, the GAO said.
DOC.HEAD: TV Studio Goes Off the Air as Police Search for Pizza Robber
DOC.TEXT: A television station went off the air the night of Aug. 25 when police evacuated studios to conduct their third search of the day for an armed robber. After 25 minutes of dead air, Chicago station WLS-TV resumed broadcasting at a jury-rigged studio in the Sears Tower. It issued a special newscast to let viewers know what had happened. The station went off the air again 15 minutes later as police using scent dogs searched the 13-story studio building. A man thought to be armed with a pistol was seen entering the building that morning, not long after a nearby pizza restaurant was robbed, police said. Two daytime searches failed to locate the man, but repeated sightings by station employees prompted the studio evacuation and third search at about 8:30 p.m., Lt. Frank Kehoe said.
DOC.HEAD: Ted Turner Enters New Arena _ Books
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner is about to take his first step into the world of book publishing, but he isn't assuming the role of giant-slayer this time out. Turner Publishing Inc. is beginning as a modest venture with little of the brashness that has accompanied other Turner projects. Turner's startup of Cable News Network 10 years ago, for instance, included a prediction that newspapers would die out. ``We don't have any intention of becoming a Random House or Simon & Schuster. Publishing is not the main business of TBS, and it never will be,'' said Michael Reagan, vice president and publisher of Turner Publishing. Turner Publishing, a subsidiary of Turner Broadcasting System, releases its first book, a coffee-table volume of Reagan's photographs, next month. The book, ``Portrait of Great Britain and Northern Ireland,'' is tied to a TBS mini-series. Most of what follows also will be tied to TBS programming, especially the company's vast movie library. Set for a Valentine's Day release is ``Kisses,'' a photo collection of silver screen smooches ranging from Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh in ``Gone With the Wind'' to Groucho Marx and Margaret Dumont in ``A Night at the Opera.'' TBS will show a one-hour ``Kisses'' special to coincide with thet book's release. The publishing company is the latest _ and smallest _ venture of TBS. Its initial budget is less than $2 million, Reagan said. Turner Publishing evolved from the TBS chairman's creation of the Turner Tomorrow Award, in which a $500,000 prize is offered for a novel that addresses positive solutions to global problems. The award carries a promise to publish the winning manuscript and, Reagan said, ``it became apparent we'd need a publishing company.''
DOC.HEAD: Miss America 1989 Hired as TV Reporter
DOC.TEXT: Miss America 1989, Gretchen Carlson, has been hired as WRIC-TV's ``Neighborhood News'' reporter. She previously worked as a free-lance reporter and talk show guest host for KSTP-TV in Minneapolis. ``Certainly Miss America helped bring (Miss Carlson) to our attention, but I hired her as a reporter,'' said Wayne Lynch, WRIC's news director. ``She certainly got a lot of on-camera experience last year, but we're really trying to stay out of the Miss America business here.''
DOC.HEAD: CBS News President Departing
DOC.TEXT: CBS News President David Burke said Aug. 23 he would resign at the end of the month. Eric Ober, a 24-year CBS veteran and president of the CBS Television Stations division, was named to replace him. Burke, 54, a former ABC News executive vice president, had two more years to go on his contract. Ober previously worked at CBS News as vice president for public affairs. Burke's exit marked the second high-level change in network news of the summer. Earlier in August, former Los Angeles Times Publisher Tom Johnson succeeded Burt Reinhardt, 70, as president of Ted Turner's Cable News Network.
DOC.HEAD: Salembier Resigns as New York Post President
DOC.TEXT: The New York Post announced the resignation of Valerie Salembier as president Aug. 23. Post owner and publisher Peter Kalikow said he would reassume the title of president. Howard Rubenstein, spokesman for the newspaper, said Kalikow had not asked Salembier to resign. He added that she was not leaving for a specific position elsewhere. Kalikow bought the newspaper, then losing money, from Rupert Murdoch in 1988. He hired Salembier, the former publisher of TV Guide, the next year. Last November the Post discontinued its 8-month-old Sunday edition, which failed to attract sufficient advertisers or readers and lost millions of dollars.
DOC.HEAD: Butler Appointed Editorial Page Editor in Oakland, Calif.
DOC.TEXT: Mary Ellen Butler became editorial page editor of The Tribune on Aug. 24, replacing Jonathan Marshall, who left to become economics editor for the San Francisco Chronicle. Butler started at the paper as features editor and spent the past seven years writing editorials.
DOC.HEAD: Martello Named AP's Correspondent in Trenton, N.J.
DOC.TEXT: Thomas J. Martello, a newsman in the Trenton bureau of The Associated Press, was promoted to correspondent in charge of the bureau Aug. 22. He succeeds Jo Astrid Glading, who resigned to take a job with New Jersey state government. Martello joined the AP in Trenton in 1988. He previously worked for the Watertown (N.Y.) Daily Times and The Times of Trenton.

Myron J. Bennett, a combative radio host-turned-politician, died of cancer Aug. 19. He was 82. Bennett built a big following in the 1940s with his tart commentary on the city's politics on radio station KSO. In 1948, he was elected the city's public safety commissioner. He was charged during his first year in office with involvement in a conspiracy to collect kickbacks from tavern owners. The charges were later dismissed. He lost his city post in 1950 when Des Moines changed its form of government. A Republican, Bennett then switched his party affiliation and ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for governor.

Frances Bilderback Bowen, a longtime columnist for the Today's Sunbeam of Salem, died Aug. 19. She was 91. Miss Bowen joined Sunbeam Publishing Co. in 1946 as a columnist, news writer and treasurer. She retired in 1981.

Claude L. ``Tiny'' Day, a sports journalist who played and promoted country music, died Aug. 24 of a heart attack. He was 63. Day was sports editor of The Greeneville Sun for more than 40 years. He performed with a country group known as The Sauceman Brothers and The Hillbilly Ramblers for four years after serving with the Marines in World War II. Day also performed with groups at the Grand Ole Opry until recent years and served as a part-time promoter of area appearances by top country entertainers. Survivors include his wife and two sons, two sisters and a brother.

Irwin Albert Lewis, a former CBS and NBC pollster credited with conducting the first exit polls and director of the Los Angeles Times Poll since its creation in 1979, died Aug. 18 of cancer. He was 68. Lewis was a civilian employee of the Armed Forces Network in West Germany during the 1950s, working as a news writer and bureau chief. He later worked for UPI and Armed Forces Radio and in 1956-57 wrote for Dave Garroway on the original ``Today'' show. Lewis later joined the NBC election unit, becoming its director of polling in 1966 and director of elections in 1969. He was named director of polling for the CBS News-New York Times Poll in 1976. He joined the Roper Organization the following year.

Patrick E. Malloy Jr., retired night managing editor of the Tribune-Democrat, died Aug. 23 of lung cancer in North Haven, N.Y. He was 82. Malloy working for the Johnstown Democrat as a copy boy in 1927, and later served as sports and night city editor. He retired in 1973.

Stella Mae Roberts, a longtime reporter with The Associated Press and a former national secretary-treasurer of the Wire Service Guild, died Aug. 25 after a long illness. She was 67. Ms. Roberts joined the AP in Oklahoma City in 1945 and worked there 31 years, much of that time in the capitol bureau. After retiring in 1976, she became public information director of the Oklahoma Employment Security Commission. Survivors include a niece and two nephews.

William H. Rudy, a former New York Post racing columnist, died of liver cancer Aug. 21. He was 79. Rudy started his career in Chicago as a baseball writer. He joined the Post in the 1950s and stayed there for 20 years as a racing columnist and political writer. He is survived by his wife, a son, a daughter and three grandchildren.

Ward Sims, an Associated Press writer whose career included stints as correspondent in Juneau and Fairbanks and bureau chief in Anchorage, died Aug. 22 of a heart attack. He was 65. Sims joined the AP in San Francisco in 1950. He became correspondent in Tacoma, Wash., in 1951 and later that year transferred to Seattle. In 1960, he became Alaska statehouse correspondent in Juneau. In 1968, he transferred to the Philadelphia bureau and a year later became a national desk editor in New York. He returned to Alaska to open a Fairbanks bureau in 1977 and a year later became bureau chief in Anchorage. He retired in 1984. In 1964 he covered a devastating earthquake in Alaska. His last byline for the news service was a retrospective article about the disaster, published last year on the earthquake's 25th anniversary. Survivors include his wife and son.
DOC.HEAD: National Geographic Writer Wins Journalism Award
DOC.TEXT: National Geographic senior writer Michael W. Edwards won the John Pennington Award for outstanding journalism Aug. 18. Edwards, of Washington, received $3,000 and said he would use the award to study the Russian language and the Soviet Union at Harvard University. The award is administered by John Pennington Award Inc., a non-profit foundation set up by Pennington's widow, Marilyn, and Ellis Clifton of Atlanta. Mrs. Pennington said the foundation was impressed with a story Edwards did on the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union and one from Nicaragua in 1985. Edwards was an Atlanta Journal reporter who exposed stuffed ballot boxes in Quitman County in 1962 when Jimmy Carter was running for the state Senate. Had the fraud gone unreported, Carter, who later was elected governor and then president, would have lost the election. He has said he would have quit politics had he lost the '62 race.
DOC.HEAD: East European Journalists Named Times Mirror Fellows
DOC.TEXT: Eight journalists from Eastern Europe have been chosen as Times Mirror Fellows and will work at U.S. newspapers in three-month sessions this fall. The reporters and editors from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland will start Sept. 4 in Washington with a two-seek orientation meeting. Then they begin assignments at the Los Angeles Times, Newsday and New York Newsday, The Sun and The Evening Sun in Baltimore, The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, The Morning Call in Allentown, Pa., The Advocate in Stamford, Conn., and the Greenwich (Conn.) Time. The program is managed by the Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press in Washington.

Consumption of newsprint by daily newspapers increased slightly the first seven months of 1990 from a year earlier, the American Newspaper Publishers Association said. The trade group estimated consumption rose from 5,223,757 metric tons to 5,246,353 tons. Consumption in July fell slightly, from 719,080 tons a year ago to 718,651 tons.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists digging in for a new assault on what they consider sacrosanct energy reserves as threatened oil shortages and rising gasoline prices spurred by the Persian Gulf crisis start biting into American pocketbooks. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was only a few days old when Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, persuaded colleagues to approve a measure that would make it easier to expand oil drilling on federal land, bypassing some environmental restrictions. The oil industry was just as quick to call for abandoning recent curbs on offshore oil drilling, relaxing requirements for cleaner burning gasoline and drilling in some environmentally sensitive areas. Although neither Murkowski's nor any of the other proposals has won final congressional approval, environmentalists fear an intensified push by industry to win relief from hard-fought environmental gains when Congress returns from summer recess after Labor Day.

Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has ravaged the Hollywood of the Middle East, depriving Egypt's film industry of the Kuwaiti money that keeps the reels turning. Producers, actors and directors in the region's largest film industry watch with worry as each day of occupation costs them thousands of dollars in lost ticket revenues and financial backing. And next to suffer may be the movie-going public. ``For Arabs, Egyptian films are the main source of entertainment,'' said Munib Shafei, chairman of the Egyptian Chamber for Movie Industries. ``And this invasion has caused severe problems for our industry.'' Egyptian studios have been the center of Arabic movie-making for six decades and produce an average of 60 films annually. About 80 percent of foreign financial backing for the films comes from the Arab oil states of the Persian Gulf, mainly Kuwait.

A 72-year-old man charged with helping his wife commit suicide has been bailed out of jail by a bondsman he had never met. ``This man is not a criminal. He was just trying to do the right thing for someone he loved,'' said Carl Wardlaw, who posted the $25,000 that got Bertram Harper out of jail Sunday. Harper, of Loomis, Calif., is charged with murder and conspiracy in the Aug. 19 suicide of his 69-year-old wife, Virginia Lee, in a Romulus hotel room. Mrs. Harper, who reportedly had cancer, flew to Michigan on Aug. 18. Police said she killed herself by taking pills and putting a plastic bag over her head while her husband and stepdaughter stood by.

A wind-driven brush fire that mushroomed from 120 acres to 2,500 in an afternoon destroyed dozens of homes and threatened 300 more today. About 200 firefighters battled the blaze overnight, and fire bosses issued a call for 160 more, officials said. Dozens of residents were evacuated from the path of the flames, which were sent racing by canyon winds gusting to 40 mph. Flames consumed at least 39 homes, authorities said. No injuries were reported. Top priority was given to saving the 300 homes in the Devil's Hole, Lime Canyon and Snake Creek areas. The homes destroyed were in Devil's Hole, said Uinta National Park spokeswoman Loyal Clark. The fire was partly in the park.

Black and white leaders reached a tentative agreement to give blacks equal representation on the Selma school board and end eight months of racial strife, the mayor says. ``We're trying to throw politics out the window and reach some kind of agreement that everybody can live with,'' Mayor Joe Smitherman said. City Council members and Smitherman met with about two dozen black leaders Sunday night to draw up the agreement, he said. Smitherman said ``there are still questions to be answered'' but that he hoped to announce the details today. The proposal would end white dominance of the school board and ultimately establish a plan to alternate control between the two factions, said Smitherman, who is white. The 5,900-student district is about 80 percent black.

Rescuers Monday recovered the bodies of 69 coal miners and tunneled toward about 100 others trapped by an explosion, although there was no sign they were alive. Yugoslavia's federal trade union demanded that all those responsible for the accident, including local officials and government ministers, resign. The cause of what would be Yugoslavia's worst mining accident has not been determined, but the investigation is focusing on an accumulation of coal dust or methane gas. One miner who was working near the surface was pulled out of the mine alive shortly after the blast early Sunday. Bosko Zelic, a member of the Kreka mine's managing board, told reporters it was unlikely any more survivors would be found.

Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party declared Monday that an abortion dispute must not be allowed to torpedo a treaty merging the two Germanys' laws. ``The treaty must not fail for any reason,'' said Volker Ruehe, general secretary of Kohl's Christian Democrats. ``Agreement is needed in the next few days.'' The opposition Social Democrats have threatened to scuttle the treaty if Kohl goes ahead with a decision to extend West Germany's abortion restrictions to East German turf. Kohl and top members of his coalition met into Monday's early morning hours with Social Democrat leaders to discuss the abortion dispute. A deadlock persisted, and another meeting was set for Wednesday.

The Libyan government ``provided direct support in all phases of preparation'' for an unsuccessful May 30 terrorist attack on jammed beach resorts near Tel Aviv, Israel, the State Department said Monday. In a paper it said was based on information from U.S. sources, the department said the six assault boats used in the raid were launched from the merchant ship Tiny Star, known earlier as the Inger M. It said Libya provided personnel who accompanied the ship as it sailed from a Libyan naval base to Ras el-Hilal, on Libya's Mediterranean coast. There it picked up at least 16 terrorists of the Palestine Liberation Front.

Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa broke off talks Monday with Indians involved in a seven-week armed standoff with authorities and ordered the army to tear down Mohawk barricades in two Quebec communities. The premier said the Mohawks had not been negotiating in good faith, and he was therefore obliged to assume his responsibility for public order. The premier did not say how or when the army would move to take down the barricades in the communities of Oka and Chateauguay. At Bourassa's request, troops replaced Quebec provincial police at the barricades a week ago. Mohawk negotiators could not be reached immediately for comment on Bourassa's decision.

Existing home sales rose for a second straight month in July but analysts predicted a slowdown because of rising mortgage rates linked to the Mideast crisis. The National Association of Realtors said Monday that house resales rose 3.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units in July following a 0.9 percent gain in June. The June advance was the first in seven months.

United Auto Workers leaders met behind closed doors to map out strategy for the final three weeks of bargaining with the nation's Big Three automakers and to choose a bargaining ``target.'' The UAW was expected to announce its target company on Tuesday. The union's contracts with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire Sept. 14.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Sept. 3, the 246th day of 1990. There are 119 days left in the year. This is Labor Day.
Today's highlight in history: On Sept. 3, 1783, the Treaty of Paris between the United States and Great Britain officially ended the Revolutionary War.
On this date: In 1189, England's King Richard I (the Lion-Hearted) was crowned in Westminster. In 1658, Oliver Cromwell, the Lord Protector of England, died. In 1939, Britain and France declared war on Germany, two days after the Nazi invasion of Poland. In 1940, 50 years ago, Artie Shaw and his Gramercy Five recorded ``Summit Ridge Drive,'' ``Special Delivery Stomp,'' ``Keepin' Myself for You'' and ``Cross Your Heart'' for RCA Victor in Hollywood. In 1943, Allied forces invaded Italy in World War II. In 1951, the television soap opera ``Search for Tomorrow'' made its debut on CBS. In 1967, Nguyen Van Thieu was elected president of South Vietnam under a new constitution. In 1967, motorists in Sweden began driving on the right-hand side of the road. In 1967, the original version of the television game show ``What's My Line?,'' hosted by John Charles Daly, broadcast its final episode after more than 17 years on CBS. In 1970, football coach Vince Lombardi died in Washington, D.C. In 1976, the unmanned U.S. spacecraft Viking II landed on Mars to take the first close-up, color photographs of the planet's surface. In 1978, Pope John Paul I was installed as the 264th supreme pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church. In 1979, Hurricane David smashed trailers and beachfront condominiums along the central Florida coast, leaving several people dead and millions of dollars in damage.
Ten years ago: Most workers in Poland who had gone on strike were reported back on the job after major concessions by the government, including the right to form independent trade unions. Five years ago: The space shuttle Discovery landed at Edwards Air Force Base in California, ending a seven-day mission that included the retrieval, repair and redeployment of a malfunctioning satellite. One year ago: The United States began shipping a $65 million package of military aircraft and weapons to help Colombia fight its war against drug lords.
Today's Birthdays: Actress Kitty Carlisle Hart is 76. Cartoonist Mort Walker is 67. Actress Anne Jackson is 64. Actress Irene Papas is 64. Time magazine contributing editor Hugh Sidey is 63. Actress Eileen Brennan is 55. Actress Pauline Collins is 50. Beach Boy Al Jardine is 48. Actress Valerie Perrine is 47. Actor Charlie Sheen is 25.
Thought for Today: ``Labor is prior to, and independent of, capital. Capital is only the fruit of labor, and could never have existed if labor had not first existed. Labor is the superior of capital, and deserves much the higher consideration.'' _Abraham Lincoln, U.S. president (1809-1865).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Sept. 5, the 248th day of 1990. There are 117 days left in the year.
Today's Highlight in History: On Sept. 5, 1905, the Treaty of Portsmouth ending the Russo-Japanese War was signed in New Hampshire, President Theodore Roosevelt having mediated the settlement.
On this date: In 1698, Russia's Peter the Great imposed a tax on beards. In 1774, the first Continental Congress assembled in Philadelphia. In 1836, Sam Houston was elected president of the Republic of Texas. In 1882, the nation's first Labor Day parade was held in New York. In 1914, the First Battle of the Marne began during World War I. In 1939, the United States proclaimed its neutrality in World War II. In 1945, Iva Toguri D'Aquino _ a Japanese-American suspected of being radio broadcaster ``Tokyo Rose'' _ was arrested in Yokohama. (She served six years for treason, but was pardoned in 1977 by President Ford.) In 1957, ``On the Road,'' a novel by leading Beat author Jack Kerouac, was first published. In 1958, ``Doctor Zhivago,'' a novel by Russian author Boris Pasternak, was published in the United States for the first time. In 1975, President Ford escaped an attempt on his life when Lynette ``Squeaky'' Fromme, a disciple of Charles Manson, attempted to shoot the chief executive in Sacramento, Calif. In 1972, eleven Israeli athletes and five Arab guerrillas who had taken them hostage were killed in a shootout with West German police during the summer Olympics in Munich. In 1977, West German industrialist Hanns-Martin Schleyer was kidnapped in Cologne by members of the Baader-Meinhof gang. (Schleyer was later murdered by his captors.) In 1977, seemingly in reverse order, the United States launched the Voyager I spacecraft two weeks after launching its twin, Voyager II. In 1984, the space shuttle Discovery completed its maiden flight as it landed at Edwards Air Force Base in California.
Ten years ago: The government reported the nation's unemployment rate had dropped .2 percent in August 1980 to 7.6 percent, while wholesale prices jumped 1.5 percent. Five years ago: Violence continued near Cape Town, South Africa, where rioting against white-minority rule had spilled into white neighborhoods for the first time. One year ago: In his first nationally broadcast address from the White House, President Bush outlined a plan to fight illicit drugs, which he called the ``quicksand of our entire society.''
Today's birthdays: Composer John Cage is 78. The president of the Motion Picture Association of America, Jack Valenti, is 69. Former Federal Reserve Board chairman Paul Volcker is 63. Comedian-actor Bob Newhart is 61. U.S. Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., is 54. Actor William Devane is 51. Actress Raquel Welch is 50. ``Cathy'' cartoonist Cathy Guisewite is 40.
Thought for today: ``Those who foresee the future and recognize it as tragic are often seized by a madness which forces them to commit the very acts which makes it certain that what they dread shall happen.'' _Dame Rebecca West, Irish author and journalist (1892-1983).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Sept. 8, the 251st day of 1990. There are 114 days left in the year.
Today's highlight in history: On Sept. 8, 1935, Sen. Huey P. Long, the ``Kingfish'' of Louisiana politics, was shot and mortally wounded inside the state capitol in Baton Rouge. He died two days later.
On this date: In 1565, a Spanish expedition established the first permanent European settlement in North America at what is now St. Augustine, Fla. In 1664, the Dutch surrendered New Amsterdam to the British, who renamed it New York. In 1889, U.S. Sen. Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who came to be known as ``Mr. Republican,'' was born in Cincinnati. In 1892, an early version of ``The Pledge of Allegiance'' appeared in ``The Youth's Companion.'' In 1900, Galveston, Texas, was struck by a hurricane that killed about 6,000 people. In 1920, New York-to-San Francisco air mail service was inaugurated. In 1921, Margaret Gorman of Washington, D.C., was crowned the first Miss America in Atlantic City, N.J. In 1930, 60 years ago, the comic strip ``Blondie'' first appeared. In 1934, 134 people lost their lives in a fire aboard the liner Morro Castle off the New Jersey coast. In 1939, President Franklin D. Roosevelt declared a ``limited national emergency'' in response to the outbreak of war in Europe. In 1951, a peace treaty with Japan was signed by 48 other nations at a conference in San Francisco. In 1952, the novel ``The Old Man and the Sea,'' by Ernest Hemingway, was first published. In 1971, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opened in Washington, D.C., with a performance of Leonard Bernstein's ``Mass.'' In 1974, President Ford granted an unconditional pardon to former President Nixon for any federal crimes committed during his term of office. In 1975, Boston's public schools began their court-ordered citywide busing program amid scattered incidents of violence. In 1988, two nuclear-missile rocket motors were destroyed at an army ammunition plant in Karnack, Texas, the first U.S. weapons to be eliminated under an arms reduction treaty with the Soviet Union.
Ten years ago: President Carter met for an hour with representatives of major Jewish organizations to discuss their concerns about the Middle East. Five years ago: Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds tied Ty Cobb's career record for hits, singling for hit number 4,191 during a game against the Cubs in Chicago. Ivan Lendl defeated John McEnroe to win the men's singles championship at the U.S. Open. One year ago: Former President Reagan underwent surgery at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota to relieve a build-up of fluid in his brain that was apparently caused by a horse-riding accident.
Today's birthdays: Actress Hillary Brooke is 76. Comedian Sid Caesar is 68. The former secretary of housing and urban development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., is 68. U.S. Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., is 66. U.S. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., is 52. Author Ann Beattie is 43.
Thought for today: ``It is more important that a proposition be interesting than that it be true.'' _ Alfred North Whitehead, English philosopher and mathematician (1861-1947).

DOC.HEAD: It's Harder These Days to Draw the Line in the Sand
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, traveling.
DOC.TEXT: When the United States goes to war or comes close to it, it usually invokes one or both of two great purposes: to protect the nation against an imminent threat or to protect the democratic ideal. President Bush is denied those rationales in the Persian Gulf. Instead, he invokes the abstract principle that might should not make right and the pragmatic view that America's ``way of life'' is threatened if one man has the power to control the price and supply of petroleum. The question that remains is whether the American people will support an enterprise based on those purposes. Bush says the lesson of the 1930s is that appeasement of tyrants does not work, and he would not find widespread disagreement with that proposition among his countrymen. However, a public opinion poll probably would uncover virtual unanimous agreement with a counter-balancing proposition: ``The United States cannot be the world's policeman.'' That is a lesson America extracted from the Korean stalemate of the 1950s, the Vietnam failures of the 1970s, the budget deficits of the 1980s. Bush probably would agree. He notes that 23 nations have signed on to the effort to push the Iraqi army of President Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait and back behind the Iraqi border. ``It is Iraq against the world,'' Bush said last week. But Bush wouldn't dispute that, as in Korea and South Vietnam, the chief ally bearing the burden is the United States. The end of the Cold War has denied American presidents the ready explanation that the line had to be drawn against the advance of communism. International communism is no longer a threat. It is not even very international. Its strongest remaining outposts are Cuba, a thorn but not a menace, and China, with which the Bush administration maintains cordial relations. The Soviet Union is Bush's somewhat-silent partner in the Iraqi engagement. The Soviets were the Iraqis' chief arms supplier, which causes the Rev. William Sloane Coffin to observe that the Persian Gulf showdown could not have occurred had the Cold War not ended. ``If the Cold War was still active, the Soviets would never have allowed Iraq to risk a confrontation with the United States,'' Coffin said, because such a confrontation all too easily could have led to an American-Soviet encounter. Part of the history of the last 50 years is how the two superpowers avoided collisions. Coffin, who as chaplain at Yale was spiritual leader of the anti-war movement during the Vietnam era, is critical of Bush's ``enormous'' and ``provocational'' buildup in Saudi Arabia. He argues the effort should have been more genuinely multinational. Just as no realistic communist specter existed for Bush to raise in justifying his course, no democracy was threatened by Saddam's aggression. No democracy existed _ not in the palaces of the emirate of Kuwait or the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Instead, Bush said ``naked aggression'' was at play in Saddam's invasion. He equated Saddam's aggression in the 1990s to Adolf Hitler's in the 1930s and suggested the world could not afford to make the mistake it made then. ``If history teaches us anything, it is that we must resist aggression or it will destroy our freedoms,'' Bush said in a television address Aug. 8 to the nation. ``Appeasement does not work.'' Former Sen. Thomas Eagleton, D-Mo., writing in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, demurs from the claim that appeasement was the issue. ``We acted for one reason and one reason only: O-I-L,'' Eagleton wrote. ``If Mali were to invade Burkina Faso, we would send a letter of deep regret by regular mail.'' A week later, Bush cited the way-of-life argument, declaring before a Pentagon audience, ``Our jobs, our way of life, our own freedom and the freedom of friendly countries around the world would suffer if control of the world's great oil reserves fell into the hands of Saddam Hussein.'' That's unquestionably true, but not much of a rallying cry.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Lunden Celebrates Tenth ``Good Morning America'' Year
DOC.TEXT: With some modest fanfare, Joan Lunden today celebrates her 10th anniversary as co-host of ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' This makes her somewhat extraordinary _ lasting in a job that is a people-eater. ``I have to say I'm surprised that I'm sitting here, being the person who has the most tenure on the morning shows,'' she says, referring to those in the co-host and co-anchor business. ``It seems like it was just yesterday that I was the new kid on the block.'' Her time on active dawn duty goes against tradition. Network morning show stars tend to be television's wandering tribe, often moving on because of their own decisions, management anxiety, or both. Within the last 12 months, six other such stars have left or found new homes, notably Jane Pauley. Succeeded by Deborah Norville as part of the controversial changes that sent once top-rated ``Today'' skidding into second, Pauley is doing well in with prime time NBC News specials after 13 ``Today'' years. ``Today'' news anchor John Palmer, an NBC News veteran, got moved out in that show's shuffle. He left NBC and now has a syndicated series. Faith Daniels left the ``CBS Morning News'' and now has Palmer's old NBC job. Kathleen Sullivan of ``CBS This Morning'' got the gate, and now is pondering her next move. She was succeeded by Paula Zahn, who left ABC's ``World News This Morning.'' And new mother Maria Shriver left NBC's ``Sunday Today'' to have more family time, although she remains with NBC News. But Lunden _ who is only the third female co-host ``Good Morning America'' has had since it began in November 1975 _ has stayed put. Married to television producer Michael Krauss, she's even managed to have three kids during her time on the program. Lunden, who turns 40 next month and this summer signed a new five-year contract with ABC, says she hasn't had any desire to leave ``Good Morning America.'' But then, her life on the show has been relatively serene. And her show, unlike ``Today'' and the shows that represent CBS' many years of efforts to make ratings in the morning, hasn't had the public turmoil of the kind that last year made ``Today'' a daily two-hour soap opera. Lunden, a ceaselessly cheery woman better known for warmth than penetrating interviews, hasn't even had a good headline-making incident, like Sullivan's off-air jabs at CBS management that made their way into print last year. The best Lunden has been able to stir up was a pre-emptive on-air strike this summer. She told viewers that reporters from the tabloid National Enquirer had been poking into her life, asking friends if she'd seemed troubled lately. Why she bothered was a bit puzzling. In any event, the editor of the paper said the queries hadn't turned up anything. Oh well, the nation said, and life went on. Actor David Hartman, who hosted ``Good Morning America'' from the start until newsman Charles Gibson succeeded him in January 1987, was an avuncular man on the air. But off-camera, he was said to be a tough, demanding man, one who wanted it known the show's focus was on him, not his co-host. Despite that, Lunden, who first worked for the show as a consumer reporter in 1976, said she got along fine with Hartman, ``because I just made sure that things (between them) stayed nice all the time. ``I'm not saying that I wasn't very frustrated many times with the real tight restrictions that were put on my abilities to do stories and expand my job. But I didn't allow that to become an issue with David and me. ``Because I knew very clearly that if that happened and that relationship went, everything else was a moot point, I was gone, I was out of there.'' While Hartman was the host, ``Good Morning America'' had a good run as first in ratings. But it started slipping toward the end of his stay, and generally stayed in second until coming on strong last year in the wake of the ``Today'' debacle. It has been first for 33 consecutive weeks. But during its long stay in second, Lunden said, those on the show didn't get a lot of pressure from ABC brass, or those of Capital Cities, the network's new owners. ``They really just said, `Hey, go out there, enjoy it, be curious, and have a good time, '' she said. ``They said, `If it works, the ratings will go up.' And they did.'' __ Elsewhere in television... REASON NO. 398 TO CONTINUE BREATHING: Remember the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles? Well, CBS feels it is not enough just to start a Saturday morning cartoon series with them on Sept. 15. It now also says it will have a ``sneak preview'' of the one-hour series for kids on Sept. 8, and include in the show a save-the-environment segment called ``Turtle Tips.''

New Lab to Help Farmers Face Management Challenges
DOC.TEXT: Helping farmers make the best management decisions in the face of swift agricultural changes is the goal of a new university laboratory in the nation's heartland. The Farm Management Laboratory is drawing on the University of Illinois' experience running its own farms, as well as its records from more than 7,000 private farms and its research in agricultural economics. ``Coming out of the financial crisis of the '80s, we are concerned about the impact of environmental issues and government programs,'' said Rob Hornbaker, chairman of the board that will manage the laboratory. The lab, which opened recently in the Department of Agricultural Economics, is gathering information and plans to distribute it to farmers and extension advisers throughout the state, one of the leading producers of corn and other key crops. Creation of the lab comes against a background of growing pressure on farmers to become increasingly sophisticated about managing a business subject to the whims of a global marketplace. Farm prices can rise or fall dramatically in one day because of the volatility created by trading in the futures exchanges of Chicago, where contracts on crops often are influenced by news beyond a farmer's control. ``We have a lot of knowledge relating to farm management, and we wanted to put it together in one place,'' said Hornbaker, an agricultural economist. It will take about $250,000 a year to operate the lab, he said, and university officials hope a substantial portion will come from outside research contracts and individual and corporate contributions. One source of information will be production and financial data from more than 40 university-managed commercial farms. Another will be the university's Farm Business Farm Management system, which includes comprehensive records from more than 7,000 private farms in the state. ``That system is directed at analyzing records for farmers and helping them look at their business plans,'' said Hornbaker. ``But it does not research new issues.'' The lab is gathering data from research under way and plans to launch new research projects. For example, information is being collected about raising conventional crops like corn and wheat, vs. alternative or exotic crops ranging from spices to Belgian endive. ``Analysis of the economic implications of various enterprises has to be more site specific _ geared to a particular part of the state _ than it has in the past,'' Hornbaker said. Studies likely will evaluate the economic impact of various levels of production inputs, as well as techniques for protecting the environment and dealing with changes in government farm programs. ``There is a move toward more flexibility in farm programs, so we have to help farmers take a closer look at the economic issues that raises,'' Hornbaker said. An external advisory council of about 12 people from various segments of Illinois' agricultural industry will help the laboratory develop its priorities. As the laboratory gathers research results and management information, it will develop educational materials that can be distributed to farmers and extension advisers, perhaps at workshops on particular subjects, said Hornbaker. ``The bottom line benefit to farmers is a more precise economic analysis of all these issues that affect their operations so they have a basis for making the best management decisions,'' Hornbaker said. ``Everything we do will have an economic component.''

DOC.HEAD: Timber Plays Tall Role in Washington Congressional Race
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A fluffy creature that stands barely 2 feet tall and weighs less than 2 pounds is dominating one of America's hottest congressional races. Freshman Democrat Jolene Unsoeld has become a lightning rod for anger and frustration in the same timber towns that helped elect her as she tries to balance protection of the northern spotted owl with that of another threatened species, the Pacific Northwest logging community. Unsoeld won an open seat two years ago by 618 votes in what was the country's closest congressional election, squeezing into office by defeating a virtual unknown in a traditionally Democratic district. And that was before the federal government decided to list the northern spotted owl as a threatened species. Republicans now are sensing that Unsoeld may be endangered herself. She is being challenged by a feisty conservative, former state Rep. Bob Williams, who would be the first GOP congressman from the district in 30 years. Williams was the Republican challenger against the state's popular Gov. Booth Gardner in 1988. He lost in a landslide, but gave the governor fits with his frenetic energy and kamikaze political style. Unsoeld and Williams both have opposition in the Sept. 18 primary, but they already are campaigning against each other. The candidates talk about the deficit and the savings and loan debacle, abortion and basic philosophical differences, but the campaign is dominated by the timber issue. The owl in July was listed as threatened under the federal Endangered Species Act. The decision is certain to shut down millions of acres of prized old-growth timber, largely on U.S. Forest Service lands, to protect the owl. Loggers fear that the annual harvest will be slashed by half, decimating small timber communities that dot the lush Olympic Peninsula and other timberlands of Washington, Oregon and Northern California. Unsoeld, an ardent environmentalist, is on the defensive. On several occasions, she's waded into hostile timber rallies, a sort of Jolene-in-the-lion's-den approach that buttressed her scrappy image. In May, she was barred by angry picketers from a union hall where she'd been invited. She stood in the chill west wind for nearly three hours, putting up with taunts and jeers. ``I'm doing my damnedest to support you!'' she cried at one point. Unsoeld, a mountain-climber, citizen activist and four-year member of the state House before going to Washington, sees herself as a centrist and a realist on the issue. She backed a congressionally approved ban on the export of unprocessed logs from most state-owned lands in the West. In Washington, the new law will cut the exports of state timber by 75 percent. Domestic mills will be helped, but loggers and longshoremen say it will cause a net loss of jobs. Unsoeld, 58, also wants tax breaks and negotiations with the Japanese as possible ways to expand the timber supply and volume processed before export. She champions ``New Forestry,'' which includes selective logging of old-growth timber. Unsoeld shrugs off the anger from the traditionally Democratic loggers. ``Timber communities have been going through shock, rage, anguish and fear _ all absolutely legitimate emotions,'' she said in an interview. ``But we are beginning to see elected officials and community leaders say, `Hey, we can sit here screaming and crying or we can do something about it.''' Williams, 48, a bespectacled, intense man who served a decade in the Legislature and earned his spurs as a budget watchdog, says Unsoeld deserves every ounce of the blame she's getting. ``She was elected by the timber workers and she has deserted them,'' he said. ``They want someone in Congress who will go to bat not only for their jobs but for their way of life.'' He accuses Unsoeld of representing ``the more extreme part of the environmental movement.'' Williams supports higher harvest levels, amendments to the Endangered Species Act to require consideration of socioeconomic impacts, a study to see whether owls can survive in second-growth forests, tax incentives for woodlot owners, and tougher trade negotiations with the Japanese. He opposes export bans. Says Unsoeld, ``After ranting and raving for months, my opponent is now advocating three-fourths of my timber plan.'' Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., who represents a neighboring congressional district, calls Williams ``an opportunist challenger ... who is trying to exploit the fears of working people.'' Lance Henderson, spokesman for the state Republican Party, shoots back: ``Unsoeld's radical environmental views and her extreme liberal views on economics, her anti-business views and her lack of sufficient support for the timber community shows she doesn't fit the district.

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Mexico City has been largely rebuilt since that disastrous earthquake of 1985, but its citizens are not the same. In rebuilding their shattered city the people learned something about themselves. They learned that by pulling together they no longer had to depend on a sometimes undependable government.

The catastrophic earthquake that devastated Mexico City five years ago lasted only a minute or so, but it set in motion political and social tremors still felt today. Besides leveling buildings and homes, killing thousands (some estimates say 30,000) and leaving hundreds of thousands homeless, the quake seriously damaged the image of invincibility of the governing political party, radicalized many citizens and demonstrated to many others, if only briefly, the viability of ``people power.'' The Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) still governs the city of 15 million, but less certainly than before. Most of the volunteers who poured into the streets returned home changed, more confident of their power and distrustful of the government. Some of the volunteers stayed on as political activists. In the moments after the thunder of buildings falling to the ground subsided, citizens took charge. They rushed into the battered streets to rescue the trapped and unearth the dead. They set up shelters for the homeless and started rebuilding. And they did all this without help from a paternalistic government that had always done everything; did it without the omnipresent PRI. ``I would say that five years later it is still trembling in Mexico City,'' says Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, a political analyst, newspaper columnist and researcher at the National University's Center for U.S. Studies. ``It showed Mexico City for just a second in the historical framework of time what it would be like to be in a city where the government becomes subordinate and accountable and the people emerge, and the people rule and the government obeys.'' The quake hit at 7:19 a.m. on Sept. 19, while most people were at home or en route to work. Registering 8.1 in the Richter scale, it was classified a ``great'' quake. Another the next day measured 7.5, but most of the damage was already done. In a country where the government had been the main provider of assistance for decades, citizens of all stripes _ students, neighbors, private engineers, tough street gangs _ went into the streets by the thousands to help. One government estimate said there were 1 million volunteers, unusual in a country with no tradition of grassroots volunteerism. They organized themselves into brigades to dig their way to survivors, pull out bodies, bring food and water to the homeless and the rescue workers. ``The people were trying to save people's lives and the government was trying to regain control,'' says Adrian de Lope, then a student at the private Anahuac University. Now 25, de Lope was one of those who stayed in volunteer work. He spent four years after graduation working with the school's housing and community development project for earthquake victims. He's still a fund-raiser for the project. ``The people have the power, or at least they know that they can have it,'' he says. ``They now know that they are able to do things that they didn't know they were able to do before.'' Lorenzo Meyer, a historian at the Colegio de Mexico, says many city dwellers were already fed up with the authoritarian political system. ``But that particular (governmental) tardiness, the slowness of the response, made them more willing to criticize openly the behavior of the bureaucracy and the lack of leadership of (President Miguel) de la Madrid.'' On the other hand, government officials say no city hit by such a large disaster has been able to rebuild so fast. They point to the reconstruction, replacement, repair or financing of 105,000 housing units in three years. ``The magnitude of the damage, the tragedy, was so great that we even had to take a while to be able to perceive and know the extent of the disaster,'' says Enrique Jackson, president of the PRI in Mexico City. ``Certainly if it hadn't been for society we wouldn't have been able to begin to attend to and help the affected people. The people had a big role.'' The PRI began to recoup, organizing residents into reconstruction committees at the new housing units. Out of the rubble, questions arose. Citizens asked how the buildings that fell had been built. They wondered why hospitals, government offices, the 14-story Nuevo Leon building collapsed, killing hundreds. After a week, the government stopped counting bodies, as if to try to diminish the disaster. ``The government was directly in charge of some of those constructions, somebody you can pinpoint as the guilty one,'' Meyer says. ``You can end with another classic case of corruption, so you diminish the importance of the damage and hope that society will not demand an inquiry.'' No one went to jail in connection with any of the collapses. But in the July 1988 general election, de la Madriess to negotiate. Both Scowcroft and Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat endorsed the concept of a mediating role by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is seeking urgent talks with Iraqi officials this week. Scowcroft said Saddam has shown himself to be a realist, citing his willingness two weeks ago to bow to Iran's terms for a settlement of their eight-year war. Among other concessions, Saddam agreed to recognize the pre-war boundary of the two countries. Al-Mashat contrasted Iraq's ``desire for peace'' with the American ``design to have war.'' He said the U.S. aggressive intentions were demonstrated by the dispatch of offensive weaponry, including stealth fighter bombers, to Saudi Arabia. He said the U.S. allegation that Iraq posed a threat to Saudi Arabia ``was the biggest deception in history.'' The undersecretary of state for political affairs, Robert Kimmitt, said that sooner or later, Saddam's hand will be forced by the economic sanctions. ``I think they (the sanctions) are becoming increasingly effective. I think the difference between this sanction regime and past sanctions regimes is that it enjoys the virtually unanimous support of the world community and therefore I think the sanctions are beginning to pinch more and more as each day goes by,'' Kimmitt said.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
MEXICO CITY: Party leader.
DOC.TEXT: The PRI's Jackson says economic crisis and increasing masses of poor, not the quake, hurt his party. The party won in the voting districts hardest hit by the quake, he says. The PRI won the congressional and Mexico City assembly races, but in those same districts, the left defeated Salinas. The city today looks much the same as it did. Many of the shiny glass-walled high-rises are reconstructed earthquake-damaged buildings. By contrast, the weathered steel skeleton of an Agriculture Department building juts out on Reforma Boulevard, one of numerous structures yet to be rebuilt or torn down. There are parks or vacant lots where buildings once stood. Small camps house some of the thousands who remain homeless. Brightly colored vecindades _ small row houses around an inner patio _ stand out in low-income neighborhoods where old shacks, given a final blow in the quake, were torn down. Some government offices moved out of downtown or to the provinces. A construction code passed after the quake stiffened requirements for tall buildings. But there is lingering worry about another major quake. Seismologists are keeping an eye on a fault in a different location off the Pacific Coast. Movement there, they say, could shake the lake bed where Mexico City sits as strongly as the last quake. ``If there is a tremor now, it's not the same as before. Now we know that buildings fall and people die. Now people react with more fear to earthquakes,'' says Carmen Blanco, a National University psychology professor. She worked in the school's post-earthquake psychology service. If the city has been largely rebuilt, its people will never be the same again. Evangelina Corona, 52, who worked as seamstress on San Antonio Abad Street, dared not confront her employer before the quake. Now she is an outspoken union leader. Before the quake, she sewed so fast her machine smoked. She thought it good of her employer to give a country woman with a third-grade education a chance. Then the buildings crammed with sewing factories gave way, trapping hundreds of seamstresses. Her boss said the jobs were gone, there would be little severance. By mid-October, seamstresses from the different factories had organized into a non-government union. Antonio Paz quit his job as a government social worker because of the way the government was handling recovery efforts. He helped organize his damaged neighborhood first to survive, then rebuild, without government help. Paz works with an organization called Campamentos Unidos (Camps United), a self-help housing association rebuilding neighborhoods with no government assistance. With help from Operation USA and other international groups, it also has built a neighborhood clinic and is planning to build a Center for Studies of the Neighborhood to provide research, advice and training for projects. Some of the quake victims are also rebuilding their lives. Inspired by handicapped Vietnam Veterans in Miami where he was fitted for prosthesis, Celso Garcia has remarried and he and his wife are expecting a baby. His first wife, one of his two daughters, a sister and a cousin died in the quake when their fourth-floor apartment collapsed. Both his legs were amputated. Dr. Jose Juan Hernandez Cruz, trapped four days between the concrete slabs of the government's Juarez Hospital, has not married but has adopted a daughter, now 2. He works at a Health Department clinic until mid-afternoon and at a prison in the evenings. He's looking foward to visiting the Marseilles, France, team that rescued him. The 19 babies who were discovered one by one in the wreckage of hospitals, the last one nearly nine days after the quake, are now in kindergarten. One has met the American firemen who rescued her. One of the 19 is Evelia Alvarez Gasca, who lost her mother in the quake. She is being cared for by a 31-year-old aunt who has cancer. Raul Reyes Gonzalez is a street vendor, selling fried pork skins and other tidbits. Since the earthquake he has been doing volunteer work at a neighborhood housing association. Reyes Gonzalez' old slum neighborhood was the site of one of Campamentos Unidos' first projects. Before the quake it was a collection of one-room wood and cardboard shacks with two bathrooms for 600 people, too flimsy to be damaged. Government and private projects put up condominiums, replacing communal toilets and laundry sinks with facilities for each apartment. ``Simply with the bathrooms, socially there has been a 90-degree turn,'' Reyes says. ``We aren't yet high society, but we're living like human beings.'' He says he still works as a volunteer for the satisfaction of seeing others ``have a home worthy of a Mexican.''

DOC.TEXT: Five years ago the world of Celso Garcia collapsed around him. Today, with the help of some handicapped Vietnam veterans in Florida, he has put it together again. Garcia's wife, his 4-year-old daughter, a sister and a cousin all were killed when the five-story building where they lived collapsed in the Mexico City earthquake of Sept. 19, 1985. Garcia's legs had to be amputated. ``The walls split apart as if sliced by a knife,'' he recalls. ``Just before that I watched the wall at the head of the bed fall on my wife.'' ``I saw the floor open up and I fell through.'' He called to his family, one by one. Only Rubi, his 7-year-old daughter pinned beneath him, answered. Trapped in the rubble, he at first felt a tingling in his legs. Then he felt nothing. ``I began to see myself without legs,'' he says. When a rescue worker reached them hours later, he took away the piece of glass Garcia had been gripping in his hand, a way out should the wait become too long and the pain too great. Rubi suffered severed tendons in one arm. With therapy, she has regained most of the use of her fingers. With most of his family dead and his home destroyed, Garcia wondered what the future held. Answers came from the veterans in Miami. With help from the World Organizations for Private and Voluntary Assistance, he went to South Florida to be fitted for prostheses and for rehabilitation. The Broward County Paralyzed Veterans Association paid his airfare. His rehabilitation at the Sunrise Rehabilitation Center in Sunrise went far beyond the physical. ``I thought at one time that a handicapped person wasn't respected or valued, that he was a burden,'' he said. ``But I saw that even though they were handicapped in worse ways, those veterans had their lives.'' For nearly three months, he went bowling with the veterans, to shopping centers, everywhere. ``I saw that they were as normal as anyone and I asked myself why I couldn't do this in my country, and this has raised my spirits,'' he says. Garcia is now remarried and his new wife is expecting a baby. He has a job as coordinator of the vocational junior high school where he used to teach. They live in an apartment complex put up by Rotary International. He drives an adapted car, also from World Organizations. He taught summer classes to neighborhood children. ``When I have the opportunity when I go out I go without prostheses so that people who have this problem or may have it in the future know you can overcome things,'' he says.

DOC.TEXT: MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Here are some facts about the earthquake that devastated Mexico City on Sept. 19, 1985: SIZE _ The quake that struck at 8:19 a.m. (CST) on Sept. 19 measured 8.1 on the Richter scale. It was followed by an aftershock measuring 7.5 at 7:38 p.m. on Sept. 20. VICTIMS _ The government's official death toll of 4,541 was not raised after Sept. 26. The U.S. Agency for International development cited an unofficial government estimate of 9,500. Unofficial estimates, based on information from foreign rescuers and other sources, put the toll at between 20,000 and 30,000. HOMELESS _ An estimated 250,000 were left without homes. Government and private housing programs built, repaired or provided credit for 105,000 housing units. DAMAGE _ About 950 buildings collapsed and 4,775 others were damaged over about 20 square miles of the more than 550-square-mile city. In Ciudad Guzman, Jalisco, 3,000 homes were damaged or destroyed. In Jalisco, Guerrero and Michoacan, 56 other buildings were affected. The Mexico City damage included 30 percent of the public schools and 25 percent of the hospital capacity. Major streets, water systems and electrical stations were damaged and national and international telephone installations were destroyed. COST _ The government estimated damage to buildings and services at $4.1 billion. Housing reconstruction costs from 1986 to 1990 totaled $716 million. The Red Cross, UNICEF and other Mexican and international organizations built new housing and provided credit.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Look up eponym in your Webster's: ``one for whom or which something is named or supposedly named...'' Just as the name Webster is closely linked with dictionary, many others have achieved immortality through eponymity, but usually by accident.
DOC.HEAD: SID MOODY
DOC.TEXT: They are departed now, one and all: Rudolf Diesel. Antoine Sax. Amelia Jenks Bloomer. William Russell Frisbie. Jules Leotard. Danile C. Stillson. But glory, glory, hallelujah, their names go marching on. Theirs is immortality achieved by eponym: someTHING named for someBODY. Diesel's engines make the world go 'round under his name. This is fortunate. His first patent for them issued Feb. 28, 1892, was for an ``Arbeitsver fahren und Ausfuhrungsart fur Verbrennungskraftmaschinen'' (combustion power engine) which is an eponym to break jaws with. The four-slotted screws of Henry F. Phillips hold much of the world together. The adjustable wrench invented in the 1800s by Stillson tightens what's loose. Of the legacy of Monsieur Sax (1814-1894), a Belgian maker of music and its implements, it has been said: ``A gentleman is he who knows how to play a saxophone and doesn't.'' Immortality by eponym is accidental, rarely by design. W.R. Frisbie modestly stamped his name on pie plates that issued in the 1870s from his bakery in Bridgeport, Conn. He had no inkling those skimmable pie tins which bore his name would become a tradition at Yale University among tin-tossing students and would years later catch the eye of the Wham-O Manufacturing Co. in search for a name for its plastic discs. Despite a slight misspelling, W.F. Frisbie sails through the air somewhere on Earth daily. Fitzroy James Henry Somerset, Lord Raglan, illustrates the unpredictability of eponymity. He lost an arm at Waterloo, telling his amputators: ``Here, don't take that arm away until I get my ring off the finger.'' He commanded the British in the Crimean War and their boneheaded charge of the Light Brigade. And what is he remembered for? A coat sleeve. Lord Cardigan led that charge in a brilliant gold-trimmed uniform. We remember him for a humbler garment. But it is a rare war that bequeaths two eponyms. Even rarer was a double eponymery by one man, Edward Stanley, Earl of Derby. He sponsored a horse race in 1780 which took his name. So did the domed hat that men wore to the track. Another Englishman was a Mr. Derrick, an executioner in the first Elizabethan Age whose scaffold resembled its latter-day namesake and whose given name has become as lost as have his customers. His name might well have become eponymous for ingratitude. One of his clients was the Earl of Essex, who once had pardoned Derrick for a rape charge. When Queen Elizabeth later soured on Essex, it was Derrick who carried out her ultimate displeasure. Food and drink, especially alcohol, are well-traveled pathways to eponymity. If there wasn't a Harvey Wallbanger, there was a Harvey, says Tad Tuleja in his authoritive work, ``Namesakes.'' He was a California surfer of the 1960s given to ricocheting off walls after a surfeit of the drink's direct ancestor, then named a Doozie. Samuel Benedict, an ``American socialite'' circa 1894, became an eponym by one account when Oscar of the Waldorf served him poached eggs on muffins covered with hollandaise sauce to better commence a morning after. Another version says the eggs were first served at Delmonico's to a Mr. and Mrs. LeGrand Benedict. Howsoever, eggs Benedict. Then there was Clara Hirschfield. Her father, Leo, concocted a cylindrical chocolate candy in 1894. What to name it? Hirschfield seized upon his nickname for Clara, and the Tootsie Roll was born. The White House has been an eponymic gold mine. Baby Ruth, the candy bar, was also Grover Cleveland's new daughter. The Teddy bear stems from Theodore Roosevelt's demurral at shooting a bear cub. Alice blue is the color of the gown his daughter, Alice, wore to a ball, she who in her aged years said following two mastectomies: ``I'm the oldest topless woman in Washington.'' Medicine is another means to vocabularic Valhalla. Choking diners are saved by the maneuver of Dr. Henry Jay Heimlich, currently of Cincinnati, a rare achiever of eponymity in his own lifetime. Pregnant mothers feel less pain thanks to Dr. Fernand Lamaze. This Frenchman devised his method after a 1951 visit to the Soviet Union where babies were delivered by the Pavlov method named for Ivan Petrovich Pavlov. It involved the conditioned reflexes Pavlov used to get dogs to salivate by ringing a bell.

UNDATED: a bell.
DOC.TEXT: That perfection is hardly a requisite for eponymity is shown by the enduring fame of playwright Richard Sheridan's Mrs. Malaprop or the real-life massacres of English by the Rev. William Archibald Spooner, an Oxford don. He passed away in 1930 but left an eponymic legacy such as the spoonerism he delivered to a shy groom he had just wed: ``Son, it is kisstomary to cuss the bride.'' The universe marches ineluctably and eponymously to the laws of Boyle, Robert; Ohm, George; Newton, Sir Isaac. It shakes to the scale of Richter, Charles F., a California seismologist. It sweats or shivers to the degrees of Fahrenheit, Gabriel Daniel, a 17th-century German-Dutch instrument maker, or if not his, to the degrees of Anders Celsius, a Swedish astronomer (1701-44). Other eponymic laws govern our lives with a more tolerant rule: Parkinson's, C. Northcote, based on the study of the British civil service in his years as a professor in Malaya: ``Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion.'' Or Murphy, Edward A., an aircraft engineer in Ohio. He is not the only source cited by eponymists for Murphy's Law, but will suffice: ``If anything can go wrong, it will.'' In everyday life eponyms are everywhere. In the bedroom bureau: perhaps descendants of the tights Leotard wore on his French trapeze over a century ago. Possibly a trimmer version of the pantaloons Mrs. Bloomer, an early feminist, devised in the 1800s to liberate womankind from hoop skirts. More likely the namesakes of Levi Strauss, the German immigrant who sped to the California gold rush with a load of canvas to make the sourdoughs' tents. They needed pants, instead. Mayhap, but unlikely, we hold up those Levis with the belt of Browne, Sam, a 19th-century British soldier who designed it to keep the uniform from sagging lopsidedly when wearing a sword. In the kitchen cupboard or refrigerator or at ladies' socials we find the works of the late Earl S. Tupper, a chemist with DuPont who was fascinated with the properties of polyethylene. In the cookie jar we may find the fig Newton, so named by the Kennedy Biscuit Works of Boston after one of its suburbs which sounded more euphonious than a fig Framingham Center. In the living room ashtray may be the remains of Jean Nicot's eponym. A French diplomat in Portugal in the 1560s, he received a smokable plant from the New World which his grateful sovereign named Nicotiana tabacum and the U.S. Surgeon General later condemned as nicotine. In the garden may bloom the Christmas plant Joel Roberts Poinsett brought back from Mexico during his difficult ambassadorship there in the 1840s. Or the yellow-blooming shrub William Forsyth returned with from China several decades before. In the trees and heavens eponyms trill and soar: Steller's jay, Audubon's warbler, Cassin's sparrow, Swainson's hawk. We used to drive Tin Lizzies. There was no Elizabeth, alas. The term most likely derives from tin limousine. But we still drive eponymously on the roads surfaced a la John L. Macadam, an 18th-century Scot. If on foot, we may huddle against the elements in the slightly misspelled eponym of Charles Macintosh (1766-1843). Eponymery also has its dark side. Blacks suffered under the yoke of Jim Crow regulations which took their name from the song ``Jump, Jim Crow'' sung by pioneer white minstrel Thomas Dartmouth Rice in the early 1800s. In World War I Paris felt the wrath of Big Bertha, a mammoth cannon named for the wife of its maker, Bertha Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach. For years, of course, Frenchmen disposed of each other with the invention of Dr. Joseph-Ignace Guillotin. He devised it during the French Revolution out of humanitarian and egalitarian impulses. It brought instant departure instead of a tortuous one, theretofore reserved to the upper classes. From Lamaze to guillotin, birth to death, we live in an eponymous world. We always have, ever since someone opened...by George (George who?...you've got it) _ Pandora's Box.
