DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Age of Marvels
LaserPhoto NY700
DOC.TEXT: Some electronic gadgets just make life easier, from microwave ovens that zap supper to fax machines for ordering junk food. Some gizmos make life more enjoyable, such as the Walkman, Watchman and video games that fit in the palm of the hand. Some save lives, such as pacemakers that keep hearts beating in rhythm and laser beams that allow bloodless surgery. Some offer protection, from the wizardry of national defense sensors to personal security alarms that ward off burglars. Some, like computers, do things that nothing else can. Whatever, it's hard to imagine life without electronics. They are to modern living what the earliest flickers of fire were to evolving humans _ a means to cook, get warm, find safety, defeat the darkness, signal others and allow groups to gather. ``There's no aspect of our life that is not touched by electronics even if we do not own the product. They've made our lives easier, enhanced lifestyles and made us healthier,'' said Mark Rosenker of the Electronics Industries Association, a Washington-based trade group. ``With each and every one of these enhancements, you can't believe you ever did without it,'' Rosenker said. On the down side, they do raise expectations. Getting something there overnight just won't do anymore. It has to be faxed instantaneously or sent by electronic mail. And, confound it, electronics don't necessarily make life simpler. Just ask anyone who's had a computer system crash from a bugaboo. Computers can even catch a virus, and please make sure no one pulls the plug. The electronic age has beamed a revolution into the home. Microwaves heat water for instant coffee at breakfast and, with push-buttoned planning, can automatically cook supper. The TV, now in stereo and soon to be high definition, flashes instant news and entertainment from signals bounced off globe-circling satellites to dish-shaped receivers. Remote control negates the need to flip dials. VCRs retrieve what was on too late to watch the night before or, with a rental tape, become movie projectors. The popcorn comes from the microwave, of course. How we talk to others has also changed dramatically. There's call waiting, call forwarding and call conferencing. Machines will answer if you're not around. New phones can dial numbers on voice command. Need freedom while talking? There are cordless phones and portable cellular phones, which fit in the car or can simply be carried around. No need anymore to yell for the kids. Just beep them on digital pagers. Once the domain of doctors, lawyers and the self-important, pagers are ubiquitous. Even the criminal element _ drug dealers, prostitutes and bookies _ have prospered by their wizardry. And, shades of Dick Tracy, the new ones fit on the wrist. Remember the fax-less days? Now your personal facsimile can order at McDonald's, send in a food order to the grocery store, request a song on a radio station and, oh, yes, send business documents and news releases. The home computer has more memory and more power to figure taxes and keep bank records. Use it as a word processor and kiss the typewriter goodbye. Laptop computers and office organizers give executives a jump start to the business day before they get to the office. High-tech gadgets open and close the garage door and trigger burglar alarms. If those burglars are caught and aren't dangerous enough to be in jail, they may serve their sentence wearing an electronic bracelet monitored by police. You don't have to be a geezer to remember when cars were started with hand cranks. Now they come to life with electronic ignitions, and computer chips tell a car how much gas to burn and how evenly the brakes are applied. Radar helps the cops catch speeders; radar detectors help speeders elude the cops. Sensors turn on street lights at dusk and shut them off at dawn. You can bank by machine, pay bills, get cash, transfer money. Forget record albums. Now there's compact discs and digital audio tape. Nintendo video games turn TVs into arcades. There are hand-held versions that fit in the palm of the hand for entertainment on the hoof. Some even convert into portable TVs. Remember arithmetic with pencil and paper? Now the calculator is where it's at as the slide rule becomes as quaint as the abacus. There are other intrusions in education. College courses now come on VCR tapes. Even the sports world is electronic. Instant replays govern football games and radar guns measure the speed on a pitcher's fastball. It hasn't been all that long since the dawn of the Electronic Age in 1883, when Thomas Edison controlled the flow of electrons through a light bulb. Now its growth seems to be stuck on fast forward. The U.S. electronics industry is worth about $285 billion a year, almost triple what it was just 10 years ago. And electronics has made the world a smaller place. Even totalitarian governments know what they can do. In China, students used electronic mail and fax machines to tell the truth about Tiananmen Square. ``You can't close down a society anymore. Once people have access to these things, it makes it much harder to shut off their minds,'' said Sara Kiesler, professor of social and decision sciences at Carnegie-Mellon University. And she also said parents shouldn't worry too much if their children prefer to use calculators instead of working out problems manually. ``We tend to cling to old ways. Younger people think if a machine can do it, it's a waste of time to do it by hand,'' Kiesler said. ``They're saying, `why bother to rub sticks together when you can strike a match.' ''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: CDs
LaserPhoto NY701
DOC.TEXT: With compact discs becoming the format of choice for playback of pre-recorded albums and singles, there is a new wave of players ready to catch the eyes and ears of dedicated audiophiles. Most major electronics manufacturers are now marketing compact disc changers to satisfy the appetites of those who hunger for hours of uninterrupted digital sound. The two most popular versions of CD changers are the magazine and carousel styles. Most CD magazines hold up to six discs, which are loaded and stored horizontally. Once loaded, the magazine is inserted into the player and each disc is then pulled from the magazine and individually played. Carousel changers, on the other hand, hold five discs on one large platter. A merry-go-round-like disc tray rotates to the pickup mechanism to play the CD. Regardless of the make or style of the compact disc changer, the end result is the same: hours of hassle-free listening. CD changers incorporate the same laser optics used in single-disc players to read the information stored on the discs. CD changers cost more than many single-disc players, but don't be frightened by the thought of paying a higher price for the convenience of owning one. Shopping around can pay off, as dealers, on occasion, will offer quality, brand-name changers on sale for around $200. If you don't want to wait for a sale, then expect to pay $279 to $400 for a changer. Like single-disc units, changers are also available with varying degrees of ``frills.'' Some carousel and magazine changers are available without remote control and have to be programmed on the unit's front panel. Eliminating the remote feature can save you a few dollars. But fully programmable changers packed with options are attractive. Here's what most of them will do: After loading a changer with discs, it can be programmed to play only the selections you want and in any order. Thanks to the laser pickup and the way the digital recordings are stored, the changer can go from one disc to another to find a song in a matter of seconds. Most changers allow around 30 selections to be programmed. Some also offer selection memory and title file memory, so favorite programs may be saved. Changers with a random play function allow the unit to pick and play selections on its own. That feature is nice when listening to group ``greatest hits'' CDs. It's like having a jukebox in your home. Carousel changers are manufactured by Magnavox, Sony, Yamaha, Technics, and Onkyo. Magazine-style changers are available from Pioneer, Magnavox, Sanyo, Yamaha, Onkyo, and others. Some unique changers include the Yamaha CDC-500, which uses a six-disc magazine and also has a tray for single-disc play. Sanyo's CPM 900 will hold up to 10 discs in its magazine, six 5-inch discs and four 3-inch discs. Fisher's DAC199 has five individual loading trays and can be programmed to display disc titles on its lighted front panel. The SL-PC45 top-loading carousel changer from Technics allows the user to insert discs while one is playing. Sharp's MV-D100 is a three-disc CD changer that also plays laser videodiscs. Consumers also have found it handy to keep discs permanently stored in the CD changer's magazines. You simply buy more magazines to accommodate additional discs and build a library. Some of the magazines also are compatible with auto CD changers. As with any stereo component, it is recommended that you give prospective units a full in-store test before buying.
DOC.HEAD: (Ron Gustafson is newswire and features editor for the Dunkirk,
DOC.TEXT: N.Y., Evening Observer.)

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Home Electronics: Videodisc
LaserPhoto NY702
DOC.TEXT: The laser videodisc format is actually the big brother of the compact disc and is continuing to grow in popularity among audio-video enthusiasts. Though the concept of the optical-read disc has not changed in its 11-year history, there have been some big quality advances. Today's laser videodisc players provide more than 400 lines of horizontal resolution to complement large screen monitors. Most new discs range from hit movies to music videos and also incorporate true digital sound. And 1989 was a banner year for disc sales in the United States. Some of the popularity growth may be attributed to the acceptance of the compact disc. What can this playback-only disc system do? Here's the lowdown on the laser videodisc format: Discs: They come in three sizes, 12, 8 and 5-inch. The 12-inch discs feature hit movies, concerts, operas, and educational material. They can contain up to 60 minutes of audio-video programming per side. The 8-inch discs are usually music videos with up to 20 minutes of programming per side. The 5-inch laser videodiscs are known as CDVs (compact disc video) and are gold in color. They resemble standard CDs but are able to hold up to 5 minutes of video along with 20 minutes of audio. These discs are also devoted to music. Compact discs, which can be played on most current models of laser videodisc players, are available in 3- and 5-inch sizes. The 5-inch disc can store up to 74 minutes of material and the 3-inch disc up to 20 minutes. The price of laser videodiscs also make them attractive to collectors of classic and hit movies. Many new releases on disc are priced at under $30, whereas the same title on a tape may cost as much as $90. Music videos cost even less with CDVs listing for about $10. Since these discs are read by a low-power laser beam, there is no wear to them. With proper handling and storage, they should last a lifetime. Players: Many leading hardware manufacturers currently offer laser videodisc players. You can select from such names as Pioneer, Magnavox, Yamaha, Sony, NEC, Mitsubishi, Sharp, and Philips. Panasonic and Proton are expected to market players soon. All of the name-brand players are available as ``combi'' units. They will play all of the optical disc formats from CDs to 12-inch laser videodiscs (LDs). These combination players are available for about the price of hi-fi VHS videocassette recorder. Pioneer also offers a lower-priced player for 8- and 12-inch discs which has analog instead of digital audio circuitry. Players with all of the frills offer such features as two-sided, two-disc playback and sing-along capabilities. How they work: I recently bought a new Pioneer CLD-1070, my third laser videodisc player since becoming a charter member of the ``laser camp'' in 1979. It's connected to a 27-inch Sony monitor and my stereo system, which has a separate Dolby Surround processor-amplifier and rear speakers. This ``combi'' player can do it all. The remote control allows the user to program selected tracks from compact discs as well as laser videodiscs encoded with ``chapter stops.'' For instance, if I want to see a particular scene from ``Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' the player can locate it in a matter of seconds. The player will also produce jitter-free freeze frame and slow motion on selected discs. The picture provided by the laser videodisc is far sharper than my HQ VHS deck. Colors are vivid and true and the picture is rock solid. As for the sound, nothing compares to digital audio. It's a state-of-the-art component which makes the ``home theater'' concept a reality. This deck, like most laser videodisc players, can be racked into an audio-video system since it has a front-loading drawer. The player will automatically select the proper playing mode for compact discs or the larger LDs. It also knows which big discs contain digital soundtracks and will switch on the digital circuit. In scanning the current line-up of players, most have similar features, so it's a matter of preference when making a purchase. Another important point about this high-quality format is that many of the feature films being released may be purchased in the ``letterbox'' or widescreen format. Usually when a movie filmed for the widescreen comes to the home tube, it is cropped in a process known as pan and scan. By cropping the wide picture, it will fill up the entire television screen. But up to two-thirds of the picture may be lost in this process, so the viewer is not seeing all of the action. By ``letterboxing'' a videodisc release, the picture is not cropped. Instead, black bars are inserted on the top and bottom of the programmed material and the original widescreen picture is left intact. With disc production currently being increased and more strongly backed by hardware manufacturers, the laser videodisc could prove to be a powerful force in home entertainment in the 1990s.
DOC.HEAD: (Ron Gustafson is newswire and features editor for the Dunkirk,
DOC.TEXT: N.Y., Evening Observer.)

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Home Computers
LaserPhotos NY703,NY704
DOC.TEXT: Ordinary consumers may want, need, and use home computers, but not necessarily with all the complex gizmos that attract dedicated hackers. So computer marketers aiming at this broad middle range group have begun to concentrate on basic usefulness of the machines, with word processing, school work, household management and entertainment at the top of the list. They also are making them easier to set up and use. After its initial flop with the PCjr in the home computer marketplace, IBM scrambled to recoup by interviewing consumers across the country about what they really want from a household computer. The business computer giant re-entered the market this summer with its PS@1 line, four compact models ranging in price from $1,000 to $2,000 and dedicated to such prosaic functions as homework, financial records, correspondence, and information gathering and entertainment through software like Prodigy. The computers have built-in modems that allow communication with other PCs or information networks. Each computer, which can be bought at department or computer stores, arrives with all components in one box, ready to set up and go to work. Approaching from the other end of the market, Smith Corona, with long experience in home-use typewriters, has come up with a line of compact personal word processors. SCM word processors range from $500 to $900, with printers costing an additional $200 or $300, depending on type. Included in the line is the 6.5-pound PWP 7000LT, which the company says is the first laptop personal word processor in the industry, with ports for printers and modems to latch into on-line information services. SCM also is marketing a line of electronic typewriters range from $230 to $430, some with displays and keyboards similar to word processors. IBM, looking at a 20 million-unit market that is expected to double in five years, found that their potential consumers wanted something relatively simple to set up and start with but didn't skimp on more serious computing capabilities. ``Because it was developed to meet the expressed needs of today's contemporary families, the computer has the potential to become as necessary to the home as the microwave oven and as useful as the VCR,'' says IBM's James Cannavino. Each IBM model features Microsoft Works and an IBM DOS operating system, with Selectric Touch keyboard, Photo Graphic color or black-and-white high resolution display, and a mouse. Powered by Intel 80286 microprocessors, models offer options of either 512 kilobytes (KB) or 1 megabyte (MB) of memory. If more storage is needed, users can add optional equipment such as a 3.5-inch diskette drive, a 30 MB hard disk, or a 5.25-inch external disk drive. The IBM machines open with an information quadrant graphic that gets users into any of four capability modes: information for tutorials and on-line help; Microsoft Works for word processing, spreadsheets, databases and communications; storage for the users' own software; and IBM DOS, the operating system with menu-driven commands for functions such as copying and formatting. Users can pick from an array of on-line services including Prodigy, for shopping, brokerage, banking and travel ticketing; the PS@1 Users' Club, for on-line support, information and a users' electronic bulletin board, operating through Prodigy; and Promenade, an education and entertainment on-line service with classes, tutoring, library and encyclopedia access and card and board games. (Prodigy is IBM's joint venture with Sears.) SCM's machines are geared primarily to word processing with built-in printing systems, though some of its models have separate printers and are set up with Hayes compatible 1200 baud modems so owners can plug into on-line networks. Desktop publishing capability is offered through SCM's high-speed, high resolution transfer printer (HRT100), which can print with a variety of characters and typefaces via plug-in cartridges. The company also offers a letter-quality daisy-wheel printer (DWP I). The portable laptop uses the latter. It also has 50,000 characters of editable internal memory and a built-in disk drive with storage capacity of 100,000 characters per disk. Its display is a 16-line backlit LCD board that flips up, and it can push optional spreadsheet programs. The line features what SCM calls an entry-level word processor, the PWP 1000. This portable machine comes an 8-line LCD and 32,000 characters of internal memory. It offers additional storage with an optional 32,000 character DataStore Card. The machine features a built-in address file and battery backup to hold records in case of a power failure. Full screen monitors are featured on top-of-the line SCM models, such as the PWP 5100, with a box-like monitor and printer combined; the PWP 100c, with a printer-typewriter configuration; and the PWP 220, with separate keyboard, monitor and printer.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Telephones
DOC.TEXT: The telephone has come a long way since the day in 1876 in Boston when Alexander Graham Bell told his laboratory assistant over a primitive liquid transmitter, ``Mr. Watson, come here; I want you.'' Today, that liquid transmitter has evolved into cordless phones, tapeless digital answerphones, speakerphones, integrated telephone answering machines, cellular phones, phones with autodialer memory, on-hook dialing and voice dialing. Voice-dialing phones use voice logic sensor technology to allow a user to dial any of 50 individual numbers by simply saying the name of the person or business being called. The programmable phone stores a voice print of each party's name and number in its memory, so that when a name is announced, it automatically dials that number. Some models have a built-in answering machine that greets callers with a digitally-synthesized voice which asks them to dial in their number so the call can be returned. Recently introduced by AT&T are the first answering machines that respond to rotary phones and voice responses. The two-line models also are the first to answer calls on one line while taking a message on the other. ``Now, answering machines can get their messages from virtually any phone, anywhere in the world,'' explains Rob Davis, product manager for the company's answering machines. ``For example, people vacationing at a mountain cabin or a shore cottage with only a rotary telephone available won't have to jump in the car and drive to the nearest pay phone to get their messages.'' Another recently marketed telephone is a hands-free headset model which allows a person to listen to FM radio programs but to answer calls with the touch of a button when the radio reception is interrupted by an alerting tone. Digital technology has enabled engineers to do away with bulky telephone answering systems and create compact and tapeless digital answerphones designed for home use. With the absence of tape cassettes, the phones are approximately the size of a standard telephone and have fewer working parts than conventional answering machines. ``Digital recording puts an end to twisted tapes or overworked parts which break or wear out,'' said a General Electric spokesman, describing one of the company's models. ``With remote message play, users can listen to their messages even when they are away from home. ``The phone also features an LED message counter to quickly display the number of calls received and has an auto-disconnect function which automatically stops the outgoing message when any phone in the house is picked up.'' And for the traveler who wants to dial up the latest stock prices or call for hotel and plane reservations, the New York Telephone Company is testing new public computer terminals at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport. The company says customers can access some 150 different travel, financial, entertainment and information services available at the terminals, which also are equipped for conference calling. ``Preliminary market studies tell us that many airline travelers _ especially business people _ would use these types of services frequently,'' says Robert Bellhouse, general manager-public communications. ``This six-month test will provide use with more definitive information on the level of market acceptance.'' The access terminals include video displays, keyboards, and a telephone handset and keypad.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Entertainment
DOC.TEXT: The fun end of computers and videos has become an separate entertainment medium of its own. Some new twists: _ Sing-along laserdiscs. Laser Karaoke from Pioneer provides the background orchestra, on-screen lyrics and mood images, and a mike to croon into, in the home entertainment version of a songfest. Karaoke means ``empty orchestra'' in Japan, where the form _ starting with cassettes with orchestral backings but no vocals _ has been popular for at least 15 years. Pioneer offers it as a feature on its laserdisc combination players which can handle discs from a library of more than 500 songs, including current hits, Broadway show music, the country-western genre, traditional and nursery tunes. There's also a selection of Japanese, Cantonese, Mandarin, Korean and Tagalog songs. The equipment lets the singer override the vocals on most CDs and all karaoke discs and even lets him adjust the pitch. _ Home colorization. You can enter the great colorization debate on your own by colorizing your videos with the Video Equalizer from Videonics. This machine includes a digital video enhancer, digital video processor split-screen fucntion and three-channel audio mixer. The unit's ``digital paintbrush'' will let you change color of scene elements without affecting other colors or objects. You also can ``sharpen'' images by removing noise or snow. And you can add stereo music or voiceover narrations to the existing sound track. _ For game addicts, here comes something called U-Force Power Games, a four-games cartridge to be used with the U-Force hands-free controller for Nintendo. The system turns body motion into on-screen action without attaching the player to wires, gloves, helmets, floor pads or joysticks. Games on the cartridge include Power Field B-Ball, where the player can dribble, drive and shoot with natural movements, just as though he were on a real basketball court; Hose 'Em Down, which lets the player direct rescue operations of a burning building; the Nuclear Rat Attack, in which the player must fight off thousands of nuclear-waste-eating rats attacking his space ship; and Rock on Air, with the player creating music with a wave of his hands. U-Force is from Broderbund. _

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Sewing Machines
LaserPhoto NY705
DOC.TEXT: A stitch in time these days may well be powered by a microprocessor instead of a thimble. True, electronic sewing machines aren't for everyone, primarily because of price. The occasional weekend sewer may find the $2,500 price tag on Singer's new Quantum XL-1 daunting. But for those who sew a lot for family and home, an old truism still holds: any sewing machine will pay for itself many times over in savings realized in the family clothing or decorating budget. And the cost may be justified for anyone who values time and versatility or hates sewing handwork. The Quantum, with computer-controlled thread supply, can thread itself and do three kinds of buttonholes (keyhole and bartacks in two weights) in one-step operations. It has over 190 built-in stitches for construction, embroidery and lacework. These include automatic script and block alphabets for monogramming and 20 embroidery design motifs. Singer says the machine will handle wider stitch widths than any other machine, at a maximum 25 millimeters, without attachments. And, like most modern machines, it will baste, hem, and sew on buttons. These functions are controlled by an LCD display that shows what stitch has been selected and the actual size of the pattern motif being used. The touch-sensitive display gives operating instructions and warns of problems. A display board shows pictographs of all embroidery and monogram types. (Similar graphics on the machine include the droll choice of tortoise or hare on the speed control switch). The Quantum is technically portable, since it has a handle, but the company says that most consumers with cabinetry for earlier Singer models should be able to install the new machines in their existing furniture _ specifically cabinet models 621 and 385, or electric lift models 690, 691 and 692. This machine is the fifth generation of electronic machines produced by Singer, which marketed its first, the Athena, in l975.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Car Systems
DOC.TEXT: Naturally, you want all the comforts of home in your car. Music. A telephone. A security system. Owners of Nissan's new luxury car, the Infiniti, can get audio systems custom-tailored to its acoustic characteristics and blended inobtrusively into the car's design. ``The design is based on the simple philosophy that the car's music system is meant to be heard and not seen,'' says Jerry Firth of the Bose OEM Division, which is supplying the systems. Available for the 1990 Infiniti Q45 four-door sedan and the Infiniti M30 sports coupe, the audio systems feature digital switching amplifiers built into each speaker enclosure. Two 4.5-inch HVC speakers in front and two 6.5-inch full-range speakers in the rear are placed ot provide optimal stereo balance. An electronically tuned radio-cassette player has automatic dynamic noise reduction, Dolby B noise reduction, tape seek and scan, treble and bass controls, push-button station selection and station seek and scan. The cellular phone is the communication link for most motorists today who can't bear to be out of touch while on the road. A combination mobile, portable and transportable model from Audiovox, CTX-5000, sits in its cradle and operates as a five-watter from the car's electrical system. It becomes portable by disconnecting the handset, which contains all the phone's electronic controls, from the cradle. As a transportable, it attaches to a three-watt battery pack for extended use in a boat, for camping or in another car. For those who would like not to have their Infinitis _ or even their battered VWs _ stolen, there is the Prestige remote-controlled auto security system, also from Audiovox. From as far away as 100 feet, the key-ring remote controller can signal to lock the car's doors, trunk and disable the starter. The owner can use the controller to re-open the car when he returns. And if someone tries to break into the car, a high-wattage electronic siren will sound. It will shut down automatically after 90 seconds but re-set for continued protection.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Splatter Matter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A previous version of this story appeared on the wire. ^By LEE SIEGEL
DOC.TEXT: Scientific research is about to blow the lid off the mystery behind a common household horror: why thick soups and stews explode and splatter the inside of microwave ovens. ``It's a consumer problem: the housewife or kid comes back and here's lunch all over the inside of the microwave,'' said David W. Cable, a mechanical engineer at MetriCor Inc. in Woodinville, Wash. MetriCor, a subsidiary of Corning Inc., sells $12,000 fiberoptic sensors that are being used by Rutgers University scientists to measure temperatures and pressures of food as it is cooked in microwave ovens. He said the researchers want to know why some microwaved foods splatter as they cook _ and how to prevent the messy problem. Cable, who is MetriCor's marketing and sales manager, presented preliminary results of the study Wednesday during the annual meeting of the Institute of Food Technologists, which drew more than 15,000 food scientists to the Anaheim Convention Center. ``What causes cream of mushroom soup to attack the walls of a microwave oven while chicken bouillon remains cautiously in its bowl?'' the institute asked in a news release. ``Scientists are coming close to an answer for that question.'' Cable said a food being cooked in a microwave oven is injected with microwave energy ``at a rate similar to lightning striking a tree. The phenomenon is the same, except for its magnitude.'' ``As water and sap (in a tree) flash to steam, the tree literally explodes. ... This is what happens in the microwave to foods that are trapping the steam.'' Food scientists call the splattering phenomenon ``popping'' or ``bumping,'' Cable said. ``Some people have developed a sort of Richter scale of these explosions,'' he said. Cable and the institute said that so far, the food-industry sponsored study has provided the following solutions, some of which may seem obvious: _Foods should be centered in the microwave because heat is more evenly distributed there. The edges contain hot spots that are more likely to make water in thick soups flash into exploding steam bubbles. _Thicker soups are much more likely to splatter than thinner liquids because heat concentrates more easily in a viscous liquid, allowing steam bubbles to expand until they are large and create a messy explosion. Cable suggested cooking thick soups or stews at lower power, stirring them before putting them in the microwave oven, and covering the cooking container with a paper towel to contain the splattering. _If a cooking container contains ridges or some other rough surface, bubbles can form more easily and in greater numbers. And lots of small bubbles distribute heat more evenly, while a few large bubbles are more likely to send the soup flying. The Rutgers study may result in improvements in packaging for microwaveable foods, allowing them to be cooked with less mess, Cable said. Cable acknowledged the research may seem silly, but said consumers ``don't expect this nice clean package you put in your microwave to come apart and throw food all over the inside. ``It's a cleanup issue, and we're all tidy Americans. We don't like to be untidy.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Education
DOC.TEXT: Here's a different mouse-computer combination: Mickey Mouse and software features that introduce your pre-schooler to letters, numbers, colors and shapes. ``Mickey's ABC's,'' ``Mickey's 123's,'' and ``Mickey's Colors & Shapes'' are the top-of-the-line software features from Walt Disney Computer Software. A budget line for pre-schoolers includes ``Donald's Alphabet Chase,'' ``Mickey's Runaway Zoo,'' and ``Goofy's Railway Express.'' Each is animated with familiar Disney characters and is compatible with the Sound Source, Disney's digitized speech box that plugs into the printer port with its own amplifier and speaker. _ Patterned after in-school book clubs, Scholastic Software has launched a software club aimed at elementary through middle school students and their families. Education and entertainment software for Apple and MS-DOS computers will be available by mail through order kits sent to their teachers, with 20 to 50 percent discounts. The club program also will offer themed printer paper, memory expansion boards and other computer accesories. _ Software from Educational Testing Service may help you with the S.A.T. and other tests along the educational path. ETS software already is available for grade school level teachers and students. On the way are programs for higher level tests, including those for professional registration.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Electronics: Smoke Alarms
LaserPhoto NY706
DOC.TEXT: One of modern technology's more common items, the smoke detector, is being ignored by many owners, often to their peril. Non-working smoke detectors contribute to as many as 6,000 fire-related deaths and 130,000 injuries each year, according to Change Your Clock, Change Your Battery, a cooperative campaign sponsored by the International Association of Fire Chiefs, the American Burn Association and Eveready Battery Company. They hope that tying the ritual of time change on Oct. 28 with the routine of changing batteries will increase the number of working smoke alarms and emergency flashlights. The group estimates that 50 percent of home smoke alarms now are useless because of old or missing batteries. And without working flashlights, the difficulty of locating safe, swift exits in night fire situations increases. ``A yearly smoke detector battery change is the single most easy and accessible way to make a difference in the number of fire-related deaths and injuries,'' says Dave Hilton, president of the IAFC. ``A working smoke detector can double the chances of surviving a fire.'' Besides this annual routine, checking the batteries with the test button at least once a month is recommended.

DOC.TEXT: Computerized communications technology soon may be a factor in the restaurant trade, says a market research firm. ``Whoever can hook up to that keyboard first, whether it's a restaurant chain or deli, stands to benefit mightily,'' says Doreen Zavada, vice president and general manager of CREST (Consumer Reports on Eating Out Share Trends) division of the NPD Group, Inc, a market research firm. Zavada says customers in the near future may be able to punch in orders on their computer keyboards that will be piping hot in their kitchens when they arrive home. Faxes and video tapes also may be used to speed remote control shopping. Research was collected from about 12,800 households to determine consumer trends affecting the restaurant business. _ The typical PC owner has a median income of $42,000 and owns many other electronic gadgets, according to HTI, a market research group. Of 125,000 households polled, 27,000 have PCs and incomes well above the $28,000 average for non-owners. PC owners are likely to have an answering machine (42 percent), both cable and basic TV (37 percent) and compact disc players (28 percent). The study also indicates that the PC owner is 60 percent more likely to own his or her own business and more than twice as likely to own a fax machine or cellular telephone. ``We're finding out that PC owners are committed to new technology and the convenience and entertainment it brings,'' says Lynne Armstrong, the research group's president. _ If you're concerned about all the juice you're using to run your electronic gadgets or the environmental impact of disposables like batteries, you might check into the Real Goods Trading Company's catalog. Low power consumption lights, TVs and VCRs, rechargeables, inverters, and alternative power sources, such as solar collectors, hydro-electric systems and wind generators, are among the ``green'' products featured. There's even a generator@battery charger you can hook up to your bicycle to store energy via pedal power. For information or catalogs, call 1 (800) 762-7325. _ A fascimile machine in every American home in the not-too-distant future is predicted by an executive for a New Jersey-based electronics company. ``We tend to forget that it was once considered amazing when a household got a television set,'' says Marino Andriani, senior vice president of sales and marketing for Emerson Radio Corp. ``Now, it is almost unusual if you don't have more than one. ``The home fax will reach that level of acceptance one day, and not too far off. People are using the fax in ways never dreamed of when the machine was first introduced. We see college kids sending messages home, vacationers writing letters on them. ``Who will be the first on the block with a home fax machine is now a realistic question to ask.'' _ A new process that can put a favorite photo or image on a computer screen each time it is turned on has been developed by a California high-tech firm. The company _ Integrated Concepts of Redding, Calif. _ says it digitally translates the color or black-and-white photo onto a database, then sends it back on a diskette to the customer with simple instructions for loading the program. The file may also be downloaded by modem. According to the company, the idea was first used by companies which wanted their logotypes to appear on idle computer screens. Later, images of family, friends, pets, works of art, vacation scenes, fireplaces, sunsets, landscapes and ocean views began to be used. _ A ``clean'' humidifier that eliminates bacteria and viruses from its mist and needs little maintenance is being marketed this fall by Bionaire. The Clean Mist line uses a process called ``film boiling'' which sterilizes the mist, then mixes it with filtered room air for an uncontaminated mist only slightly above room temperature. The company says these humidifiers also can be used as vaporizers, and medication cups are included with each model. _ Stereo sound has been added to the latest all-in-one television-VCR combination from Gold Star Electronics. The 20-inch KMV-2102 model features on-screen, eight-event, one-year programming, an on-screen function display menu, bar graph picture and a selection of cable-compatible channels. It has an MTS stereo TV decoder with DBX noise reduction and Dolby noise reduction systems, and a unified random access 43-key remote control. _

The stock market rallied and oil prices eased as the world's battered financial markets gained optimism that a Middle East war had been averted _ at least for a while. But the recovery Friday was based more on a belief that stock prices had bottomed out and oil prices shot up too rapidly over $31 a barrel than on the latest tense developments in the Iraq-U.S. standoff. Traders termed Friday's action a chance to buy stocks at low prices following a sharp drop in the Dow Jones industrial average during the week.

The U.S. economy grew at a sluggish annual rate of 1.2 percent from April through June, the government said in a report that showed widespread economic weakness even before the Persian Gulf crisis. The Commerce Department report Friday showed the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, grew for the fifth consecutive quarter at a pace below 2 percent. Many economists had been looking for at least a small upward revision.

Gasoline prices have climbed 19.9 cents per gallon since Aug. 1, making for the most expensive fillups in more than eight years, according to the American Automobile Association. Self-serve regular unleaded gasoline averaged $1.274 per gallon nationwide, up 3.7 cents since Monday, the AAA reported Friday in its nationwide survey of 5,000 stations. The price is the highest since the July 4, 1982, price of $1.296.

The stock market's depressed levels opened the door for a number of companies to launch or extend stock buyback programs. A.O. Smith Corp., which had suspended a share repurchase program in June 1989, said Friday it was resuming stock buybacks. The company, a manufacturer of auto, truck and farm equipment, allocated $7.5 million for the repurchases. The toymaker Hasbro Inc. said its board approved the buyback of up to 3 million shares. Western Publishing Group Inc., First Illinois Corp., First Financial Holdings Inc. and Bernard Chaus Inc. were among other companies announcing stock buybacks.

A federal appeals court said the government is acting properly in setting auto mileage standards without preparing formal Environmental Impact Statements. The court, in a 2-1 decision Friday, rejected lawsuits by the state of California, the cities of Los Angeles and New York, and several environmental and safety groups. They had challenged the way the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration sets annual standards for the auto industry.

Federal Reserve policy-makers concluded in July that inflation remained high enough to maintain current interest rates despite a relatively slow economy, newly released records show. ``The staff projection prepared for this meeting suggested that the economy would expand over the remainder of 1990 at around the rate estimated for the first half of the year and at a slightly faster pace in 1991,'' said minutes of the July meeting, which were released on Friday.

Corporations' after-tax profits, reflecting the generally weak overall economy, edged down 0.2 percent in the April-June quarter, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Friday that the decline was the first since a 5.9 percent drop in after-tax profits in the July-September quarter last year. In the fourth quarter, profits rose 1.7 percent followed by a 0.5 percent first-quarter increase.

Data General Corp., which has repeatedly cut its payroll while trying to end a string of losses, said it will lay off more than 2,000 additional workers over the next several weeks. The announcement Friday was widely expected by Wall Street analysts, but some questioned whether the cost-cutting steps would allow the computer company to turn a profit. Data General expects to suffer a loss in the quarter.

A developer whose firm rejuvenated urban centers around the country was killed along with his wife and daughter when their private plane crashed between two houses. Killed were pilot Michael Spear, 49, president of The Rouse Co., his wife, Judy, 47, and their 19-year-old daughter, Jodi, police said Friday. The company's projects include Boston's Faneuil Hall shopping area, Harbor Place on the Baltimore waterfront, South Street Seaport in New York and Underground Atlanta.

Stock prices rallied sharply near the close Friday in what analysts termed a technical rebound from the market's recent slide. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had plunged 173.02 points over the three previous sessions, climbed 49.50 to 2,532.92. It ended the week down 111.88 points. The dollar rose sharply and gold prices were higher. Bond prices continued lower on Middle East tensions. Cattle futures prices slipped, soybeans and wheat advanced, while corn was lower.
Editors: Financial institutions in London were closed Monday for a bank holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan, Hitachi Study Joint Information Systems Project
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. and electronics giant Hitachi Ltd. are studying the possibility of creating a new company to develop and manufacture information systems for automobiles, the two companies said Monday. Potential projects include facsimile machines, navigation systems and digital telephone and other services to be built into Nissan automobiles, the companies said. A Nissan spokesman said the field is promising, noting that other Japanese car makers seem to be pursuing similar joint projects with electronics and communications companies. The companies said they had not yet made a commitment to work together on the project and that no decisions have yet been made on capitalization or an establishment date for the new company.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Jumps by 15
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose by 15 this week to 1,002, according to a widely-followed index of drilling activity released Monday. The count had dropped by five a week ago after rising by 26 rigs the previous week. A year ago this week, the count was 909, the Houston-based oil toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. said Monday. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, New Mexico led the gains list by adding 10 new rigs, followed closely by Texas, which added nine. Other increases were posted in North Dakota and Oklahoma, each of which added six, and Ohio, which added one rig. Kansas led the states posting declines with a loss of seven rigs for the week, while Colorado and Pennsylvania each saw a loss of five rigs. Of the other states posting a loss, California was down two, while Louisiana, Michigan and Wyoming, which each lost a rig.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Completes Sale of Mediplex, Leaves Health Care Field
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. on Monday said it has completed the sale of The Mediplex Group Inc. and Mediplex Construction, the cosmetics company's only remaining health care businesses. The sales of Mediplex Group to Diamond Health Care Acquisition Corp. and of Mediplex Construction to Diamond Health Care Development Corp. concluded Avon's plan to exit the health care industry. ``Avon now is entirely focused on beauty and direct sellling, which are our heritage and our strength,'' Avon Chairman and Chief Executive Officer James Preston said. The New York-based beauty products marketer accelerated a program to concentrate on its core business, improve profitability and trim debt last year in defending itself against unwanted takeover offers. Avon said that at the closing it received about $40 million in cash, excluding a working capital adjustment and additional investments in Mediplex, plus a $40 million note to be repaid by a bond issue that is scheduled to be completed within 60 days. The sale proceeds will be used to reduce Avon's debt, the company said. In the past 20 months, Avon has cut its debt by about 40 percent to less than $650 million from $1.13 billion. Diamond Health Care Acquisition Corp. and Diamond Health Care Development Corp. are based in Waltham, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: BellSouth, CellTelCo Joining in Paging Venture
DOC.TEXT: BellSouth Enterprises and CellTelco Nationwide Paging Partnership announced plans Monday to launch a joint nationwide paging service. The agreement between MobileComm, a BellSouth subsidiary, and CellTelCo is subject to regulatory approval. The operation would be managed by a committee including representatives of the two companies and would be marketed by MobileComm. The deal calls for CellTelCo to contribute its license for a nationwide paging system in return for 50 percent of the partnership. MobileComm would provide network facilities and capital in exchange for the remaining 50 percent. MobileComm said it also would offer to buy an equity interest in CellTelCo when the deal is finalized. The amount of that purchase was not disclosed. ``This joint venture with CellTelCo will allow BellSouth to be a major participant in the development of the national paging industry,'' said Earle Mauldin, group vice president for mobile systems at BellSouth Enterprises, a management division of BellSouth Corp., the regional telephone company. ``This important relationship ... allows our partners to fully participate in the high-growth nationwide paging business,'' said CellTelCo general partner Robert Blow.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Lower on Perception of Eased Middle East Tension
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders attribute the lower prices to the perception the crisis in the Persian Gulf is easing. One trader notes that the tone for grain and soybean prices were set by the New York commodity markets, where oil and precious metals prices dropped sharply this morning. ``Deflationary forces are at work,'' said Victor Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. ``The fear of war remains, but it has abated somewhat.'' Also pushing grain and soybean prices lower is the weather. Hot and dry conditions prevail in the Midwest, ideal growing weather for the corn and soybean crops. DOC.HEAD: Greece Deregulates Beef Imports In Line With EC
DOC.TEXT: Greece lifted controls Monday on beef imports in line with its European Community partners, the Trade Ministry said. The move, effective immediately, followed a 1988 ruling by the European Court and a warning by the EC's executive Commission that Greece should comply with European Community regulations. ``Greece, with some delay, has adapted to existing practice in the EC,'' the ministry statement said. Under the new ruling, wholesale prices for beef products are determined by market forces, with some controls to prevent excessive profits, the statement said. Importers and wholesalers may now go beyond the previous profit-ceiling of 15 drachmas a kilogram, or 4.5 cents a pound. But the government will intervene when profits rise too high. The ministry did not define excessive profits.

DOC.HEAD: SEC to Seek Sanctions Against Florida Man
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators launched an administrative action Monday against a Florida man accused of selling more than $4 million in unregistered or risky securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission charged that Michael C. Beatty, of St. Petersburg, Fla., sold $4.2 million in promissory notes and other unregistered securities to investors between 1984 and 1988, while falsely claiming they were safe investments in a sound company. The SEC also alleged that Beatty did not disclose to investors that Minnesota authorities had ordered him to stop selling the securities in 1987. The action by the SEC follows a default judgment by a federal court in Minneapolis against Beatty ordering him to pay back more than $1 million to investors. On June 1, a federal judge in Minneapolis issued an injunction against Beatty, co-owner of Investment and Tax Services Inc., barring him from further alleged securities law violations after he failed to respond to SEC allegations. The judge also ordered Beatty to pay back $1.47 million to investors, although Beatty has filed for bankruptcy protection. Tim Warren, an enforcement division branch chief at the SEC's Chicago regional office, said the SEC was seeking a hearing before an administrative judge to determine what sanctions, if any, should be imposed against Beatty following the Minneapolis court ruling. Possible sanctions range from censure to a bar from the securities industry. Attempts to reach Beatty for comment were unsuccessful. There was no telephone listing for him in St. Petersburg under the address supplied in court papers.

DOC.HEAD: Tumble Over News From Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Lessening tension in the Middle East punched down oil prices by more than $4 per barrel today in a selloff that professional traders called the biggest one-day decline in recent memory. Prices of wholesale unleaded gasoline and other refined petroleum products also plummeted in response to a sense that the threat of war has receded in the world's most abundant oil region. ``It's an easing of the tensions,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inronze at the Tchaikovsky competition.
