DOC.HEAD: Prices Drop as Concerns Ease Over Mideast Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as heavy losses in other markets heavily influenced trading in the Chicago pits. ``The market looked at the outside markets and saw gold and silver down sharply'' and followed suit, said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in Chicago. ``Fundamentally, there was no reason for the soybeans to be down, but last week's rally made the market vulnerable to a selloff.'' The weather also exerted pressure on soybean prices, as hot and dry conditions prevailed in the Midwest and raised expectations for higher yields. Soybean prices got some support from dryness in the Mississippi delta, with the crop expected to be hurt if conditions do not improve. Corn prices also were hurt by the weather, as Friday's 6- to 10-day forecast from the National Weather Service called for a warming trend in the Midwest. At the close, wheat was 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.81{ cents a bushel; corn was 3\ cents to 6{ cents lower with September at $2.52 a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $1.13{ cents a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents to 11{ cents lower with September at $6.19 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: GM to Increase Air Bags in Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said Monday it would boost the number of new cars equipped with driver-side air bags to about 1.3 million in 1991, up from about 450,000 this year. The world's largest automaker also said it planned to have the safety devices in nearly all of its domestically made cars by 1995. The 1.3 million cars are expected to represent between one-third and one-half of GM's 1991 sales. Chrysler Corp. currently equips all of its North American-made cars with air bags and Ford Motor Co. has air bags in about half of its fleet.

DOC.HEAD: Convict Four in Finance Scandal That Rocked Britain
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Monday convicted four prominent professionals including the ex-head of Guinness PLC for misconduct over the brewing giant's multibillion-dollar takeover of a Scottish distiller four years ago. The convictions capped a stunning chapter in what became known as the biggest white-collar fraud in British history, the seamy side of the country's explosive financial-market growth last decade. It tainted some of the most respected names in British business and was described by investigators as a web of greed and deceit that in many respects mirrored Wall Street's insider trading scandal of the late 1980s. After nearly a week of deliberations, the jury at Southwark Crown Court returned guilty verdicts on 19 of 20 counts against former Guinness chairman and chief executive officer Ernest Saunders; Gerald Ronson, chairman of Heron International PLC; former stockbroker Anthony Parnes; and millionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons. Four other men still face trial for their alleged involvement in the scheme to illegally arrange for the purchase of Guinness stock during the takeover fight for Distillers Co., a Scotch whisky and gin maker, in 1986. Saunders, 54, was convicted of two charges of conspiracy to contravene the Prevention of Fraud (Investments) Act, eight charges of false accounting and two charges of theft. He was acquitted of illegally destroying documents. Ronson, 50, was found guilty of conspiracy to contravene the Prevention of Fraud (Investments) Act, two charges of false accounting and one of theft. Parnes, 44, was found guilty of four charges of false accounting and two of theft. The jury convicted Lyons, 74, on two charges of conspiracy, three charges of false accounting and one of theft. Saunders, who has maintained he is a scapegoat, smiled wryly as the jury foreman read the verdicts. Afterwards, as he was led away, he waved to son James and daughter Joanna in the court's public gallery. ``We will never accept that our father has been dishonest,'' his son said afterward. ``We will continue the fight to help him clear his name.'' Judge Denis Henry said sentencing would take place Tuesday for Saunders, Ronson and Parnes, and on Sept. 25 for Lyons, who is to undergo surgery this week. The four were accused of orchestrating an illegal operation to support Guinness' stock price through undisclosed purchases of Guinness shares, and thus make the brewer's $5.18 billion offer of cash and stock more attractive than a rival bid from supermarket operator Argyll Group PLC. Guinness succeeded in April 1986 in what was then Britain's largest takeover. In December of that year, the Department of Trade and Industry announced it was investigating and Saunders was arrested in May 1987. Other arrests followed. The judge ruled that because of the complexity of the case it should be split into two trials. In the second trial, expected to start in October, Saunders will be joined by Roger Seelig, 44, former Morgan Grenfell and Co. Ltd. corporate finance director; Lord Patrick Spens, 47, former director of corporate finance at the merchant bank Henry Ansbacher and corporate finance partner of the investment firm Cazenove and Co. Ltd.; and David Mayhew, 48, who continues as senior corporate finance partner of the investment firm Cazenove and Co. The seven men have pleaded innocent to all the charges and until now each has been freed on about $850,000 bail. The eighth man is U.S. lawyer Thomas Ward, whom British police are seeking to have extradited from the United States. Ward has denied wrongdoing. The case was brought to trial by Britain's Serious Fraud Office, set up two years ago to investigate and prosecute complex fraud cases. Former Guinness director Jonathan Guinness said Monday that while he felt sorry for Saunders and his family, ``I don't see how the jury could have come to any other verdict.''
The stock market rallied sharply today as fears of war in the Persian Gulf eased and oil prices fell. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 76.49 at 2,609.41.

DOC.HEAD: Stock, Bond Prices Jump as Oil Prices Retreat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Treasury bond ...,' to CORRECT description of the movement of the bond's yield in relation to its price.
DOC.TEXT: Stock and bond prices jumped sharply today and the price of oil plummeted as Mideast tensions appeared to ease and OPEC ministers gathered to discuss boosting crude oil production. The value of the dollar dropped in foreign exchange as it appeared the worst of the Iraqi crisis may have passed. The dollar's value typically is supported in times of international turmoil by investors who buy the currency as a safe haven. Iraq had demanded that the U.S. ambassador in Kuwait leave the embassy in that nation, and Iraqi troops surrounded the embassy over the weekend. But Iraq did not press its demand by using the troops, helping ease market jitters about the eruption of armed conflict, traders said. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 77.48 points to 2,610.40 by 3 p.m. EDT. In the broader stock market, gaining issues outnumbered losers by nearly 7 to 1 among New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,463 up, 226 down and 279 unchanged. Earlier, prices climbed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange amid optimism about the Middle East situation. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 976.00 points, or 4.04 percent, to close at 25,141.76. The stock exchange in London was closed for a national holiday. Oil prices plummeted. In mid-afternoon trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the world's largest market for petroleum, the October-delivery price of light sweet crude dropped $4.66 to $26.25 per barrel. In Vienna, representatives of 11 of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered at an informal session. Ten of the nations have agreed in principle to authorize an oil production increase, said a delegation source, who demanded anonymity. About 4 million barrels of oil a day have been lost to the world market because of the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The sanctions were imposed after Iraq invaded and occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2. Treasury bond prices moved sharply higher. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 1 7-16 points, or $14.38 per $1,000 face value. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, fell to 9.00 percent from 9.15 percent Friday. The yield of the so-called long bond is an important rate used to set the interest on some mortgages and other loans. Bond traders said their market was more optimistic that a negotiated settlement could be reached in the Mideast through the efforts of the United Nations. The financial markets have feared that the outbreak of a war would further disrupt oil supplies, sending inflation higher. Inflation is the greatest fear of the bond market, since it erodes the value of the fixed-return securities. Inflation also worries stock traders, since it puts a squeeze on corporate profits and can lead to higher interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Independent Gas Station Operators Protest Prices
DOC.TEXT: Groups of independent gas station operators blocked petroleum depots Monday in the Lyon and Montpellier regions of France to protest a cut in their profit margins due to the Gulf crisis. Riot police dislodged about 30 operators blocking access at the Edouard-Harriot depot in Lyon. The action was aimed at stopping tanker trucks from entering to load up with gasoline. About 20 independent operators blocked two depots in the Herault region in southern France. The action lasted all day at the depot in Frontignac, officials said. Independent operators are calling on the government to guarantee them a minimum profit margin and to abolish gas price controls which have reduced their profit margins.

Stock prices ran up their sharpest gain of the year today as fears of war in the Middle East abated and the price of oil fell. Stocks began to recover on Friday, when the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 49.50 points from its lowest level in more than 13 months. Analysts said the market gathered fresh momentum over the weekend when fears of war in the Persian Gulf went unrealized. At the same time, many of the Street's chart-watchers argued that stocks were ripe for a rebound after their steep drop since mid-July. The market got some help from oil prices, which tumbled from last week's highs, and the bond market, where interest rates fell. Brokers said investors also were heartened by conjecture that the Federal Reserve had become increasingly willing to relax its credit policy as recession worries intensified of late.

DOC.HEAD: Gannett Exec Takes Posts with Time Warner's Southern Progress
DOC.TEXT: The president of Gannett News Services, Nancy Woodhull, has been named executive vice president and editor in chief at Time Warner Inc.'s Southern Progress Corp., it was announced Monday. In the new job, Ms. Woodhull will be responsible for overseeing the editorial direction of the magazines Southern Living, Progressive Farmer, Southern Accents, Travel South and Cooking Light. The post is newly created, the Birmingham, Ala.-based regional book and magazine publisher said in a news release. Don Logan, president and chief executive, said the company has expanded to five magazines from two over the past few years and needed an experienced editorial manager to oversee the publications. Ms. Woodhull, 45, has been a professional journalist for about 26 years, and was a founding editor and the first managing editor-news at Gannett Co. Inc.'s national newspaper USA Today. In 1984, she was named vice president of Gannett New Media, which has explored new products and technology with an emphasis in spinoffs from USA Today. In 1988, she became president of Gannett News Services, which operates a national wire, radio and TV service available exclusively to Gannett's 83 newspapers, 10 television stations and 16 radio stations. In a telephone interview, she said she had submitted her resignation on Friday, effective Oct. 1. Asked why she was leaving Gannett, she said, ``It's more a case of going to something. I was very impressed with the magazines Southern Progress puts out,'' she said. Ms. Woodhull joined Gannett in 1975 as a night city editor for the Times-Union in Rochester, N.Y. She had been a reporter for the Detroit Free Press. She served as managing editor at the Times-Union and at another Rochester paper, the Democrat and Chronicle, before moving to USA Today in 1982. She is a native of Matawan, N.J., and has made her home for nine years in McLean, Va., with her husband, William D. Watson. They have a daughter. Time Warner is a New York-based entertainment and media conglomerate which owns Southern Progress through its Time Publishing Ventures Inc. unit.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: of late.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 78.71 to 2,611.63. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by nearly 6 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,464 up, 252 down and 271 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 160.15 million shares, against 199.04 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index climbed 5.14 to 176.19.

DOC.HEAD: UTC Makes Management Changes At Otis And Carrier Subsidiaries
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. announced Monday it was reorganizing the hierarchy at its Carrier Corp. and Otis elevator subsidiaries. Karl J. Krapek, president and chief operating officer at Otis elevator, was named president and chief executive officer of Carrier Corp. He replaces William A. Wilson, who was transferred to United Technologies as senior vice president, commercial-industrial operations, until he retires March 31, 1991. Jean-Pierre van Rooy, president of Otis' North American operations, succeeds Krapek. Van Rooy will hold the title of executive vice president and chief operating officer. John A. Consentino, Jr., group executive at Washington-based Danaher Corp., rejoins UTC as president of Otis' North American operations. Hartford-based United Technologies provides high-technology products and services to the aerospace, building systems and automotive industries. Its products include Pratt & Whitney aircraft engines, Carrier heating and air conditioning systems, Otis elevators and escalators and Sikorsky helicopters.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rolled up their sharpest gain of the year Monday as fears of war in the Persian Gulf abated and oil prices took a steep drop. But the pace of trading slowed, and many analysts said they weren't yet convinced that the market had pulled out of its long summer swoon for good. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 78.71 to 2,611.63, for its biggest daily point gain since it climbed 88.12 points last Oct. 16 in the aftermath of a ``mini-crash'' on Wall Street. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by nearly 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,453 up, 256 down and 287 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 160.15 million shares, down from 199.04 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 197.94 million shares. Stocks began to recover from their 1990 lows on Friday, when the Dow Jones industrial average gained 49.50 points. Analysts said the market gathered fresh momentum over the weekend as the most intense fears of war in the Persian Gulf went unrealized. At the same time, many of the Street's chart-watchers argued that stocks were ripe for a rebound after their severe slide since mid-July. The rally also drew a lot of inspiration from the oil market. Crude oil futures plunged $4 a barrel to $26.91, registering the most dramatic one-daay drop traders could recall at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Brokers said investors also were heartened by conjecture that the Federal Reserve had become increasingly willing to relax its credit policy as recession worries intensified of late. Interest rates fell in the bond market. Point-plus gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up 1{ at 44}; Procter & Gamble, up 4 at 75~; General Electric, up 2[ at 63{; International Business Machines, up 4 at 104], and Ford Motor, up 1[ at 35{. Over-the-counter issues, even more depressed than the prominent NYSE issues in this summer's selloff, also racked up sharp gains. Microsoft climbed 4| to 60|; MCI Communications 1\ to 34, and Sun Microsystems 1\ to 28~. Energy stocks were steady to moderately higher. But precious-metals issues plunged as the price of gold plummeted. ASA Ltd. fell 4] to 48[; Homestake Mining 2[ to 19}, and Newmont Gold 4] to 47. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $92.46 billion, or 3.14 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 5.13 to 176.18. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 11.95 to 380.70, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 9.93 at 321.44. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market picked up 13.94 to 381.27. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 320.73, up 4.44.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Posts Sharp Losses
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped to a post-war low against the German mark Monday while gold prices tumbled more than $25 an ounce amid selling sparked by a perception that tensions have eased in the Middle East. A slide in oil prices relieved some anxiety about the inflationary consequences of a prolonged Persian Gulf conflict and encouraged sales of gold and the dollar. Gold bullion often is bought as a hedge against inflation. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $388.30 a troy ounce, down $26.70 from Friday's close. Later, Republic National Bank quoted an ounce of gold at $389, $25 lower than the late bid Friday. Currency trading was lighter than normal because markets in London were closed for a bank holiday. In European activity, the dollar hit a post-World War II closing low of 1.5423 German marks in Frankfurt, West Germany, down from 1.5575 marks late Friday. The previous lowest closing level for the dollar against the mark was 1.5445 marks, set last Thursday in New York. The dollar traded as low as 1.5385 German marks during the day in Frankfurt before recovering. Its previous intraday low was 1.5400 marks on Thursday. When activity shifted later to North America, the dollar lost ground in New York. It fell to 1.5505 marks from 1.5605 marks late Friday. Currency analysts said rising optimism about chances for a negotiated settlement to the conflict caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait reduced demand for dollars. Investors typically buy dollars as a safe haven for their holdings during times of international turmoil. Worries about the flagging U.S. economy, temporarily put aside during a dollar buying binge that followed the Iraqi invasion, were given a higher priority in trading decisions. Speculation that U.S. interest rates eventually will be nudged lower to foster an economic revival has weighed on the dollar. If rates fall in the U.S. while rising or remaining unchanged overseas, returns on dollar-denominated securities would be less appealing. Michael Faust of MMS International in New York said the Japanese yen took center stage in North American currency trading. Buying interest in the yen coincided with the decline in world oil prices, a welcome development for oil import-dependent Japan. A rebound in the Japanese stock market also helped restore faith in the yen. Oil prices were bid down on the assumption that many OPEC countries may boost output temporarily to compensate for the gap left by the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti petroleum. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met informally in Vienna, Austria, to discuss a response to the Persian Gulf crisis. A barrel of light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, plunged $4 to settle at $26.91 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. By the time trading was done in New York, the dollar was quoted at 144.20 yen, down from 146.75 late Friday.Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 144.80 Japanese yen from 145.70 at Friday's close. In Europe, the British pound rose to $1.9505 from $1.9445 Friday in London. Sterling gained in New York and a pound fetched $1.94335 compared to $1.9400 on Friday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes included: 1.2735 Swiss francs, up from 1.2720; 5.2010 French francs, down from 5.2360; 1,149.50 Italian lire, down from 1,159.50; and 1.14315 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1353. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, were: 1.2670 Swiss francs, down from 1.2685; 5.1745 French francs, down from 5.2275; 1.7365 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7550; 1,142.75 Italian lire, down from 1,157.50; and 1.1335 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Gold prices fell nearly $9 an ounce in light trading in Switzerland. Precious metals markets in London and Hong Kong were closed for national holidays. In Zurich, gold fell to $401 a troy ounce from $410.75 late Friday. Silver followed gold's lead. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.848 a troy ounce, down from $5.187 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Fall as Middle East Tension Lessens
DOC.TEXT: Most commodity futures prices on the New York and Chicago exchanges were battered Monday as concerns about the possibility of war decreased, with oil off sharply on reports OPEC oil ministers may soon decide to raise crude output. Precious metals futures fell; grain and soybeans were down; and livestock and pork futures gained. The lack of military action in the Persian Gulf provided the bearish tone for energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange on the improved prospects for a diplomatic solution to the crisis triggered by Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. The perceptions that the crisis may be resolved peacefully were prompted by the Security Council's weekend sanction of force against Iraq. Other diplomatic activity suggested the Iraqis were feeling acute isolation over their seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and were willing to talk. An OPEC meeting in Vienna also led traders to bid down the price of oil. Robert Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said it is likely the market will continue its downward trend Tuesday. Despite the sharp drop in oil prices, analysts said crude can move back up as easily as it moves down, depending on whatever news comes from the Middle East. Light sweet crude settled $2 to $4.01 lower with the contract for delivery in October at $26.91 a barrel; heating oil was 6 cents to 12.86 cents lower with September at 78.10 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 6 cents to 17.10 cents lower with September at 87.56 cents a gallon. Precious metals futures declined sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange, with an analyst saying the decline shows the precious metals market is fundamentally weak. ``The movement upward was based on sharply higher oil prices and political factors,'' said Peter Cardillo, an analyst with Jesup, Josephthal & Co. in New York. ``The market gave back a good portion of the gains of the past three weeks.'' Cardillo noted that the precious metals market was weak across the board, with selling by banks, speculators and funds. He said it is likely the market will see more selling on Tuesday, before gaining some support. Gold was $26.70 to $28.90 lower with August at $388.30 a troy ounce; silver was 34.2 cents to 39 cents lower with August at $4.848 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``The market looked at the outside markets and saw gold and silver down sharply'' and followed suit, said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in Chicago. ``Fundamentally, there was no reason for the soybeans to be down, but last week's rally made the market vulnerable to a selloff.'' The weather also exerted pressure on soybean prices, as hot and dry conditions prevailed in the Midwest and raised expectations for higher yields. Soybean prices got some support from dryness in the Mississippi delta, with the crop expected to be hurt if conditions do not improve. Corn prices also were hurt by the weather, as Friday's 6- to 10-day forecast from the National Weather Service called for a warming trend in the Midwest. Wheat settled 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with September at $2.81{ cents a bushel; corn was 3\ cents to 6} cents lower with September at $2.52 a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $1.13{ cents a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 11 cents lower with September at $6.19 a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Buying interest in livestock was spurred by a sharp rise in prices on the New York Stock Exchange and the declines in the oil and metals market, traders said. Pork futures were boosted by Friday's U.S. Agriculture Department cold storage report which showed a greated-than-expected drawdown of frozen bellies in July. Live cattle were .60 cent to 1.23 cents higher with October at 76.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .53 cent to 1.45 cents higher with August at 88.70 cents a pound; hogs were .20 cent to .78 cent higher with October at 49.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher with February at 54.37 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court To Reconsider Chestman Ruling
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court agreed Monday to reconsider a decision overturning the conviction of a stockbroker charged with trading on inside information about the 1986 takeover of the Waldbaum supermarket chain. Federal prosecutors had asked for the rehearing, saying that the May 2 decision by a three-judge panel of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threatened future insider trading prosecutions. A full panel of the appeals court Nov. 9 will rehear the appeal of the stockbroker, Robert Chestman of Gruntal & Co. In the May decision, judges ruled 2-1 to vacate Chestman's March 1989 conviction on securities fraud, mail fraud and perjury charges. The conviction stemmed from trades he made after receiving information about A&P's takeover of Waldbaum Inc. from a client who was a Waldbaum family member. The court found there was no proof Chestman knew the information was confidential when he received it from Keith Loeb, a nephew by marriage to company founder Ira Waldbaum. The judges also ruled there was no evidence that Loeb, who cooperated with authorities, violated a breach of fiduciary duty in giving the information to Chestman. In court papers, prosecutors said the decision was incorrect and would ``seriously impair the government's ability to bring future insider trading cases against tippees.'' ``Moreover, the decision may well be viewed by the securities industry as providing a safe harbor within which to trade on inside information,'' the government said. Chestman's attorney, Elkan Abramowitz, said he was not surprised the appeals court granted a rehearing but said he did not immediately want to respond to the government's arguments.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Sees Wild Slide Amid Prospects for Mideast Peace
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell by $4 a barrel Monday, the sharpest one-day decline traders could remember, in a selloff that reflected easing fear of a war in the Middle East. The notion that there might not be any shooting in the nearly month-old conflict also punched down wholesale prices of unleaded gasoline and home heating oil. ``The surprise in the market place may have been an improved outlook for a peaceful solution in the Middle East,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Traders were responding partly to news that U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar would meet Thursday in Jordan with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to discuss the crisis that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. A lack of hostilities over the weekend and the likelihood of increased oil production by OPEC nations also helped push oil prices down, analysts said. In Vienna, sources said ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appeared near agreement on an informal deal that would allow some countries to temporarily increase production in response to the Persian Gulf crisis. Light sweet crude, the benchmark U.S. blend, fell $4 to $26.91 per barrel for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a key market for petroleum. That snapped a streak of three days in which oil traded above $30 per barrel for the first time in nearly five years. The Merc doesn't keep records of petroleum price ranges, but exchange officials and traders said they couldn't recall a bigger one-day drop. Crude oil fell $3.04 per barrel on the Merc on April 24, 1989, following a sharp rise that occurred amid jitters caused by the Exxon Valdez accident and a gas leak and explosion on a major oil platform in the North Sea, said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. There were a also couple of one-day drops exceeding $2 in December 1985 and January 1986, after OPEC nations announced pricing changes that sent oil into a long decline, Hittle said. Despite the recent wild swings in crude prices, she said, traders were caught off guard by the sharpness of Monday's decline. ``People were expecting a correction,'' Hittle said. ``I don't think anyone thought it would be quite so steep.'' Unleaded gasoline also fell farther in one day than anyone at the exchange could remember, dropping 17.10 cents to 87.56 cents per gallon for September delivery. Gasoline had risen above the $1 mark for the first time last week as it went through seven straight days of record high closes, but at one point Monday it was down more than 20 cents per gallon. Crude oil, at its lowest on Monday, traded $4.86 per barrel less than Friday's closing price of $30.91. Home heating oil plummeted 12.86 cents to 78.10 cents per gallon for September delivery. Natural gas dipped from $1.525 to $1.502 per 1,000 cubic feet on October contracts. Hittle said Monday's downturn was accentuated by a British banking holiday, which prompted traders in London to make oil deals elsewhere. ``We're getting European selling,'' Hittle said. That can force U.S. prices farther down if they are falling or farther up if they happen to be rising, she said. Those who follow oil prices said there is no reliable way to predict where they will go, because of the uncertainties in the Persian Gulf. Some said prices could easily shoot back up. ``We're not by any means to the point where we're going to call a full turn here,'' Baker said. ``Tune in every morning to see what the newspapers say and what the radio bulletins are giving us. We start from there.''

DOC.HEAD: Fall 78 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: General Cinema Corp. said Monday that its third-quarter profits plunged 78 percent, in part because of a drop in summer moviegoers. For the three months ended July 31, General Cinema reported earnings of $5.7 million, or 8 cents per share, against earnings of $25.6 million, or 35 cents per share, in the same 1989 period. Revenue rose 3.1 percent to $506 million from $491.3 million a year earlier. Earnings from the firm's theaters division plunged to $1.3 million from $12.2 million a year ago. For the first nine months of 1990, General Cinema Theaters had an operating loss of $1.7 million, compared to operating profits of $9.7 million in the same year-ago period. ``Summer pictures this year did not attract the number of patrons which the industry had been anticipating, resulting in attendance levels well below the record levels of the summer of 1989,'' General Cinema Chairman Richard A. Smith said in a statement. ``The lower patronage, combined with continuing higher film and occupancy costs, resulted in the disappointing earnings performance,'' he said. Smith said sluggish theater revenues were likely to continue through the fiscal year. During the quarter, General Cinema Theaters opened 52 screens and closed 10 others, bringing to 1,488 the number of screens at 314 theaters. General Cinema's income from interest and dividends dropped to $22.3 million from $41.4 million a year ago, reflecting payment of nearly $600 million of capital gains taxes in January related to the firm's sale of its soft-drink bottling business. The sale reduced the amount of General Cinema's investable funds to $1.1 billion from $1.7 billion a year ago. General Cinema's consolidated statements include operating results of Neiman Marcus Group, the company's 60-percent owned retailing subsidiary, with a lag of one quarter. Smith said that after deducting minority interest, Neiman Marcus contributed $2.8 million in earnings for the quarter, compared to $3.9 million a year ago. The Neiman Marcus current year results are for the period through its third quarter ended May 5. General Cinema profits for the first nine months of the year were $55.6 million, or 75 cents per share, down 43 percent from $98 million, or $1.33 per share, in the same period last year. The 1989 figures included an after-tax gain of $52 million, or 70 cents per share, from the sale of securities.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon To Spend $2.8 Million To Settle Refinery Pollution Suit
DOC.TEXT: Exxon U.S.A. will spend $2.8 million to improve environmental safeguards at a refinery to settle a lawsuit for fouling a New Jersey waterway, officials said Monday. The settlement resolves allegations that Exxon violated the terms of its state wastewater discharge permit at its refinery in Bayonne, which discharges into the Kill Van Kull waterway. The New Jersey Public Interest Research Group and Friends of the Earth filed the lawsuit in May 1989 in federal district court in Newark under the federal Clean Water Act, which provides for such citizen action. Exxon, without any finding or admission of liability, agreed to invest $2.8 million for ``environmentally beneficial mitigation projects'' at the Bayonne facility, NJPIRG said. The measures are supplementary to the existing wastewater treatment system at the facility. Exxon also must comply with effluent limitations and other requirements of its wastewater discharge permit, issued by the state Department of Environmental Protection. Exxon will spend $1.8 million to install geodesic dome roofs on 15 petroleum storage tanks to prevent rainwater from entering the tanks. Contaminated rainwater now must be drained to the facility's wastewater collection system for processing in the wastewater treatment plant and then discharged into the Kill Van Kull. Domes will reduce the wastewater at its source, NJPIRG said. Exxon will spend an additional $995,000 on a petroleum product collection system at its barge pier. The closed above-ground collection system will reduce the potential for pollution at its source, NJPIRG said. Exxon spokesman Amos Plante said the agreement ``demonstrates Exxon's commitment not only to comply fully with all permit requirements but also to take further responsible steps designed to reduce or eliminate waste materials at their source.''

DOC.HEAD: Hits Lowest Point Since 1983
DOC.TEXT: Consumer confidence in the U.S. economy dropped this month to the lowest level since 1983 and raised the biggest threat of recession in many years, the Conference Board organization said Monday. The New York-based business research group said its Consumer Confidence Index, a widely watched barometer of perceptions about the economy, fell 18 points from the July level to 83.8, partly because of fears about the Middle East. That was the lowest level since 83.1 in April 1983, when the economy was emerging from a recession. Consumer confidence is considered a crucial element of economic forecasting because it indicates American willingness to borrow and spend. Consumerism accounts for a major portion of all U.S. economic activity. The findings substantiated the view of other economists who say consumers were increasingly worried even before the Middle East crisis caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But the survey showed the invasion heightened those fears because of the rising price of oil, resurrecting memories of the 1970s oil shocks. ``Given the economic uncertainties generated by the Middle East crisis, a loss in the consumer's sense of security is inevitable,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the group's Consumer Research Center. ``Even before the Kuwait invasion, there were indications that the economy might be in trouble,'' he said. ``But if the present political crisis is not resolved quickly, and people become more hesitant to spend, the economy could soon move into recession. Recession is more likely now than it has been in many years.'' The most notable elements of the Conference Board survey showed showed 20 percent of respondents felt conditions are good, down from 23 percent in July. The number who feel conditions are bad rose to 24 percent from 21 percent. Only 21 percent feel the number of jobs are plentiful, down from nearly 26 percent in July and nearly 32 percent a year ago. By contrast, the number of respondents who feel jobs are difficult to find rose to nearly 26 percent, vs. 22 percent in July. Nearly 19 percent of survey respondents feel conditions will worsen in the next six months, up from 12 percent in July. Less than 14 percent believe the situation will improve, vs. 17 percent in July. The survey, covering 5,000 households nationwide, calculates an index of consumer confidence based on questions about business conditions, employment, income, vacation plans and major purchases over the next six months.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Repairing Engine Mount Cracks in British Airways 767
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co. said Monday that crews have been sent to Britain to replace engine-mount pylons on all seven of British Airways' 767s after cracks were found on six of the jets. The British carrier grounded the 767s, powered by Rolls-Royce engines, after finding a crack in a pylon on one of the twin-jets during routine maintenance, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokeswoman Elizabeth Reese said. ``We inspected the others and five more had similar cracks so we grounded the fleet,'' said John Lampl, British Airways spokesman in New York. British Airways is the only operator of 767s with Rolls-Royce engines. Other 767s have either General Electric or Pratt & Whitney engines and are not affected, Reese said. British Airways took delivery of the first of its 767 wide-bodies in February. Boeing redesigned the engine mounts to fix the problem and is paying the repair costs, Reese said. She said she had no idea what the cost would be. The engine mount pylon holds the engine to the wing. The Federal Aviation Administration has approved the redesigned part and Boeing was awaiting approval from Britain's Civil Aviation Authority, Reese said.

DOC.HEAD: Contractor Pleads Guilty in Scheme to Defraud Government
DOC.TEXT: A maker of Army field radios agreed Monday to plead guilty and pay $4.65 million to settle federal criminal and civil charges in a scheme to defraud the government by falsifying test results. E-Systems Inc. of Dallas pleaded guilty to a three-count criminal information in U.S. District Court charging that it conspired to falsify records and test results of tactical field radios supplied to the Army. Prosecutors charged the company repeatedly altered performance records and concealed repairs and defects in test radios to ensure the Army would accept and pay for them. The investigation began in 1985 after the Army ended two E-Systems contracts to build radios through its Memcor Division in Bushnell, Fla. The company had been building the Army's principal vehicle-carried field radios since 1969. E-Systems appealed the termination and the testing program irregularities were noticed at that time. The company later sued the government over the termination. In its plea, E-Systems agreed to pay a $2 million criminal fine and $1.8 million in restitution. The plea agreement also calls for the company to drop its pending $38 million lawsuit against the government. Also, the company will pay $850,000 to cover false claims submitted as part of its civil lawsuit. Earlier this month, three former managers and a former supervisor at E-Systems' Memcor Division were indicted on charges of repeatedly falsifying records and test results to conceal failures and defects in the radios. In January, a front-line supervisor of production, Sadonna S. Hobbs, was convicted of perjury relating to her denials of the activity. She is serving a 16-month prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Overturns $148 Million Award to Liggett Group
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday overturned a $148.8 million jury award to cigarette maker Liggett Group against Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp., which had been found guilty of predatory pricing. U.S. District Judge Frank W. Bullock in Greensboro, N.C., said the jury had come to its decision in March using legally insufficient evidence. He denied a motion for a retrial by Liggett, which had accused its larger rival of trying to put it out of business. Brown & Williamson is the nation's third largest cigarette maker with brands including Kool and Viceroy. Liggett, the nation's smallest cigarette maker, has the L&M, Lark and Chesterfield brands. Bullock said Liggett had failed to show that Brown & Williamson had injured Liggett in a dispute that centered on generic cigarettes, which cost about one third less than the average pack price of $1.60. Alan Hilburg, a Liggett spokesman, said company lawyers were studying Bullock's decision and had not decided whether to appeal. In its lawsuit, Liggett argued that Brown & Williamson in 1984 and 1985 used volume discounts and rebates to wholesalers, which forced Liggett to match the incentives and reduced its profits. Liggett's market share was the industry's lowest before it entered the discount business. Liggett, based in Durham, N.C., also charged that Louisville, Ky.-based Brown & Williamson had copied Liggett's plain black-and-white packaging in an attempt to confuse consumers. After 115 days of testimony and nine days of deliberations, a federal jury in Greensboro awarded Liggett $49.6 million in damages, which automatically is tripled under the law. ``The judge's ruling underscores that what happened when Brown & Williamson began selling generic cigarettes is exactly what's supposed to happen in a free-enterprise system,'' Brown & Williamson said in a statement. Industry figures show that Liggett Group had a 14.4 percent market share in discount cigarettes in 1989, down from 15.2 percent the previous year. Brown & Williamson's generic share was 23.3 percent in 1989, up from 20.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Stock, Bond Prices Jump as Oil Prices Plummet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `The Nikkei. . . to UPDATE with later Tokyo trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices plunged $4 per barrel and stocks rallied to their best gains of the year Monday, as the financial markets sensed a reduced threat of war in the Mideast and a possible OPEC agreement to boost oil production. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks climbed 78.71 points to close at 2,611.63. It was the Dow's biggest one-day jump since last Oct. 16, when it climbed 88.12 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by nearly 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks. In earling trading Tuesday, prices continued to climb on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, while the dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen, also amid optimism about the Gulf situation. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 518.52 points, or 2.06 percent, to close the morning session at 25,660.28, on top of a 4.04 percent rise Monday. The stock exchange in London was closed for a national holiday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the world's largest market for petroleum, the October-delivery price of light, sweet crude dropped $4 to close at $26.91 per barrel. Traders called it the steepest one-day decline in memory for the benchmark grade of oil. ``That's an enormous decline, and these markets are very, very sensitive to oil prices at this time,'' said John D. Paulus, chief economist at the investment firm Morgan, Stanley & Co. Unleaded gasoline for September delivery fell 17.1 cents a gallon to close at 87.56 cents on the exchange. Among the signs of reduced tensions in the Persian Gulf, traders said the markets were encouraged that Iraq did not use military measures to enforce its demand that the U.S. ambassador in Kuwait leave the embassy. Iraqi troops had surrounded the embassy over the weekend, but an Iraqi deadline passed with no action taken. In addition, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar planned to meet Thursday with Iraq's foreign minister to try to mediate an end to the crisis. In Vienna, representatives of 11 of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered at an informal session. Ten of the nations have agreed in principle to allow individual OPEC nations to exceed their oil production quotas, said a delegation source, speaking on condition of anonymity. About 4 million barrels of oil a day have been lost to the world market because of the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti. The sanctions were imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Oil traders said the drop in prices also was accelerated by the market's tendency to make drastic ``corrections'' after prices move too far in one direction. Oil leaped above $30 per barrel last week for the first time in nearly five years. The bond market took encouragement from the oil drop as well, because of its implications for inflation and interest rates. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 19-32 points, or $15.94 per $1,000 face value. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, dropped to 8.99 percent from 9.15 percent Friday. Higher oil prices had threatened to ignite inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-rate securities. The dollar did not join stocks and bonds in the upswing. In New York trading, it fell to 1.5505 German marks from 1.5605 marks late Friday _ a post-war low against the mark. Traders said currency investors remained concerned about the state of the U.S. economy and its impact on the dollar. They said investors have been more concerned about the faltering U.S. economy and its impact on the dollar than on the Mideast upheaval. The dollar's value has been slipping for months, and although it has proven to be a safe haven in times of political turmoil, the currency has gained little from the threat of war in the Mideast.
